The crew of the Milano get into more wild and crazy adventures in Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2.  After a job gone wrong the Guardians end up on the run from the Sovereign and are rescued by a celestial being named Ego who claims to be Peter Quill's real father and takes him to his home world so the two can reconnect, however Gamora suspect that Ego isn't telling them the whole truth; meanwhile Rocket and Groot fend off an attack by the Ravagers.  Kurt Russell joins the cast and delivers a really good performance.  And there are a dozen of fun cameos and Easter eggs that fans are sure to enjoy.  Additionally, director James Gunn keeps the tone lighthearted, just like the first film, and the action is incredibly exciting.  The soundtrack is also especially well-done and does a good job at complimenting the scenes.  It doesn't quite reach the highs of the original, but Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a solid sequel that's extremely entertaining.

Drax was disappointing too- in this movie he has suddenly and inexplicably learned how to crack jokes and use metaphors. He has no other purpose than comic relief, and could have been replaced with howard the duck or a giant chicken and it would have had zero impact on the movie. 
Starlord and the Green girl have zero chemistry. The gold aliens are uninteresting and unthreatening. Thanos "other daughter" is also uninteresting, unthreatening, and her character arc is about as nuanced as a fart joke.

SCOTT: (Dr. Scott Allison, Professor of Psychology, University of Richmond) Greg, looks like the galaxy needs saving yet again. Do you think the Guardians are equal to the task?

GREG: (Greg Smith, Founder of Agile Writers of Richmond, VA) My opinion is guarded at best. Let s recap:

SCOTT: The Guardians are back: Peter Quill (Chris Pratt), Gamora (Zoe Saldana), Drax (Dave Bautista), Rocket (Bradley Cooper), and Baby Groot (Vin Diesel). The group has been asked by the Sovereign race to fight and destroy a huge monster from another dimension. In exchange, the Guardians receive custody of Gamora s evil sister Nebula (Karen Gillan). When the Sovereigns discover that Rocket has stolen valuable batteries, they give chase and force the Guardians to crash land on nearby planet.

GREG: And who should be on that planet but Quill s long lost father, Ego (Kurt Russell). He wants Quill to work with him to rule the galaxy. Ego teaches Quill to draw power from the planet to create magical power balls and other stuff. Meanwhile, Nebula has escaped and is in search of Gamora to kill her. And Drax is making friends with Ego s sidekick, the empath Mantis (Pom Klementieff). While Rocket and Yondu (Michael Rooker) are searching the galaxy for their lost friends. It s wild and wacky mayhem in a galaxy not so far, far away.

SCOTT: Greg, Guardians Vol. 2 fascinated me. I couldn t help think that this entertaining screenplay was penned by a group of Marvel writers who were a bit inebriated -- by alcohol and by the unparalleled success of their movie studio. Guardians Vol. 2 is Marvel s 15th straight number one opening at the domestic box office. And this movie feels like a film drunk on its own success. What this means exactly is that the movie winks at itself and is saturated with irreverence. David Hasselhoff from Baywatch makes a cameo; the soundtrack thunders with 1970s hits; a giant pac-man swallows up the villain; and we learn that Drax has sensitive nipples and generates large turds. Just when I thought that the film was missing a reference to Mary Poppins, sure enough we got one. Marvel films have always boasted some of these droll elements, but along with Deadpool I think the studio has now crossed the line into the comedy genre and is veering perilously close to Spaceballs in the wisecracking department. Don t get me wrong, I enjoyed Guardians Vol. 2. But let s not begin to think about this movie as a serious hero story packed with meaningful life lessons. Guardians Vol. 2 is a high-quality space comedy, and coupled with Deadpool it underscores the increased comedic trajectory of Marvel.

GREG: If by  high-quality  you mean that the filmcraft was excellent, then I ll agree. The CGI, camerawork, and acting are all first-rate. But the story lacked any coherence. The main plotline seemed to be Quill s reuniting with his father and mending the pain of being abandoned by him. The secondary plot involved sisters Gamora and Nebula reconciling after years of sibling rivalry. So, the theme of this movie seems to be  family . But there was scant little plot. There was no  main goal  to be acquired. Rather, we re to be sustained by the ongoing mystery of  who is Ego  and a ton of wisecracks. If Guardians is, indeed, a spoof or farce, then story may fall prey to comedy. As we ve seen recently, horror and comedy stories often lack strong story lines as they, instead, rely on shock and awe. However, I expect more from Marvel and from my science fiction adventure films. There wasn t a clear villain in this story until the very end when Ego is revealed to be evil. Without a strong villain, you cannot have a strong hero. And so, Quill is just following his father along until he realizes that he s not a very nice guy and must be destroyed. But this realization doesn t occur until the three-quarter mark and by then it s much too late. I was hopelessly bored by Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2.

SCOTT: I can see your point, Greg. We ve watched plenty of movies that are long on comedy and short on storytelling. I don t think Guardians Vol. 2 is the best example of movies of this type. There are two stories running parallel here, one involving family division moving toward reconciliation (or lack thereof) and the other focusing on the Guardians  mission to save the universe. The two stories are effectively intertwined, too, with the seemingly good dad, Ego, turning out to be the father from hell, and the seemingly bad dad, Yondu, turning out to be the terrific father. Ego s efforts to destroy the universe must be stopped and our heroes do the job. The transformations here are interesting. Quill, Gamora, and Nebula glean significant insights about family, loyalty, and love. In our book Reel Heroes & Villains, we call this a mental transformation. The character of Yondu seems to especially evolve into selfless heroism, undergoing a moral transformation. Nebula also experiences significant emotional and moral transformations. So all told, I ll have to rate the film highly on this dimension.

GREG: The traits we look for in heroes are here. Quill looks to do the right thing by himself and his crew. Gamora is loyal to Quill and her friends. And even when battling her estranged sister, shows mercy and compassion. The transformations are less clear. Quill doesn t seem changed by his experience. He s still  Star Lord  by the end of the film. And while Gamora and Nebula have reconciled, they re still who they were at the beginning of the film. And Drax and Rocket continue to be Drax and Rocket. And this should come as no surprise - as this is a franchise film. The films are episodic. So, we need our characters to reset at the end of each episode. We keep coming back to these films because we expect to see the characters we ve come to know and love. So, any true transformation is squelched by the need to return the characters to their initial states.

SCOTT: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 represents another Marvel triumph, despite my misgivings about their film products slowly evolving in farce. We have strong, memorable characters comprising the heroic ensemble; there are two parallel-running plots that satisfy us emotionally; and we are treated to remarkable CGI effects. The opening 5-minute scene featuring a dance number by Baby Groot dazzles us and is worth the price of admission by itself. I am concerned that Marvel films are morphing into a theater of the absurd, but even with this concern I would be a curmudgeon to award this film anything less than 4 Reels out of 5. These Guardians remain a diverse and highly enjoyable set of heroes. As you mention, Greg, they possess many heroic traits and their strengths complement one another. They go on a pretty standard hero s journey, encounter unexpected friends along with a surprising villain, they undergo change, and they live up to their job description by saving the galaxy. The timeless message at film s end is that the main hero, Quill, had the secret to success within him all along. I see every reason to award this hero ensemble a rating of 4 Heroes out of 5. Greg, I m surprised you don t see as much hero transformation going on as I do. Perhaps you are focusing only on inner transformation, which is understandable since that s how we describe the concept of transformation in our last Reel Heroes book. But I can t overlook the power of relationship transformation. Relationships in this film undergo vast change -- consider the relationships between (1) Quill and Ego, (2) Quill and Yondu, and (3) Gamora and Nebula. They are all completely metamorphosized. And each relationship metamorphosis reflects deep changes within each party involved in the relationship. As such, I award this film 4 transformation Deltas out of 5. Movie: Transformations: Heroes:

GREG: I guess I m a curmudgeon, then, Scott. I was totally bored by Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2. This was a CGI fest with no story to speak of. I wasn t impressed with Quill s gradual realization that Ego was a bad guy. And I wasn t impressed with Rocket and Yondu flying through 700 wormholes. And I wasn t impressed with the battle between the two sisters Gamora and Nebula. There was no plot and that left me waiting for over 2 hours for something to happen. I give Guardians of the Galaxy, Vol. 2 only 2 out of 5 Reels. These are bland heroes with no particular qualities that made me care about them. Yondu in particular has always been a sort of gray moral character. So when he was revealed to be a father figure for Quill, I was not bowled over. I didn t feel any sense of loss when he died. I give these characters just 2 Heroes out of 5. And while I ll grant you some relationship deltas, Scott. This is an action adventure and I wanted to see something more for transformations. This was not a romantic comedy or drama - so a relationship transformation isn t interesting. But as I said before, these are episodic heroes and transformation is not in their model. I give them 2 Deltas out of 5. Movie: Transformations: Heroes:

SPOILER ALERT!

*** This review contains spoilers ***

When Guardians of the Galaxy (2014) was released, it had become a huge success. Critics as well as fans loved it, and everyone was humming its songs. Naturally, when a sequel was announced, it had to fill the big shoes of its predecessor.

Sequels don't do well in the superhero genre or in any genre actually. Though this film is not all bad, it doesn't match up with the first one. The funky tunes are back and the film is a visual spectacle full of colours.
Where it lacks though is with its villains and character development. Let's talk about character development first. Only some of our characters get the spotlight in this film. As it explores Peter's parentage we learn a bit more about him, Youndu, Gamora and Nebula. Whereas Rocket and Drax are pushed aside.

The villains come off as boring. I don't like films where they make the bad guy look good at first and later reveal their true intentions. The Gold people aren't very memorable either. Most of the jokes do not land and feel forced.

While this sequel isn't on par with the first one, it still keeps you interested, and is still worth watching. Stay till the end of the film for FIVE after-credits scenes.

Recommended!

The inaugural chapter of the most irreverent galactic mercenaries from Marvel was a gigantic turning point in the path set by superhero movies. "Guardians of the Galaxy" was one of the best - and completely fortuitous-proposals in 2014, a carefree sci-fi film that divorced in full from the general storyline that, by requirement, has to follow regarding the super longed final outcome called "Infinity War". Its massive success was mainly due to inexorable features as the different and unusual-at that time-humor types present in the characters, the visuals as artificial as extraordinary or a soundtrack based on the 80's Walkman, which were developed with ease on the three true foundations: Story (screenplay), Actors (performances) and director (decisions). From all, that colorful and hilarious mix comes the expected "Vol. 2 ", which remains stable in relation to the first one and satisfies the enormous expectation that was on the shoulders of the guardians, who not only saved cosmic characters, also a couple of terrestrial individuals.

If the creative outbursts of the writer seemed eccentric in the first film by virtue of the composition of apparently nothing correlated tones and genres, in this one, James Gunn is fully unleashed from any impediment in a story of living planets, hybrids between deities and humans and allusions to Mary Poppins. The director preserves his characteristic flame innovating and relating exotic formulas even in the opening since later in the astonishing 80's introduction, the initial sequence ratifies a cosmic and comical aura almost equal to its predecessor, orchestrated by multi-functional Gunn, a man who knows perfectly how to manage the tools at his disposal. After it sets us in the atmosphere, the plot slides, unlike the previous one, to delve into the traumas and the open questions, including the leitmotif of the feature film: to find Peter Quill's lineage, while each one of the characters receives a meritorious treatment of their past in the form of dyads, having behind them an intergalactic ships army and a father with wicked purposes, getting an emotional and tension level according to its outstanding visual risks.

Here, the triad of elements, that were as original as refreshing in the first installment, are strengthened, getting the same heart with a similar wrapper, it's really a continuation, not a clone. The most important pillar is the story, the plot around which the movie will have to be meant. Before it was about setting up a dysfunctional family, now, it's about being a dysfunctional family. With a general structure established, its writer, who is also a director, chooses to explore and clarify the past of his pieces, since due to its dazzling introduction was possibly a wide and amusing deepening of its roots. In addition, this study is applied to the introduction of new Guardians: Mantis, Yondu, and Nebula, who arrive to transform the quintet into an octet of light hearted fun, finding in them a new breath to irreverence of the core stars. Likewise, within that sea of fabulous inclusions, the scriptwriters insinuate and strengthen what they have been announcing for some time: Independent of the appearances in "Infinity War" or future movies, the story-as a team-of the Guardians will have three films, nothing more, nothing less, however, the filmmaker has insinuated that although the official closing of the cycle of Stard-Lord and his gang ends with the longed for third one, we could see more movies, in the distant future, of the Guardians, but... Of who? With great feasibility may be referring to the ancestors of Gamora and Groot, the former Guardians who, as cameos, make their first glimpse into the universe, a new crew led by master Sylvester Stallone, of whom it has been spoken will have a leading role in the development of Phase Three, but, would Marvel is willing to change the unbridled tone of the guardians, which served as a lighthouse in past years for the atmosphere of its movies, for a more serious one of the guardians of before? It's unlikely but lucrative.

Marvel risks its life with an unseen masterstroke in its film compendium so far, a knack that added and reduced at the same time, a narrative skill called Ego the Living Planet. With a brilliant performance by Kurt Russell, this living man-planet not only catches the attention of the new characters but also steals easily the antagonist of the central villain: Ayesha. Elizabeth Debicki seems wasted in this commotion of modernistic faces, her mean and authoritarian attitude, besides having a little time on screen, doesn't get a real impact, the trouble is that she was the main villain, not a supporting character, her impetus of revenge against the guardians are taken to the extreme and despite her excellent performance within the bright chrome and extravagant golden suits, her evildoer has neither effect nor tact. Despite all, it displays the care that Marvel is taken in villains, its weakness in most of the preceding movies, in which the hero is conspicuous by the absence of a real malignancy.

It happens with very few motion pictures, "Guardians" is in that strange but thankful section. Even though humans will always get swept up in visuals, seeing is believing!, James Gun's film, like its predecessor, presents an authentic, nostalgic and a maddening musical compendium from the late 1970s/early 1980s, hits enhancing the scenes with regard to the seen ones in the universe. While "Mr. Blue Sky" by Electric Light Orchestra provides the best and most monumental opening for a Marvel movie,"The Chain" by Fleetwood Mac orchestrates one of the most mind-blowing sequences that Phase 3 of the MCU has been able to set up, to this mix of yesteryear, we can add it a few songs that are right on target in the dramatic moments, which also make way for the best of Marvel. One can feel the value and the impact that a simple melody can have in the cinema, and here, all his team appreciates it and gives the indicated treatment to such an emotional tool, and it happens with very few motion pictures. 

Do you want an appetizer? See the teaser trailer. Another extra? See the official trailer. But in case you are still overcome by doubts, another one? Delight yourself with the opening sequence. The pictures are sickeningly sweet like a visit to a candy shop, prevailing and vigorous like the guilty pleasure of entering the shop. The range of colors is phenomenal, and its application boosts greatly that feeling, moreover, the way to sort the components in the scene is beautiful, colorful; a harmony vis-à-vis with each character. However, they episodically fail in the well-known "more is less" proverb, even thought Ego's planet is paradisiacal, the screen is crowded of pigments and dizzying gadgets for the spectator, tarnishing the beauty of photography, from superhero world newcomer Henry Braham. It's worth highlighting the remarkable work in the editing room, that in addition to vivify scenes, produce mind-boggling IMAX and 3D screenings, that will leave you astounded. Also, it's meritorious to applaud the exact length of the film, those two hours and eighteen minutes don't feel unused at all.

And Gunn keeps on to inscribe rules for upcoming superhero movie directors. The filmmaker concludes his feature film, his work, his son, his beloved in an intimate and melancholy way, producing a breath of hope and affliction at the same time, something that, at first glance, doesn't fit into the atmosphere of the story, but that after following the crazy adventures of our guardians for two hours feels phenomenally effective. A smile and a goodbye hurt more than hundreds of blows and Gunn has shown (also) to know how to handle it. He's a peculiar director, that has pros and cons like any other man-but more pros-, the priority for music, the character design, the importance of comedy and drama, the tidiness imposed on frames and a few hazards crossing their minds. It seems Marvel will continue at the service of the demands and ideas of this talented man and his squad of characters, demonstrating in this installment more of everything, duplicating what we liked about the first one, but giving it personality to a film as fun as tear-producing simultaneously.

This movie really did not live up to its predecessor. I will concede the fact that it is a fun movie to watch. The kids will enjoy this movie and regardless it will be a fun watch. However, stylistically, tonally, and thematically this movie failed. In it's a place in the MCU this movie was inconsequential, the plot resolved itself which was not a desired outcome for the MCU with infinity war so close. There is a massive tone shift from its predecessor that leaves a bad taste in my mouth. The first guardians was a masterpiece that blended a fun atmosphere with deep sentiment. This movie attempted to replicate that, but failed by ruining every emotional moment with a crappy one-liner. Regardless the plot is all over the place and isn't clear. Most of the movie is spent developing the characters of Yondu and Ego despite both of them dying and exiting the MCU which leaves a bad taste. Meanwhile Mantis was hardly developped as a character despite her role as the next addition to Guardians and the MCU's hero list. As unfair as it is to compare a sequel to its original it'd be hard to critique this movie without looking back at the masterpiece guardians of the galaxy was and when you do that this movie failed to live up to its expectations. 
To close up with a recommendation this movie is worth watching the first time and enjoyable, but the more I chew on the movie the more I dislike it and would never sit to watch again.

Peter and Gamora's relationship is so uninteresting and it's about all either of them talk about. I can say however, Rocket Raccoon and Yondu were the only thing saving this movie from me despising it as the comedy surrounding them (for the most part) is witty, well-placed and genuinely funny and they lead to the only laughs I got out of the movie. Baby Groot was only there for the marketing as people are drawn to cute things even if they turn out to be absolutely useless. Peter and his dad couldn't keep my interests throughout the movie and it all seemed kind of ridiculous to me, in my opinion this movie could have done A LOT of things better, and the comedy could have been much better written.

James Gunn returns with the sequel to the Guardians of the Galaxy with a movie that brings back many of the things that made the original so great. Is it greater than the first though? It is hard to rank one above the other, but I still believe the first installment (in what is now going to be a trilogy) deserves the nod. Led by the continuously likable and charismatic Chris Pratt as Star-Lord, we join the Guardians on a journey across the planets and galaxies.

Vol. 2 introduces many new characters such as Mantis and Peter Quill aka Star Lord's father, Ego, the latter played by Kurt Russell. The characters of Drax and Rocket were hilarious as usual, Drax especially in many scenes. We learn more of the intense relationship between the sisters Gamora and Nebula, but there were two who really stood out for me: Baby Groot and (surprisingly) Yondu. Baby Groots time on camera created many laughs, not just for his sheer cuteness, but for his interactions with the other characters. Yondu in this movie was given far more story to deal with, and it certainly paid off. It made you really care for him on an emotional level, which does sound quite unusual given he is a ravager. And last but not least, Star-Lord, and being the lead character, deserved all the attention because he was great.

The movie was another great entry into the Marvel Cinematic Universe and has created more anticipation for Avengers: Infinity Wars where we will see the Avengers team up with the Guardians. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2 will provide more laughs, more emotion and more action for any movie viewer, led by a great director and cast.

The follow-up to one of the biggest surprises for cinema in recent years. I thought the first movie was going to be a failure. It came out during that time of year when summer movies are usually not very good, around August. It looked like it was going to be too silly when you look at it, a talking tree and a raccoon in space. How is this going to work? Well, it did work, and almost everybody really seemed to love it, myself included. The characters were so likable, the action was a ton of fun, and I really like how it took on a refreshing change in tone for the Marvel Cinematic Universe. I got surprisingly so wrapped up in the action, the comedy, and even the drama of the first movie. However, many people are treating as one of the greatest sci-fi movies ever made and also their favorite MCU movie. I don't know if I can go as far to say it's one of my absolute favorites. It didn't leave that much of an impact on me. I thought it was extremely fun, hilarious, and definitely among the better Marvel movies; but at the same time I didn't think that much about it. Regardless, I still loved the movie.

Because we all loved the first movie, everyone got excited by for its sequel and thought it was going to be twice as good. But I kept my optimism for this movie low because I didn't want to be disappointed. From what I've initially heard about it, it's said to be not as good as the first one. It wasn't a surprise to hear that. After people adoring the original, they're likely to be disappointed with how its sequel turned out. So I went in to see this movie with that mindset.

Watching the movie, I was trying to see where the people were coming from. I guess there are a few things about it that I can understand. Some of the humor did feel a bit forced. The movie felt like it did want to be twice as good as the first so they wanted to add twice the comedy. But sometimes the timing is a bit off. There were a couple of jokes that came at inappropriate moments, like when one character delivered a joke while another character was explaining her troubled past. I remembered not many people laughed at that part, that joke shouldn't have been delivered at that moment. Also, the story felt a bit choppy. There were many subplots that felt out of place when the movie goes from one scene to another. I was really getting into one scene, but then all of the sudden it jumps into another scene unrelated to what we just saw. Then it goes back to the previous scene after I was getting into that other scene. This cycle goes on throughout the movie and it gets a bit distracting. And one last thing, the character choices for the main villain are pretty clichéd. It's another one of those bad guys who want to control the entire universe. On the same subject, the side villains are absolutely useless and not the least bit intimidating. They never played a major role in the movie until one of the after-credit scenes, which I guess gives them a purpose the be in the movie.

With those reasons, I can understand why some people would be a bit disappointed with this movie since the first one didn't have those problems. The first one knew when to deliver the comedy, it had a much more flowing narrative. Although, both movies do have stereotypical bad guys. But what this movie had that the original didn't have enough of was character development. I really enjoyed the main characters in the first film, but I wasn't particularly interested in them. In this movie, we get to explore what makes these characters who they are as we get to know about their backstories and understand more of their relationships. Star-Lord is finding out something about his lineage that makes him special from the others and creates a dilemma between his friends and his father. His fatherly figure, Yondu, is realizing that he's been doing nothing right his entire life and his crew are giving him that treatment. With that, you suddenly feel sorry for one of the antagonists from the first film. The same thing with Nebula, she has had this strong rivalry with her sister Gamora that has inflicted her to do bad things. You can also feel for her character as well the relationship with Gamora since they're sisters. There's also a bond between Drax and a new character named Mantis about how their relationship grows just for who they are, I thought that was a very sweet and charming aspect to the movie. There's even a growing relationship between Yondu and Rocket Raccoon as they realize each other's similarities, both have had similar pasts and share some of the same traits. Yondu even gets along with Baby Groot, who by the way is the most adorable thing... ever! Anyway, it's this way of understanding the characters that really makes me care about them. For me, the most important aspect of any film is the characters. They are what we as human beings relate to, so if we understand the characters then we get invested in the movie. Basically, if I love and care about the characters, then I'll most likely love the movie.

Not only that, this movie is hilarious! Even though I said the timing of the comedy doesn't always hit, most of it still works really well. There are many types of humor used here, with many references and visuals, a lot of it has to do with delivery along with one heck of a great soundtrack, and some are just completely random that you can't help but laugh at it. There's this one brilliantly random joke towards the end that almost had me in tears it was so funny. I think those who've seen the movie will know what it is, it's the most quoted line in the movie. It just goes to show that Marvel clearly wanted to have some fun. Even though I said the narrative of the movie was a bit choppy, the movie has great pacing. That's one other problem I had with the first movie is that the pacing was a bit inconsistent. There were moments where I was feeling a kind of bored and wanted some scenes to wrap up. In this movie, not ONCE did I ever feel bored! And the drama in this film is so strong, especially at the end. Never would I've thought there would be so much genuine emotion in a movie like this. Without giving away too much, one of the characters dies at the end. Because I cared and learned so much about that character, the death of that character was not only very emotional and even tear-jerking, but it felt earned; and it was handled in a way that made it feel important. I was even getting a little teary-eyed, which is rare for me.

If you haven't already guessed, I love this movie... a lot! I saw this movie three times already in the theater and I still want to see it again, that's how much fun I had with it. The action was extremely satisfying, the visuals are absolutely gorgeous and really colorful, almost all of the comedy works and is very clever, and the character development is incredibly strong. Because of that, I do enjoy this movie more than the original. I just really love these characters. Sure, the movie still has its flaws, but honestly, I had so much fun with this movie that I can pretty much overlook any of its problems. If you think you'll have fun with this movie, by all means, go watch it!

Grade: A-

Guardians of the galaxy vol. 2 was another round of fun, funny, and visually stunning round of irrevent fast paced mayhem. This movie, however, focused on the characters and their back stories , which was very welcome. You could tell James Gunn knew what he was doing with the script, and knew he couldn't just make 2 hours of the first movie again. There were points, mainly the first 30 minutes, however, that felt very repetitive of the first film.

If I could give this movie an even higher rating I definitely would. I loved it! Incredibly funny and full of action. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who has enjoyed any Marvel movie ever. I would even venture to say it's better then the first. It's a must see.

This movie would've been a whopping 5 stars if it hadn't been for Starlord's insane father. He wasn't a very intriguing villain at all and didn't even have a sense of humor...and everyone knows an evil mastermind is what makes a movie great. The storyline, as seems to always be the case with sequels, was all over the place. There was a crazy assassin trying to kill her sister, Starlord's daddy drama, Quinn's issues with his gang, two new on-the-spot romances...kind of exhausting after the straightforward plot of the first movie. 
But you can never go wrong with a snarky gun-toting raccoon, and it's good to know that 80s music is still in style. And there are some funny moments.

All hail James Gunn for accomplishing the ostensibly impossible: making a 2nd installment of a surprise break-out hit almost as great as the first. I say 'almost' because, inherently, Volume 2 loses traction because you can't duplicate the surprise factor. That's what made the first one so awesome - no one was expecting it. But now, we are totally expecting it, and even so, writer/director Gunn et al have definitely succeeded in delivering a sequel that is worthy of the first. It offers the same lightness and fun that the first one had in spades, and continues developing the characters that were introduced in the first. Though there are some new characters, the film spends most of its time expanding on the ones we already know, to mostly positive effect. My biggest disappointment with this movie is that you never get to see the Guardians in action as a unit; for the most part, everybody does their own thing, and the movie is focused on developing the characters individually rather than as a group. Volume 1 was spent establishing their origin story of how they came together to become more than the sum of their parts, and this film was primed to actually show us how awesome that could be. But alas, the group is immediately split up again, chasing their individual storylines. The story gets a little bogged down in the middle, as the two central storylines are mired in "family themes" and are a little too heavy. Luckily, there are Drax and Rocket and Groot to lighten things up. Strangely, Chris Pratt's inherent charm is rarely used for comedic effect. Instead, the film opts to land most of the humor on the shoulders of Rocket and Drax, who both rise to the occasion and deliver solid laughs... and who can possibly resist Baby Groot, who may be the most adorable and lovable character ever put to film? The film also further develops the former villains Yondu and Nebula, whose character arcs are welcome additions to the plot. This movie has a well written story, solid character development, lively action, and incredible visuals, which is really all you can hope for in a summer action flick. By the opening credits, I was grinning from ear to ear. True, it's not quite as fresh or funny as the first one was, but it is definitely as fun, and that's all that matters for a movie like this.

Mi Super REVIEW a "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2"
No tiene nada de malo repetir la formula que te llevó al éxito y James Gunn (Director/Guionista) lo sabe, solo que en esta ocasión excedió los limites. Hay que ser honestos, "Guardianes de la Galaxia" fue una sorpresa para todos, quien iba a pensar que unos superheroes desconocidos por parte del público general triunfarían en la crítica y en la taquilla, incluso Gunn no se esperaba semejante éxito. Por lo que en esta segunda parte no tomó grandes riesgos y volvió a usar la misma formula (comedia y acción sin limites) pero como dije anteriormente, Gunn no supo balancear la comedia y la acción de manera excelente en esta segunda parte como en la primera.
GUARDIANES DE LA GALAXIA VOL 2 no es tan buena como la primera parte, es MUY inferior a su antecesora ¿Esto quiere decir que sea mala? No, pero ¿Por qué es inferior? Como lo mencione al inicio de esta "crítica" Gunn exagera con su formula mágica de comedia llegando ser excesivamente innecesaria en algunas ocasiones (no lo voy a negar, hay muchas partes que me hicieron "cagar" de risa)
pero por ejemplo: Drax (Dave Bautista) en los primeros minutos de la película, de vez en cuando suelta una carcajada que al inicio es muy contagiosa, una o dos e incluso tres veces su risa causa mucha gracia, pero llega un punto en que utilizan tanto la risa de Drax que al final termina siendo incómoda y hasta irritante.
En la primera película también hay chistes, pero en mi opinión nunca se sintieron forzados, la primera película es un festín de carcajadas que nunca se sienten forzadas, y acá, de vez en cuando pasa todo lo contrario.
Ahora, otro aspecto que hizo que la primera película fuera única y diferente a todas las de Marvel fue la música "AWESOME MIX". En esta ocasión tenemos el "AWESOME MIX VOL 2" que termina siendo mal utilizado. En la primera película, la música no solo se utilizaba para usarla de fondo, todo lo contrario, ayudaba a describir el estado de animo de los personajes, no se necesitaban de dialogos, solo con la música se podía entender lo que estaba ocurriendo, logrando un lenguaje cinematográfico extraordinario. En esta segunda parte hay momentos en los que la música es mas "música de fondo" que otra herramienta para complementar la historia. Hay momentos en los que la música funciona (La escena final con la canción "Father and Son" sin duda queda como anillo al dedo.) pero lamentablemente son pocas las canciones las que se aprovechan de manera correcta.
MARVEL sigue teniendo errores con sus villanos, y VOL 2 no es la excepción, la Villana pasa desapercibida por completo, tanto que nunca le tomaremos importancia.
Pesé a todos los errores mencionados, tengo que decir que disfruté la película, sus escenas de acción son espectaculares, hay varias escenas con excelente humor, pero sin duda alguna no supera a su primera parte, no es una mala película, es buena, pero aun así deja mucho que desear. El error y el que tiene la culpa es nada mas y nada menos que Gunn, quien escribió un guión sin arriesgarse a tomar nuevos caminos.

Dato curioso: James Gunn dirigirá y escribirá la tercera y ultima parte de Guardianes de la Galaxia; ¿Quién debe estar mas asustado? ¿Nosotros o él?

Another great installment and adventure in the GOTG universe. However, weaker soundtrack as well as dialogue than the first. But it's pretty rare to find a sequel that dominates over the first installation. Gotta love Baby Groot. Love how they pick up right where they left off basically. I really enjoy the constant comedic bickering between all the Guardians. I love how Drax is so dim witted and ignorant. Great opening scene haha. Why don't we have simulated fighter crafts? I really have gotten accustomed to their comedic approach with touchy moments to these films. Kurt Russel is Chris Pratt's father?! Of wait nevermind, Ego is Peter Quill's father. Yondu has been rejected by The Ravengers due to his relationship with Peter which broke the Ravenger Code(poor guy). The Ravengers have a larger role in this movie. They really approached this film to appeal to a large range of audiences. Shiz gets real crazy and weird mid-film. I like the sister fight sequence (however now I kind of feel bad for Nebula).
Side note: Funniest moment is when Peter says, "I'm gonna make some weird shit". 
Ego is a freaking maniac, WTF. Rocket actually has a bigger role in this film (maybe that is why he serves as the main character on the new GotG: Mission Breakout ride in California Adventure). Rocket also experiences a connection with Yondu. It's crazy how important the music is in these movies, there's lots of connections between the songs and the plot and also it serves as a fantastic addition to these intense and comedic movies. End fight scene gets pretty intense! I love their weapon technology.
Side note #2: I want to be Star Lord for Halloween this year
This film really hints at the power and importance of a father-son relationship (Chris Pratt even stated in an interview that the script has helped him get over the passing of his father). Yondu dies and is given a Ravenger Funeral due to his actions. A really good, heartwarming ending.

First mid credit scene is Kraglin seen practicing with Yondu's arrow, later impaling Drax with it.  

Second mid credit scene is a group of Ravengers, headed by Stakar Ogord (Sylvester Stallone) forming a team. (Possibly hinting at a Ravenger stand alone film).

Third mid credit scene is very important, it is the high priestess Ayesha marveling over her creation, Adam Warlock. (To later be revealed in the next GotG installment).

The fourth mid credit scene shows us that Baby Groot has now turned into Teenage Groot.

The end credit scene is Stan Lee hanging out with the Watchers (an advanced alien race that oversees the universe), he watches as they leave and finally says, "Wait guys, I have more stories to tell!" (Hinting at his increasing age and the fact that he has so much more to add to the Marvel Universe).

Stan Lee appears in this film sitting with the Watchers as Rocket and Yondu jump space time, rudely interrupting their conversation.

Decent film but not as good as the first. Very ominous plot well played out though predictable.  Presents an interesting take on child parent relations through Quill and Quill's father.  Main characters do a decent job, but one cannot help to sense they might have been a little stressed out while filming it.  Perhaps they shouldn't be on such strict schedules, not sure what was going on behind the scenes but there was a lack of passion when filming this film that is detectable from the two main actors Chris Pratt and Zoe Saldana who play Peter Quill and Gamaroa respectively.    

The end of the story was very well done especially the dynamic between Peter Quill and Yondo.  This interaction had a lot of heart in it and was well acted.  The Sovereign was also a great plot idea that worked well that provided alot of amusement as strict vengeful puritans with a lust for getting people back. 

Overall it was a good movie, but I wish they had made the plot a little more emotionally mature.  Too many of the blockbusters in this day an age are aimed for the high school early college market of young adults that plays seemingly more to the males than the females.  This is one movie the exemplifies this trend which is the reason I am giving it 3.5 stars instead of 4.  I'm actually quite sick of the lack of real deep emotional material in films.  Surely it is possible to create something akin to Game of Thrones in space at some point right?  If you borrow this idea just remember to give me the credit! Far better than it's already good predecessor, Guardians of the Galaxy volume 2 succeeds in almost every way. Characters that felt cartoonish previously are fully fleshed out, the action scenes utterly surpass those of the first film. When it made jokes, they were just as funny, although the film is more serious in tone than the first. The most striking things about the film were the beauty and the heart. This film is a visual masterpiece, from the cinematography to the color palette to the designs to the CGI. It cannot be understated how much an achievement was made in that regard. The heart of the film is considerable, this movie is very much a character movie and the final emotional notes of the film are very resonant. Kurt Russel embodies his character masterfully. The only gripe I have with the film is that the third act heavily bent some of the rules set up earlier in the film. If not for that it would be a perfect five stars.

Guardians of the Galaxy #Vol2 Non-Spoiler Review:

Let's be honest: you can't repeat a big surprise. With Vol 1 being a massive surprise hit for Marvel Studios and the Guardians reputation to withhold, Vol 2 had every reason against it, to fail. I am happy to report as a big Marvel Cinematic Universe fan, Marvel have nailed it again. 

In a nutshell it's spectacularly fun. I literally smiled and laughed out loud from start to finish. The sequel returns with true comedy that makes it funnier than it's predecessor, and it's not repeated comedy skits that we watched before, it's fresh comedy which is a credit to the script writers. 

When it takes a step away from the comedy, you start to realise they haven't sat back on the sequel. It  takes some guts to pause all action and concentrate on no less than three slow character building scenes in the middle of the film. It turns out that's working great for the characters and is one of the main reasons why the final act works fantastically. 

Now, onto my favourite part of Guardian's of the Galaxy - the soundtrack. In real life, Peterâ??s Awesome Mix Vol 1 became a best-selling soundtrack, becoming the first soundtrack album in history consisting entirely of previously released songs to top the chart. Vol 2 does not disappoint with new added songs from artists such as Electric Light Orchestra, Fleetwood Mac, George Harrison and many more. I've been listening to the soundtrack all morning, and like the Vol 1, I can't get enough of it. 

In conclusion, Vol 2 was just as great, just as funny, just as epic than the first one.  I won't lie, I saw flaws, the plot being the biggest flaw. However; James Gunn has done more than enough to have this film standing tall alongside it's predecessor and all of its brothers and sisters in the universe. You Marvel nerds out there, like me, will love it.

Nice emotional development in both Star Lord and Gamora.  Star Lord is every child who has a missing parent who comes back.  He idolizes his new-found dad, overlooks his obvious issues, and finally is faced with deciding who is his "real" family.  Gamora and her sister struggle to make and adult relationship out of the mess of their childhood abuse that pitted them against each other.  In the end there is a sense of forgiveness and reconciliation.  I loved this movie for these important themes.  Having children through adoption, they have faced these issues and it is so good to see them played out onscreen.  I would encourage parents who have kiddos who have faced abuse or have a missing parent to make sure their kid is ready to see this kind of storyline.  Talk with them about how it felt to see Star Lord meet his dad and have to turn away from his dad.  Talk about the hurt the abuse Gamora and her sister experienced and how it wasn't their fault.  This movie is a good tool for kids who are ready for it -- just be prepared for discussion after wards.

Guardians of the Galaxy 2 doesn't quite reach the heights of the original but it's still a great laugh and one or Marvel's best films.

As with the first film, Drax steals the show with some of the funniest lines and moments, many at the expense of newcomer Mantis. Baby Groot also has some of the best moments including the opening credits.

The villains is also a marked improvement on Ronan from the first film. Whereas Ronan felt more like a plot device than a real villain, Ego is important to the films story making for a much better developed and more interesting character.

The story isn't quite as strong as the first films though with some parts feeling like they are a bit padded out. And despite the film largely being hilarious, there is the odd joke that feels a bit forced and at times, out of place. None of this stops GOTG 2 being a highly entertaining film that is well worth watching again and again.

A MI PARECER ESTA PELICULA ES OTRO ACIERTO DE MARVEL Y JAMES GUNN, YA QUE A PESAR DE NO SUPERAR A LA PRIMERA ENTREGA LOGRA PLASMAR VARIOS MOMENTOS ESPECTACULARES Y BIEN LLEVADOS. 
EL RITMO DE LA PELICULA PODRÍA DIVIDIRSE EN 2 YA QUE LA PRIMERA PARTE ES UN POCO LENTA Y NO SABES MUY BIEN A DONDE VA LA TRAMA PERO LA SEGUNDA PARTE RECUPERA TODO Y SUBE DE UNA MANERA BRILLANTE HASTA UN FINAL ÉPICO.
CONSIDERO QUE A LO LARGO DE TODA LA PELICULA HAY BASTANTE HUMOR DEL BUENO CON REFERENCIAS OCHENTERAS PERO TAMBIEN SENTÍ QUE HUBIERON MOMENTOS SERIOS EN LOS QUE NO DEBIERON ABUSAR DE ELLO. SI BIEN ES CIERTO, ESTO ES LO QUE CARACTERIZA A LOS GUARDIANES DE LA GALAXIA Y FUE EL GRAN ACIERTO DE LA PRIMERA, PERO EN ESTA SECUELA CREO QUE EXAGERARON UN POCO.
LOS EFECTOS ESPECIALES FUERON ALUCINANTES AUNQUE NO TANTO COMO EN DOCTOR STRANGE, PERO SIN DUDA LOS ESCENARIOS COMO EL PLANETA EGO, EL ESPACIO, LAS NAVES, LOS TRAJES Y EL CGI EN GENERAL HACEN QUE GUARDIANES DE LA GALAXIA 2 SEA UNA EXPERIENCIA INCREIBLE Y QUE NO CREAS QUE CASI TODO ES PANTALLA AZUL.
POR EL LADO MUSICAL ME GUSTARON LAS CANCIONES DEL AWESOME MIX VOL. 2 SOBRETODO LA DE FATHER AND SON, TENGO QUE ADMITIR QUE EL GIRO DE LA TRAMA NO ME LO ESPERABA, ME FASCINO QUE EGO FUERA EL VILLANO Y SIN DUDA LA INTERPRETACIÓN DE KURT RUSSEL LE DA UN GRAN PESO A LA PELICULA POR LO QUE EL CONFLICTO PRINCIPAL GIRA EN TORNO A LA RELACION DE PADRE E HIJO AUNQUE AL FINAL EN EL CLIMAX TODOS LOS CONFLICTOS SE RESUELVEN COMO LA RIVALIDAD DE HERMANAS ENTRE GAMORA Y NEBULA, EL COMPAÑERISMO ENTRE ROCKET Y YONDU. 
DE BABY GROOT SOLO TENGO QUE DECIR UNA FRASE DEL FILM, ES DEMASIADO ADORABLE PARA MATARLO.
LOS MOMENTOS FINALES FUERON EXCELENTEMENTE LLEVADOS Y HASTA TE ME SALIERON UNAS CUANTAS LAGRIMAS?, EL FUNERAL DE YONDU ME PARECIÓ UNO DE LOS MEJORES QUE PODIDO HACER MARVEL Y LOGRA LLEGAR AL ESPECTADOR CON MUCHO FEELING. 
EN TERMINOS GENERALES GUARDIANES DE LA GALAXIA VOL. 2 ES UNA BUENA SECUELA Y NO ES MAS DE LO MISMO NADA MAS, YA QUE TIENE GRANDES MOMENTOS A PESAR DE NO AFECTAR CASI EN NADA AL UNIVERSO CINEMATOGRAFICO DE MARVEL Y FUNCIONAR DE UNA MANERA INDEPENDIENTE SALVO POR UNA ESCENA POSTCREDITO QUE CONFIRMA LA APARICION DE ADAM WARLOCK PARA INFINITY WAR O QUIZAS PARA LA TERCERA PARTE DE LOS GUARDIANES, PERO EN GENERAL ESTE FILM ES MUY ENTRETENIDO CON EFECTOS ESPECIALES GENIALES Y SOBRETODO CON EL CARISMA DE TODOS LOS PERSONAJES UNA PELICULA DIVERTIDA CON EXCELENTES CANCIONES Y UN BUEN MENSAJE SOBRE LA FAMILIA.

I'm going to say something somewhat controversial: I think that Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 is better than the original Guardians of the Galaxy. Okay, I take it back: that is very controversial. The 2014 smash-hit is lauded as one of the greatest superhero movies of all time, one of the greatest sci-fi movies of all time, and one of the greatest altogether fun movies of all time. I mean, who have you ever talked to who hasn't loved the original Guardians of the Galaxy? Me, if I've ever talked to you about it. 
	It's not that I disliked the first film. That would border on blasphemy. It's just that everyone saw it as something fresh, something new, but as for me, it was really just a retread of Star Wars, albeit with more fun and humor. I would give it a solid three stars. I must say, though, this film caught me by surprise. Sequels, as everybody knows, are generally not as good as their predecessors. Of course, there are notable exceptions to this; The Dark Knight, the Empire Strikes Back, Terminator 2, Mad Max: Road Warrior, to name a few. But, as the general consensus goes, this was definitely not considered to be better than the original. In fact, one of the main points of criticism for this film (though it got good reviews) was that its inferiority to the original. Sorry, but I disagree. 
	Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 reunites the cast from the first; Chris Pratt as Peter Quill, Zoe Saldana as Gamora, Dave Bautista as Drax, Bradley Cooper as Rocket, and Vin Diesel as, this time, Baby Groot. James Gunn returns to direct, and the film centers on Quill meeting his father (Kurt Russell) and discovering who he is. Here, characters are more in the spotlight than the frantic action of the first film. We still get beautiful, incredibly colorful visuals and a few action sequences, but what's really focused on is the nonlinear plot and complex characters. 
	By the end of the film, we are taken to emotional heights that I genuinely did not expect. It's not that it's more emotional than I ever expected it to be per se; what surprised me was the way in which the film achieved these emotions, with a twist that I never saw coming and that was more satisfyingly emotional than anything I've seen in any movie in recent memory. When the history books are written for 2017 in film (as if they have those), Logan will obviously be the superhero movie most lauded and remembered, but I think this is definitely a superior film. In Logan, the emotions that we feel at the end were inevitable; we saw what was going to happen coming a mile away, and felt more like a cliché from a film like Despicable Me than anything genuinely emotional. Here, you really don't see coming how the film deals with the characters in a poignant and touching way, which makes it all the more special. 
	The things that I enjoyed from the first Guardians are certainly here; action, visuals, music, humor, and great characters, except characters are given more focus than the action, and the touching ending makes the first movie's "emotional ending" feel shallow and insignificant by comparison. I can see why people don't like this as much as the first; it's not as fun and the action is more far and few between, but to be honest, I enjoyed the breaks from action to get more in touch with the characters. The film doesn't take these positive attributes far enough to be considered great; Gunn has action, humor, and characters nailed, but emotional sequences still need some work. He gets it very well in this film though; so hopefully by the third installment he'll be able to deliver one of the greatest superhero movies ever made. Based on this impressive second installment, I think it's well within his grasp.

Incredible follow-up, this inter-galactic sequel takes a step back from the massive world building to bring a personal story that arguably lacks in scope but exceeds in character development and building on the original's promise as well as potential for future installments. Clever humor, fun action sequences, and a fantastic story all make for a stunning comic book film. The film would be near perfect without the aggravatingly annoying villain known as the sovereign who offer practically nothing to the film and would have done better to keep as far away from the story as possible.
By ditching an empty plot in favor of a more personal story, the film creates deeper characters, but makes them feel like less of a team than the first one.

Set to "Awesome Mixtape #2", Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. #2  is more thrilling and hilarious than its predecessor. It is an action packed, sci-fi adventure about a group of intergalactic criminals who are tasked to work together to save the universe. Chris Pratt again stars as Peter Quill, aka Star Lord. The rest of the cast follows suit - Zoe Saldana as Gamora, Dave Bautista as Drax, Vin Diesel as the voice of Groot and Bradley Cooper as the voice of Rocket. 

The film starts out with the classic 70s song "Brandi" by Looking Glass as we see two young people driving down the highway, very much in love. We later learn that this is the back story of Peter's conception and is foreshadowing the main storyline of the film. The movie jumps 34 years and Peter is now Star Lord, captain of a band of reformed outlaws. The group is hired to guard the uber batteries of the Sovereign planet. Upon leaving, Rocket steals some of the batteries and a space battle ensues. Star Lord and his crew are shot down and make an emergency landing on a nearby planet. Before landing,  they notice a mysterious spaceship, which takes out the entire Sovereign fleet pursuing them. The rest of the film is an emotional, action-packed adventure, having to do with this mysterious personage. There are lots of battles between different factions in this crazy sci-fi, fantasy universe.  

The movie has lots of lively and entertaining scenes. My favorite is when Rocket Raccoon uses traps to his advantage to defeat an incoming horde of ravagers. Every scene with Drax is terrific because he has a different philosophy of life and has the most infectious laugh of any character in any movie, ever. I also love how Peter is obsessed with 80s pop culture.  He references them all the time, but his companions never understand them, because they didn't grow up on Earth. I especially love how 80s music is used to evoke nostalgia from Peter's childhood, making for a terrific oldies soundtrack.

Overall, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is phenomenal and full of whimsical jokes that don't get old. It is a perfect family adventure that is suitable for ages 10 to 18. Parents and grandparents will even get a kick out of it. I rate this film 4 out of 5 stars for its engaging humor and captivating action. 
Reviewed by Clayton P., KIDS FIRST! Film Critic. For more reviews by youth, visit kidsfirst dot org.

Marvel is a machine when it comes to it's films. I don't think i've seen a Marvel film that I hated with a passion. They really know how to make a good comic book film, This one is no exception. This film was fantastic. This film was a fun film with heart. The characters we came to love in the previous film are lovable in this film also. Chris Pratt, Dave Bautista, Zoe Saldana, Vin Diesel, Bradley Cooper, and Michael Rooker gave more of a story to the characters we love already. They also gave them more heart. Kurt Russell did excellent portraying Ego the Living Planet. He was portrayed really well compared to the comics. The soundtrack was stellar as the last one. Slightly less star filled, but still an excellent soundtrack. This film felt well paced, a little better than the first film. The action was all through the film, a little more than the first. The laughs were spread out also. The writing of the script was well done, they really felt like a bickering family. The special effects were cool. A lot of neat shots. This film also had some sad moments, leading to some possible tears from the audience. Overall, this film is on par with Marvel's best films. A little better than the first even though the first is excellent. Definitely check this film out.

Beautiful visuals, great actions sequences and funny bits make this one of the most enjoyable Marvel movies, but I wouldn't say that it's one of the best. It fails to live up to its expectations and the plot feels VERY disconnected from the rest of the Marvel Universe, something that at this stage is really not good. It also has probably the highest stakes than any Marvel movie before, but it doesn't feel like it and, between joke and joke, you can't really take this threat seriously. But the humor in this movie is better than in most of the other Marvel movies, even if it's still kind of obvious, silly and not smart at all. The performances from the Guardians are the best of the movie and definitely what makes this adventure so enjoyable. And it has one of the best opening sequences of any superhero movie ever. But, although it doesn't live up to the freshness of the original, it is a highly entertaining movie and another great entry to the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

The long awaited sequel to the break out hit, Guardians of The Galaxy, is here! In 2014, the Marvel Studios original came out of obscurity to set box office records, introducing fans to a cast of heroes who aren't exactly your typical superheroes. Combining amazing special effects and comedy, the film quickly gained a cult following and critical acclaim, but can they defeat the biggest enemy of all, the curse of the sequel? The Guardians are back doing what they do best, with a new enemy on their tail, when they crash land on an uninhabited planet. Their rescuer comes in a form of a man who seems too good to be true, is he really there to help them or does he have something else in mind? The story in volume two is not as good as the first one, that was to be expected, but luckily it isn't far off. The characters are the same and this time they know each other a whole lot better, meaning the chemistry is better, the humor comes more quickly, and the magic is still there. Once again Chris Pratt is outstanding, it's still hard to believe he went from the annoying jock on Everwood to this charismatic megastar. The rest of the cast is also on it's game and we learn much more about the characters then we did in the first film. While not being as strong story wise, this film certainly hits closer to home, and everything is amped up from the special effects to the humor and even the soundtrack. I love these films and I hope there are a lot more of them, however I'd be remiss in not sharing my thought that something this good, especially with how the story evolves in the second film, is better suited for a weekly TV series than at most a handful of feature films. The Bottom Line, if you liked the first one, you'll love the second one.

A great MCU film and is a great sequel to the original hit. This film can somehow capture the magic of its predecessor and build on it in many ways, but the film does struggle to get its feet off the ground throughout the first act and takes until the start of the second until you start to see which direction they are going with it. The performances are all great and somehow your love for these misfits grows stronger. Especially for the character Yondu. His character impressed me and I couldn't have imaged a better way they could have developed his character from in the first film. One of the most important features in the first film is it's incredible soundtrack and this film builds on it and James Gunn chose tracks that flowed with the scenes and added a lot of depth to them. Overall I had a fantastic viewing experience and am extremely excited to see what they do next to this beloved franchise.

It was always going to be a tough ask to repeat the success of Guardians of the Galaxy. So much of it relied upon the surprise factor; the unknown characters, the quirkiness and quite frankly the utter absurdity of a walking tree and talking racoon. Thankfully the sequel retains the banter, the repartee and a host of great one liners. The underlining story however is weak and pretty predictable. Sure it serves a purpose in filling in some Starlord backstory but it can't quite match  the same retro-satisfaction of the original. Instead the surprise here is that Gunn produces a Marvel film with a heart as big as the heroes' biceps. Significant time is spent on the emotional journey of all the central characters, with numerous moments of pathos and reconciliation. The directorial generosity Gunn shows in allowing his ensemble to all had sufficient screen time to have a genuine emotional revelation is unheard of in this genre. So whilst GOTG2 doesn't hit all the same notes as the first film, it hits enough new ones with sufficient originality to make it worth the ride.

Let's just say Volume 1 was awesome and possibly the best of all the Marvel movies, while Volume 2 is unnecessary. I'm sure they will make a Volume 3 so let us hope they can piece together a more dynamic and creative storyline.

This movie was a disappointment. From the banter that felt forced and was rarely funny to the meandering plot that was nothing more than vacationing with daddy until 3/4 through the film, Guardians of the Galaxy vol. 2 tries way too hard to ride the waves of the first movie. You can see this from the dance opening only with Groot this time, or the halfhearted attempt to develop a relationship between Starlord and Gomorra wherein at one point they literally break the 4th wall to joke about how bad the ratings would be if they discussed said mutual feelings. Not worth the money. I'm shocked at the high reviews it's received, when the only redeeming quality was it's very good special effects. You can't call a book good no matter the how pretty the cover or whether the previous novel was amazing: let Vol. 2 stand on its own two feet and you'll see it crumbles quickly into a cascade of bright colors, bland humor, and not much else.

It's not that I didn't like the movie. It's that the hype wasn't worth it. A lot of the back stories were forced into the plot and dramatic moments felt artificial. The intensity of the movie was triggered in such a whiplash way that it didn't have a good effect. There were a few plot holes as well that continue to disappoint the more I think about it. The movie lost much of the comedic elements from the first movie, but I won't say it wasn't funny. There were plenty of hilarious moments, the best one being "I'm Mary Poppins, y'all!". And I, for one, love end credits scenes, but there being five seemed like an overkill. Finally, the Stan Lee cameos being explained was just a fan service and an unfortunate wedge in the real meat of the story. All in all, it wasn't a bad movie, but it was disappointing nonetheless. It certainly doesn't earn itself a five star or a full four.

I feel like the seemingly meandering story is a brilliant surprise and juxtaposition against a challenge that is more than an elephant in the room, but literally a whole planet. There's no clear plot or action device motivating our characters, until we realize by the end that amongst the familial bickering, there's a difference between the forest and the trees.

Guardiões da Galáxia Vol.2 chega despretensiosamente à fase três do MCU. A preocupação de James Gunn na sequência é apenas desenvolver seus personagens, sem conexões grandiosas com os eventos que levarão à Guerra Infinita. O objetivo é conhecer melhor a família formada no primeiro longa enquanto brinca com novas possibilidades dentro do Universo Cósmico. Tudo permeado pelo senso de humor peculiar do diretor/roteirista. Uma assinatura que mistura cor, Trash, sentimentalismo e besteirol frenético.

There were solid moments ruined by a misplaced joke or going straight-up cheesy (i.e. energy ball toss).

It wasn't without its pluses (performance, action, and holy crap this movie's beautiful), but there were just too many issues with the script to overlook it as a whole (not sure why they decided to make Drax a complete buffoon... he's overly literal and over-zealous, not a dumbass). While I don't hate it, it won't be getting the repeat viewings the first one earned.

James Gunn's Guardians of the Galaxy 2 is a strong sequel in the franchise and did not rehash too many elements from the 1st sequel.  In some ways, Guardians of the Galaxy 2 had some aspects that were better than the 1st film. There were given more character development to Yondu, Gamora, Star-Lord, Nebula, and Rocket-Raccoon. Rooker's performance as Yondu was easily the best part of the film. He gave a surprising terrific performance in this film. Kurt Russell's performance as Ego was very intriguing and the story arcs in this film were really handled well. That being said, this film definitely had its flaws. The pacing during the first act was very cluttered and choppy at times. It did not blend smoothly like the 1st movie did. I thought the Sovereign in this movie were just plain out annoying. They were extremely weak villains and they really had no purpose being in this film. Elizabeth Debicki's performance as Ayesha was very disappointing. She was very bland and generic. To be fair, she was not given much to work with. Dave Bautista's Drax had some of the best comedic lines, but unfortunately he did not get any character development added to him at all besides one very brief scene. His character was a very formulaic laugh and one-liner guy. Despite some of my flaws I had with this film, I still thought Guardians of the Galaxy 2 was an extremely fun popcorn movie with beautiful visual effects, great comedy, good acting, intriguing characters, and good overall themes.
It was very good. I laughed for a half of film, but it wasn't only a comedy. It was very interesting film with some drama and humor (classical  MARVEL humor). I was excited after this film! 5 from 5!

Movie start off in 1980 with a young Kurt Russell romancing Chris Pratt mother and grow a plant on Earth. Then forward 34 years later, the Guardians are fighting an alien beast that want to eat batteries belonging to the Sovereign. Baby Groot is very cute. Elizabeth Debicki is please with their effort and hand over Karen Gillan to them. She vow to kill Zoe Saldana. Rocket stole the batteries and Dave Bautista just laugh about it. The whole fleet chase after them and they crash landed on a planet. But before that a mystery guy wipe out the entire fleet easily to save them. Turn out to be Kurt Russell (Ego) and assistant Pom Klementieff (Mantis) which Kurt is a planet celestial and father of Chris. He ask them to visit his planet while Rocket stay put to fix the ship and take care of Karen. Elizabeth hire Michael Rooker to hunt down Chris and gang. Sylvester Stallone is an ex-comrade who exile Michael for his breech of code during their times in arms. Pom has something to tell Dave but Zoe interrupted. Rocket manage to defend and kill the hunters until Michael show up with his deadly arrow. Karen persuade Groot to free her to save Rocket but she show Michael weapon control device on the head. A comrade call Taserhead become their leader and kill all the men who follow Michael by throwing them into space. Michael need Groot help to take back his prototype device to control the arrow and Groot keep taking the wrong stuffs. One of his loyal man help them escape. Michael and Rocket kill them all. Taserhead give their coordinates to Elizabeth before his death. Kurt reveal to Chris how he is so powerful but lonely is gonna build whole new galaxy after he is disappointed with all life form he found. He created many off springs from different planet beings but none have same power as him except Chris. To complete his project he need another celestial being and Chris is the perfect choice. Karen try to kill Zoe in the gunship but end up crash and hurt. Zoe save her and she still want to fight. She is angry Zoe always win her in fight and whenever she lose, Thanos will replace a part of her with robotic part. All Karen want was a sister. They patch and make up and found a hill made of bones. Pom tell Dave the truth. Rocket and Michael are also bound for Ego. Kurt say he is force to plant a cancer tumor in the mother and Chris is angry. Kurt do it the hard way and is actullay making use of him as power source for his project. The rest of his off springs who is powerless are killed. All of them crash the party and fight. With the Sovereign fleet attacking them as well. Rocket use the batteries as bomb to kill the central system of Kurt but Groot is small enough to fit in. He couldn't get clear which button to press after Rocket teach him many times. As they are all fighting, Karen plug in the power to her cyber arms to arm the lasers and wipe out the entire fleet. Kurt awaken after Pom fail to make him sleep. All are bound for defeat and Chris start to know to use the power from heart and not mind. Groot manage to arm the bomb correctly. Michael stay put to save Chris to make himself do the right thing after so many years of misdeeds. The bomb explode and kill Kurt. Michael save Chris to outer space and himself dead. Rocket is sad to lose a friend. Sylvester and the rest give Michael a heroic funeral sending off after knowing what he has done. Michael has been sending children (off springs) to Kurt but after found out the reason, he stop at Chris. Karen left to find Thanos although Zoe try to make her stay. During the stinger, Elizabeth seem to have created a new weapon..

A surprising and refreshing addition to the Marvel Universe. 

Set to the all-new sonic backdrop of Awesome Mixtape #2, Marvel Studios' "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" continues the team's adventures as they traverse the outer reaches of the cosmos. The Guardians must fight to keep their newfound family together as they unravel the mystery of Peter Quill's true parentage. Old foes become new allies and fan-favorite characters from the classic comics will come to our heroes' aid as the Marvel Cinematic Universe continues to expand.

As of late, I've been real tired of the superhero genre. Marvel's recent films such as "Ant Man", "Captain America: Civil War", and "Doctor Strange", have all been less than adequate in my eyes. But since "Guardians of the Galaxy" is my favorite Marvel movie, I had some hope that its sequel would re-ignite my interest in superhero movies. Although it may not have done it to that extent, I still thoroughly enjoyed this sequel. 

 One thing that I loved about this film was the fact that it was Marvel's first film on RED's 8k Weapon Camera, going digital in the process. As a result, this is easily the best looking Marvel movie, while also being the most colorful. If there's another flaw that all Marvel movies share, it's that they're all pretty ugly. None of them use beautiful aesthetics or color pallets due to their desire for a more realistic look, but this film breaks that mold and gives us a fantastic looking movie.

The chemistry between the cast is still one of the highlights of the series. I love the interactions between everybody and this is one of Marvel's gut busting films. I remember laughing a lot throughout this film, as its combination of comedy and story will keep you engaged throughout.

The overall screenplay was pretty fun for the most part and even emotional at times, even if the finale was an over glorified CGI throw-down that didn't carry that much meaning.  I really felt like they gave a lot of character development to the characters we already know and love, which is really important when making sequels. I'm happy with the direction that James Gunn took this film in and I'm glad I was able to watch it.

In the end, I want to keep this short and sweet, I can finally say I like a superhero film for the first time in years, which is a huge accomplishment in my mind. "Guardians of the Galaxy 2" is a fun time and an engaging film that I think many should see.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 may not be as thrilling or original as the previous film, but it does offer us bigger laughs and the same familiar faces that many of us have come to love and connect with as much as any other marvel icon.

The plot may have been a little thin and the emotional moments a little forced, but I laughed my ass off.  Easily my favourite film of 2017 so far (Jan-May).  :D

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is the follow-up to the smash hit of 2014 and most fans of the movie have been waiting almost 3 years for the next installment of the rag-tag team of misfits fighting space adventures. While the first movie was almost an homage to Star Wars, this movie tries to establish it's own identity by showing in more depth the makings of each team member and what makes them a family.  While the film gives fans a visually delightful space quest the majority of the story is broken up into teams (coupling) where you learn a little bit about everyone in sections but then ultimately rejoin to beat the bad guy at the end.

Positives
The film is certainly the visuals and depth of characters. The visuals are always very well done and Marvel takes no breaks on making sure their movies are visually stunning. The characters are fairly defined, you learn a little bit more of why Gamora (Zoe Saldana) and Nebula (Karen Gillian) are so hateful towards one another, why Drax (Dave Butista) feels soo close to his new friends, and the meat of the story... who Starlord's father is. Those moments when you learn a little bit more about the characters are very well done but the execution is lacking in putting together a proper storyline.

Negatives
Sadly the pacing of the film and how the story of each character is revealed. There is a lot of stops and go, jumping from one storyline to another sacrificing pacing and smooth transitions into another characters moments. While you have a touching moment with Starlord (Chris Prat) with his father Ego (Kurt Russell) the movie will then jump away to another characters mission on a completely different planet. While it is understandable when you consider that James Gunn had to balance not only the main core of the Guardians but also have them interact with new characters and try to flesh them out and make them memorable for the audience to have an emotion bond with them. Had the movie decided to focus more on fewer than more, it could be said that the story would flow better (considering there will be a Guardians of the Galaxy 3 and 4 coming so why not spread out the stories a bit?) 

Another negative of the film but most likely a choice handed down from Marvel is the overuse of jokes and comedic timing. While it is sometimes nice to recall a joke from a previous film, the film decides to throw about 10 jokes a scene at the audience hoping that majority will leave the audience laughing but rather leaves the audience a bit tired and bored. There are many examples of scenes that go a bit too long and struggled to get to the point because the act of "fan servicing" to fans of the original movie's humor, it will make a scene that could have been 5 minutes into 8 minutes because 3 minutes are just recalling and rehashing the same joke or pushing the same joke to a tiring point.

Overall
Although the film did have pacing issues, very harsh story transitions and painful overuse of humor, the film does stand on its own and is a good, not great, installment for the Guardians franchise. The film is enjoyable at more points than not but in the overall sense of entertainment, you probably won't stop and watch this film when it comes out on cable but die-hard fans of Marvel Studio films will be sure to love this to the very last scene.

Vol.1 was such a great movie, it left? the bar way to high; and vol.2 tries to get there, it can't, but that doesn't mean this movie is bad, 'cause it's not, not at all; while the first half of the movie was a little heavy, towards the middle it runs smoothly, the character relationship seems natural, and the final act, the movie climax, is visually stunning, the quality of the script and the actors interpretations were all good enough to show how dramatic the situation was, actually, that makes me think, did James Gunn or the producers were watching anime lately? Not only the camera direction but the dialogues as well (also, did someone noticed the "Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagan" quote? When Drax says 'you don't need to believe in yourself, because I believe in you' out something like that).
In conclusion, is a good movie, but not as great as the first one; let's see how the volume 3 turns out.
