More fun than a rocket filled with raccoons.  So everybody's favorite band of misfits is back.  When Star-Lord (Chris Pratt) crosses paths with a man claiming to be his father (Kurt Russell), he's got some soul searching to do so he can reconnect with his roots.  Now the first Guardians was such an unexpected hit, everybody wanted to see where Marvel would take the story next.  I sometimes flip on which film is my number one, but the original Guardians has always been in my top two favorite films in the Marvel universe since its release, so it is easy to see why this was most people's most anticipated movie of the summer.  When considering the entire lineup for the hot months, I will throw myself into that camp as well (although I will say it is super close with those apes that are coming in July).  After watching this, I will still give a slight edge to the first one as far as playing favorites go, but this is still a raucous good time in its own right.  Now I know this is a group effort to be sure, but I really do feel like a lion's share of credit has to go to writer/director James Gunn.  He has such an off sense of humor that he is the perfect brain behind the franchise, and really, to have a mayhem-crazed raccoon and a talking tree that can only say "I am Groot", you have no choice to get somebody who has a different view on comedy.  This series is one of the rare ones that does not have a noticeable drop in quality like the other direct Marvel sequels.  The track record is still pretty good, but with Iron Man 2, The Dark World and the Age of Ultron, they are mostly passable at best.  In fact, until this movie, The Winter Soldier was the only exception to the rule.  This is a series that just has a ton going for it, and that is largely due to its terrific sense of humor.  Not even dwelling upon it, I can recall three scenes off the top of my head of well executed comedy that had me rolling in my seat because they know how to setup a joke, and given the fact that we are already well aware of these characters, all it does is enhance with sharp writing that bolsters the punch line just right.  As per expected, the soundtrack to this is standout, and as soon as I heard E.L.O.'s Mr. Blue Sky highlight the film's opening credits, I knew I had a movie that was after my heart.  From a story standpoint, it takes these characters to the next logical point for developing them.  Even though the stakes are technically even bigger, it still feels light, and I still don't know if that is a critique or a compliment.  It's well over two hours and you never feel the length, and you will be hard pressed to find a popcorn movie more crowd pleasing than this one.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 proves to be an action-packed adventure, featuring popular actors such as Chris Pratt and Zoe Saldana. Another superhero-comedy movie, based
on a Marvel Comics property done right, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 fills in the mysteries left from its predecessor. Though this sequel does not capture the same aestehtic
feel as the original, it does still mix the galactic misfits well with the newfound faces, such as Kurt Russell's character, Ego. The comedy in this film is just as prominent as it was
in the first, however there is more adult humour involved. As per the norm of all Marvel Studios' movies, the action is the film is great, however the reason I rank this film lower than
its original, is because, after the first hour, or so, the story seems to slow down and stop, boring until the action picks up again. Overall, this movie covers all the aspects of an
action-comedy movie well, proving to be a fun adventure for the family.

There was a lot more emphasis on story and deep character development in this one; for example, Drax was actually given a proper backstory in this while at the same time remaining true to how he was established coming into this movie. And yet despite the increased emphasis on the more emotional aspects of the characters, it managed to maintain the charm that makes the GOTG the most hilarious heroes in the MCU. Some of the original charm of the original wore off, but still I felt like I understood more about the characters and thus connected more to the movie. Everyone take notes: GOTG Vol. 2 is a prime example of serious, in-depth storytelling whilst perfectly blending with a sharp comedic edge.

Marvel's group of ragtag bounty hunters are back for one of the most fun movies they have ever put out. The story is a bit convoluted at times but at it's heart is a a deeply funny as well as intensely emotional film that will be sure to entertain as well as make you think about your life. Not only that but this film builds on the world established in the first film and adds on to the characters that we already love by introducing new ones. There are some new characters in this film that hold up progress and don't really fit, but the inclusion of a show stealing Kurt Russell, some surprising cameos, top notch action, and a truly awesome soundtrack make this movie a blast from start to finish. James Gunn and Marvel really made something to be proud of here and give you more reasons to sit through the credits and to look forward to the next MCU entry.

The first Guardians of the Galaxy was such a fun movie, and this one is no exception. However, similarly to what Empire Strikes Back did to A New Hope, the movie doesn't just live up to the previous movie, it exceeds it. The movie takes what were fun characters in the first film and expands on all of them, giving each and every one, mainly Rocket, Gamora and Quill. I was concerned during trailers and marketing that Baby Groot would be overdone and unfunny, but they actually handled him pretty well (for the most part). We, luckily, don't have another minions case on our hands. I especially like the visual flair of this movie. After all, I've always been a sucker for that cyber-space-punk style or whatever it's called. Guardians of the Galaxy does it well, except from time to time I see an overuse of CGI. One scene especially was the fight scene at the very start of the movie with the giant rathgar (it's a rathgar). I guess my final complaint would be that sometimes its tone is a bit... off? Sometimes the film gets a bit too cartoonish, to a point where I could only see kids really laughing. Two scenes in the movie stick out to a degree where characters obey cartoon physics instead of those of their actual world, which really broke my immersion. Despite these small issues, the movie is fantastic. A greater summer movie, a great Marvel movie, and most importantly, a great sequel. I hope that this practice of making expansive sequels continues in current films.

This movie was so good, just like the first. Okay maybe it was not entirely as good as the first one but nonetheless it holds up to its expectations and even surpassing them at times.

There's just so many great things about this film: the action, the characters (except for Ego, frick Ego), the music, the visuals, the interactions between everyone, the humor, just about everything. Okay yes the main plot may have been a bit too standard for me I did not care, The Guardians of The Galaxy had once again sucked me into their world and into their very very dysfunctional sort of a family as a fan and as a child, allowing my action loving self to fully immerse myself into the movie.

So what were my favorite parts about the movie? Well okay there were a lot of things great about the movie but my favorite part about the movie as a whole would probably be the interactions between the characters and how their relationships with each other were slowly built and/or further explored and deepened (whether it was happening on or off-screen) but nonetheless still fresh and very real. My favorites of these being Quill and Yondu's relationship and the relationship between Rocket and Groot. Another prominent strength of the film I noticed was indeed the humor, it was everywhere, from scene where Quill is asking everyone for tape in the middle of the climax to nearly all of Baby Groot's lines and actions, it was everywhere and while some jokes weren't too strong the humor was overall pretty funny and helped me stay engaged.

But despite the many strengths there were a few weaknesses like those stupid gold people, they were boring as frick and didn't really add to anything until one of the mid-credits scenes (oh yeah there's FIVE total mid and post-credits scenes in the movie). Also I do wish that one or two of the weaker jokes had been taken out but nonetheless I still loved this film.

In short I would highly recommend this film to anyone, regardless on whether you're into superheroes or not, because if you like action, a well-paced plot, entertaining characters, and lots of humor then this film will be one heck of a ride.

After a crop of distinctly dull and tedious Marvel superhero flicks, it is refreshing to find one that is both entertaining and funny. I am so glad to see the return of this lively and larger than life band of heroes who really show the rest how a fantasy comedy should be made. There are plenty of wise cracks, many emanating from Rocket Raccoon who really carries much of the action. However this is a true ensemble piece with each of the characters being likeable and distinct. There are some great effects and imaginative settings, this is a properly crowd pleasing blockbuster which boasts a  fantastically toe tapping  soundtrack of 70s hits. This is clearly a movie made with a great deal of love for the subject matter by director James Gunn II. Here's to the next chapter.

'GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY VOLUME 2' was directed by James Gunn and stars Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana and Kurt Russell. Shortly after the events of 'Guardians of the Galaxy', the fame of the Guardians has spread throughout the entire galaxy and reached Ego(Kurt Russell), a cosmic being who has a personal relationship to one of the guardians.

Let me just say that I liked the original 'Guardians of the Galaxy' but I didn't think it deserved the mass acclaim it had achieved. That said, I had high hopes for this movie due to the talented team working on it and Marvel's recent track record. I really liked this movie. Gunn has outdone himself with this movie and provided a true, character driven story with good humour, great acting and stunning visuals. The original cast of the original return to this movie and all do spectacular jobs. That said, this movie does have a few flaws. One of them is the messy action. Not to say it was poorly filmed, none of the movie was, but it just didn't feel that clean and felt like they were trying too hard to make it very grand. I do recommend this movie but I think caution is warranted due to the differences in how the story is driven. If you're a die hard fan of 'Guardians of the Galaxy', I can see you having issues with this movie but I think most people will be able to take the changes and enjoy it.

In comparison to the simple origin story presented in volume one, this movie provides a much deeper, fleshed out study of the characters and is built around them and their relationships. I really appreciate this focus and feel it definitely benefited this movie. I also really like how every line of dialogue in this movie means something and has some effect to the story. This was a really clever way to approach it and made for some really powerful and even hilarious moments. Combine this amazing change in focus with the incredible ending, and you probably have one of the best, if not the best, MCU plots we've had. Well done Gunn.

My-main-strength-with-Volume-One-was-the-incredible-cast-and-that echoes-all-the-way-through-to-this-movie. Chris Pratt is amazing as Peter Quill and the exploration of his character in this movie is excellent. That said, I think that a greater focus should be applied to other characters because I don't want this franchise to turn into 'Starlord: The Movie' over 'Guardians of the Galaxy'. Both Zoe Saldana and Karren Gillen were great as Gamora and Nebula respectively and I really loved the relationship between the two. It's rare that movies can have a genuinely heartbreaking and emotional relationship between two characters that's carried in blood not in attraction. Vin Disel is Groot. Baby Groot is one of the most adorable things in the known universe and do Disney play on this? You bet they do but any excuse to look at the little guy is as good reason as any. Also, rebel Groot. Stay through the credits just to see Rebel Groot. Dave Bautista is also pretty good as Drax and steals a lot of the scenes he's in. Granted he doesn't receive much focus but I think they've expended all the ways they can use his character anymore and that is actually kind of sad. Bradley Cooper is great as Rocket but I feel like he was wrongfully pushed aside in this movie. There is one scene involving him and Yondu(Michael Rooker) in this movie that I thought was beautiful and poetic. Speaking of Yondu and Michael Rooker, Rooker did a phenomenal job as Yondu and gave probably the best performance in the entire film. This movie made Yondu one of the best characters in MCU cannon and I think it's incredible how they did that. Kurt Russell was also pretty decent as Ego and I genuinely bought his relationship to one of the Guardians. This movie had TWO sets of villains. One set was a very weak punchline that served nothing to the plot and existed for the sake of existing. The other set was very enthralling and intriguing for the former half of the movie but loses credibility and enjoyment value as the movie progresses.

Technically speaking, this movie is gorgeous. I don't mean that lightly either. This movie is so artistically appealing and visually stunning that I admire Gunn and Henry Braham for the beautiful movie they've produced. It really takes you back to the visual wonder and amazement of watching something like 'Jurassic Park' for the first time. Both movies are completely different, mind you, but the sense of awe and wonder you feel in this movie, and incredible attention to detail reminds me of my first viewing of that movie. Top the cinematography off with amazing visual effects(courtesy of half of China) and flawless costume/set design, and you have one technically astounding movie. 

The drama in this movie is also surprisingly well handled and I really bought the character conflict throughout. The laugh-to-cringe ratio was around 50/50, which isn't bad to be fair but they do hover around some jokes for WAY too long and this really reduces their meaning and humour value. As stated before, the action in this movie is really messy, except for one sequence towards the middle. 

The pacing for this movie was also WAY off and didn't work in the slightest. While the music was fine, it didn't hold a candle to Volume One and was no where near as good.

In conclusion, I do recommend you see this movie and I would rate it a solid 8 out of 10. I can see some die hard fans of Volume One having issues with it but realistically the new focus of attention definitely benefited the movie and helped garner my interest back into a Marvel team I neither liked too much or cared about. Congrats Gunn, you've earned it.

THE QUICK: If you liked the first one, you'll probably like this one. It's more of the same cuteness, sweetness, silliness that's expected. The misogynistic problem is even stronger in this movie. What's missing? The heart is kind of there, but not really. The storyline teeters a bit, and it leaves you wondering, with Marvel having problems with female representation why didn't they bring back original writer, Nicole Perlman? It made me wonder if she's the reason the script was so strong in the first movie (as my screenwriting friends vomit in their mouth at the mere mention of a genre movie being well-written. Yes, for its genre, it is). Oh, and the music isn't as finger-popping as the first movie, but then again, how can you beat a movie that opens with the Native American Indian music of a band called Redbone? But the music is still worth the price of admission.
WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW, IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN THE FIRST (with slight SPOILERS of the first movie): Guardians of the Galaxy are a ragtag team of misfits and criminals who decide to do good after they saved the galaxy. They are made up of Gamora, the green girl who is a badass assassin; Groot, a plant alien who can only say, "I am Groot." He started out as a huge plant but because of risking his life for others, he nearly died, only to be replanted and starting all over as a baby. Rocket, a raccoon-type creature who has been genetically modified and carries all the scars. He is able to build weapons and machinery out of basic junk parts. Drax, a gray-ish colored dude who speaks only in a literal manner -- no metaphors (though sometimes steps out of character), he enjoys going into battle and seeks revenge on the tyrant who killed his family. Peter Quill, AKA Starlord, is an Earthling who was abducted as a child after his mother died from cancer. He was raised by pirate-like aliens known as Ravagers, whose leader is Yondu. We find out at the end of this movie that Quill's father hired Yondu to bring Quill to him, and Yondu refused, raising Quill himself. We also learn that Quill is part human and part of an ancient, unknown species. THE WALKMAN and THE MIXTAPE, when Quill was abducted he had a few belongings in his backpack, which included the Walkman and a mixtape of cool music from the 80s and before (he was abducted in 1988). At the end of the movie, he finds a 2nd mixtape gifted to him when his mother died. 
Characters continued from the first movie: Yondu, the blue dude with a cool Mohawk. A blue alien redneck with a cool mohawk who practically raised Peter Quill. Nebula, Gamora's blue sister who was raised to fight Gamora as a test of strength and agility (Gamora always bested her and their father, Thanos, considered Gamora his favorite child). Sometimes, Nebula wants to kill Gamora. 
NOW, THE REVIEW: THE GOOD/THE BAD/THE UGLY (BUT BEAUTIFUL ON THE INSIDE): Overall, the movie made for basic good entertainment. The misogyny is more prevalent in this movie. This time they bring an Asian-looking alien into the movie (complete with accent) to play the Geisha role while being told she's ugly. Also, for whatever reason, a kid movie has characters living it up on a brothel planet. First, why a brothel in a kids movie, and second, why show a character zip up his pants and putting his clothes on while surrounded by "fembots"? What makes it worst, after they are done with the business, the "fembots" turn themselves off and shut down - thus, not wasting time with any of that yucky stuff that happens after sex. In the movie's defense, Gamora does have a stronger storyline and character.
The overall storyline fails for a lot of people, as the theme isn't coherent and a lot of the emotions and feelings are expressed in dialogue (a lot of tell, and not enough show). The themes don't seem as strong as the first movie. Here, there are a few, but they seem manufactured. So, unless, you have daddy issues, have an absent father or have a father who has recently passed on, you probably won't be as emotionally invested. A lot of people feel that Act 2 slugs a bit, where Peter meets with his biological father and they get to know each other. I can agree with that assessment, but the pretty visuals help this part of the movie move along. 
There are probably too many plots in the movie, so that may cause the sluggish pace. There's the plot of Yondu dealing with a mutiny, Gamora dealing with Nebula, the whole team having to deal with some gold aliens, Rocket dealing with his emotions, Drax dealing with a possible romantic connection (?), and, oh yeah, Quill dealing with an absent father who may have other motives.
The final act is okay, and has good hero moments, but overall, Baby Groot is what makes it so endearing and cute. What also saves the movie is that all of the characters are pretty much attractive, endearing and/or cute. 
Unfortunately, Nova Corps doesn't appear in the movie - except for what appears to be a Nova Corps space ship. They could have given Dewey Cox (AKA John C. Reilly) and Glenn Close a day for a small cameo. 
SHOULD YOU STICK AROUND FOR THE END?: If you're into that sort of thing, yes. There are some funny moments. And there are a lot of them. I think 5 was the count I heard.
CAMEOS: A bunch: One of Stan Lee's funniest, a character showing up from the first movie, a shoutout to the original (i.e., comic book version) Guardians, and a few more easter eggs (or should I say "cocoon").
MY MONDAY MORNING QUARTERBACK MOMENT: One problem with the movie is the theme of Fathers and Sons not being played out as strongly as it could have. Unfortunately, there wasn't a scene where Quill spends time with Yondu (to create a stronger point of the theme of fathers and sons). I think what would even help it is if the opening flashback, instead of showing mama Quill, it should have continued from the abduction, and given Yondu a tough-love father-like moment to show that he actually tried to be a good daddy to Quill. And we hint at the reason why he won't take Quill to his biological father. Also, the first half of the movie could have Quill and Yondu going up against each other, fighting each other, while still caring about each other, then getting separated from each other. Then, when it Yondu learns that Quill is going to find his father, Yondu wants to go stop him because he knows what's going to happen. Then, they can reconnect and have all the touchy feely moments that happens at the end. As it is now, it seems that as a main character, Quill has very little to do.
OVERALL: It was an enjoyable flick, worth the price of admission - again, if you're a comic book nerd purist then you'll see it if it was acted out  by a bunch of penises dressed in puppet costumes. I would like a stronger story movie, but it's good enough for what it is. This tomato won't give you diarrhea.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2 is the sequel to Marvel and Disney's 2014 hit Guardians of the Galaxy. The story centers around Star-Lord/Peter Quill and his relationship with his father, Ego the Living Planet, whom he just met. While that is going on the Guardians are being hunted by a powerful alien race called the Sovereign due to something Rocket does. The movie has quite a few twists and turns, a bunch of laughs, some great music, and one of the best Marvel Studios villains since Loki. In the end Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2 is one of the best Marvel Studios sequels ever and is well worth a watch.

Potentially unpopular opinion: I liked Guardians of the Galaxy 2 more than 1.  Volume 2 fixed my primary problem with Volume 1 which was, other than Star Lord, no other Guardian had substantial character arcs.  GOTG2 gave each guardian their own character arc and all of them were well done. Quill and Ego, Rocket and Yondu, Nebula and Gamora, even Drax and Mantis. In fact GOTG2 felt like a smaller and more character driven sequel, something Age of Ultron tried to do. If GOTG1 is a B+ movie, GOTG2 is an A- movie.  GOTG2 kept the style and tone of the first while expanding on the character stories. And thankfully, GOTG2 surprisingly didn't shove too much Baby Groot in out faces.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 was possibly twice as explosive as the first, both in plot and effects. The soundtrack this time around was just as fitting, and really made the movie. The plot twist is easy to see coming, but that doesn't prevent the viewer from having fun. It had heart, humor, and fantastic character development, and I'll no doubt see it again, but simply lacked something the first Guardians had. Overall, though, James Gunn's second entry into the MCU is welcomed with warm arms, and should delight any Marvel fan.

In terms of this movie as part of the Marvel Universe, this movie ideally takes many of the original characters we know of in the first movie and greatly fleshes out who they are, especially in terms of Yondu and Gamora's sister. This aspect made the movie particularly refreshing to watch and gave a lot more color to their personalities (it also explains a lot of different questions, but I don't want to spoil the movie).

In terms of the movie as a stand-alone, I don't think I've enjoyed myself so much with a Marvel Movie. Sure it has the typical Marvel-style fights, but this is also topped off with a thick (and I mean really thick) amount of hillarity and well-timed jokes. The visuals are also extremely gorgeous to look at (Marvel does love their lasers), and is really hard to look away from. My overall impression: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is hilarious, fun, and full of character, something I buy blu-rays for because it's continuously fun and fresh.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2: Marvel Comics' rag-tag crew of misfit superheroes, led by Chris Pratt, is back, this time to solve the mysterious identity of our star's father. Visual effects, makeup and music are all off the charts - unfortunately the film lacks the cute, quirky charm of the original, instead opting for a string of frenetic, trippy music videos assembled around a tedious, one dimensional story. Yes there are some cute and even sweet moments but this sequel is just ok, which is particularly disappointing given the extraordinary effort and number of people involved in it's making. C+

An additional thought: James Gunn is masterful at making vintage music an extraordinarily vibrant background character!

It's been around 2 years since I saw the first movie, so I can't make a good comparison between the two. What I can say, was I found Guardians of the Galaxy 2, a bit disapointing. It had so many plot lines and character arcs going that it became hard for more than one or two to actually get the screen time to be interesting. Development and relationships got rushed, and because of all this,  the comedy ending up working against the movie at times. At the beginning, the joke's were awkward and the timing was off, and as the movie progressed it reached a point where the comedic tone and serious tone couldn't mix well. It wasn't until the last 30 or so minutes, after many of the plot lines were resolving, that I felt they actually started getting the comedy down and I found myself consistantly enjoying it more. It's not a bad movie, there are still some funny moments, the characters are still enjoyable, action is fun, and some great references. But I find it hard to say I liked it.
Also, baby Groot was over marketed for how little he did in this movie.

An emotional story about finding family not in our veins but in our hearts, Guardians of the Galaxy (Vol 2), despite its eye-popping special effects (speaking literally), it really just boiled down to a story about clique loyalty and (in case you missed it) paternal child abuse. I walked away from the movie thinking that deadbeat white trailer park pops, like Ego, and abusive urban black daddies, like Thanos, can transcend galactic boundaries. From me, a three star rating means that I liked it. Five stars are only for the film most phenomenal. Yes. I liked it. And despite the incredible journey to galaxy what... M5-billion?!?, moving so fast forward through the cosmos while slapping me back to the 70's with musicales nostalgia, this did not take me there. It just felt like another in a long series of endless comic book expositions, the colossal Marvel Studio set up before the real entertainment starts. That Infinity saga had better be worth the wait, or I may just turn in my hairless dome, opt in for some hair transplants, and quit being a Watcher.
It's a decent movie and could have been better

With what feels like having a new sequel, remake, reboot or prequel every weekend, there has been some massive franchise fatigue as of late, which is ironic as the studio that is the number one culprit as to why this happened (Marvel) has actually made one of the better entries with the James Gunn-directed 2017 blockbuster Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2-reminding everyone what a good follow-up looks like. Starting off with one of the most fun and memorable title sequences in recent memory, Gunn's directing never lets up, vowing to entertain and awe us with his weird family of oddballs that you can't help but love, confirming that the 2014 hit wasn't a fluke. Having established such a quirky tone and style with the first film-some classic sci-fi adventure coupled with a classic rock 'n roll soundtrack-Gunn doubles down on this aesthetic depicting a unique vision amongst such a saturated market. The real victory for Gunn though lies in his writing, again surpassing expectations on characters that you shouldn't necessarily find all too charming (like a foul-mouthed, cynical raccoon) and is able to hit emotional heights that other filmmakers may have stumbled on. It creates a whole package of sorts-you have the action (which does get a tad redundant toward the end), you have the heart and the humor-resulting in Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 a special sort of sequel. The filmmaking is inventive, the writing is sharp and the performances all shine-signifying that this second journey with the most unlikeliest of heroes is a treat to behold and a Vol. 3 would be welcome with open arms.

The Guardians are back in the follow-up to the surprising box office hit of 2014.

Star Lord (Chris Pratt), Drax (Dave Bautista), Rocket (voiced by Bradley Cooper), Groot (now a toddler and voiced by Vin Diesel, who took time out between crashing cars and wearing white vests, to film his line(s)) and company all return, however this time there is a focus on the family dynamic between the team as Kurt Russell turns up as Peter Quill's long lost father, Ego.

Although it doesn't hit the same heights as the first Volume, there is still a lot of fun to be had with this edition.  It is very joke heavy and they don't always hit their mark but it's the characters that make the film work.  For me, it's Michael Rooker's character, Yondu who steals the show, whose roll is developed further in this film.

Visually it's stunning and the CGI is very effective.  The technical wizardry involved in bringing characters like Rocket and Groot to life is flawless.  The actions scenes are imaginative and well put together, especially the opening scene featuring Groot dancing to ELO's Mr Blue Sky whilst the rest of the crew do battle with giant tentacled space monster is a highlight.

Unfortunately, not all the characters are fleshed out.  Although the romance between Quill and Gamora (Zoe Saldana) is moved along, the story between Gamora and her sister Nebula (Karen Gilan) isn't given much attention.

As well as Kurt Russell (who is on fine form and probably would have made an excellent Star Lord had Guardians been made in the 80's) we are introduced to new characters the Sovereign, a genetically engineered race who hire the Guardians to retrieve batteries that are a source of power to their home planet, but according to Rocket are easy to steal.  We also meet Mantis (Pom Klementieff), an empath who acts as an aid to Ego and spends most of her screen time as a focus of Drax's insults.

Less plot driven, and more character driven.  Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 offers a nice mix of action, visuals and laughs to make us intrigued by what James Gunn can come up with in Volume 3 but doesn't manage the somewhat impossible task of eclipsing the original.

Set within the larger framework of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, the 'Guardians' franchise remains a curious outlier of sorts: its deep space adventures are a peculiar fit for the capes and codpieces found in more traditional superhero yarns. That's not necessarily a bad thing; the first GOTG film was a high-octane sci-fi romp that felt fresh and original back in 2014. Writer/director James Gunn's hotly-awaited follow-up attempts to recreate the razzle-dazzle of its predecessor, and it succeeds up to a point. The returning cast proves just as loveable the second time around (with the impossibly adorable Baby Groot being the clear standout), and the movie doubles-down on the oddball humour that made their first outing such an unexpected delight. That being said, it IS possible to have too much of a good thing, and the constant barrage of quips occasionally clutters up the action. Like many filmmakers of his generation, Gunn is clearly drawing inspiration from the 'Star Wars' films here, and GOTG2's structure bares more than a passing resemblance to 'The Empire Strikes Back' with the way it splits up its heroes during its uneven middle act, along with Star-Lord's Skywalker-esque quest to develop his untapped powers under the guidance of his Celestial father Ego (played by Kurt Russell, who alternates as both the Yoda and Darth Vader of the story). Fans of the original GOTG will likely find much to enjoy with this new instalment, even if it lacks the surprise and originality of that first rambunctious adventure. Overall, this mostly-welcome sequel manages to entertain with its abundance of eye-popping FX, irreverent humour and an engaging group of characters we've actually come to care about. [P.S. Don't forget to stick around for the its (count 'em!) five post-credits scenes.]

It advances the universe even further when adding more members to the Guardians team, and it is one of the funniest Marvel movies to date. It is almost perfect on paper, but the film faults in its execution. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 lacks the heart present in its predecessor, and it lacks many other things too. The acting in Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is unfortunately very weak, and that acting makes the film hard to take seriously. However, the film's excellent soundtrack, and the good cinematography and visual effects bring the film back into the dumb-fun category. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 isn't great, and certainly not as good as the first film. However, the film's persistent charm makes it fun to watch.

I think my expectations were a little too high going into this after the first Guardians of the Galaxy film, which was perfect. Vol. 2 is still a fun follow-up; Baby Groot is adorable, and the development of Michael Rooker's Yondu is definitely a highlight. The concept of Ego is executed well, and some of the visual effects were top-notch (notably the 700 jumps scene and the final battle with the villain where he reforms his bones and muscles). I still can't help but feel that the film was trying a little too hard to be funny. In the first film, all the jokes seemed more unexpected and timed better, especially with Bautista's character Drax, his jokes were just a little too over done. There was a line said by Star-lord at the end that sums up how I feel in this regard: "you shouldn't have killed ___ and squished my Walkman"; the impact of the statement is kind of ruined by the joke. I also felt like the murder spree by the ravagers was a little unnecessary and out of taste. The music choices were ok for this one, I just felt like the soundtrack of the first film was better. I still think it was a cool movie, just that it could have ironed-out a few little things to get it to the level of the first film.

With a nonsensical and meandering plot that travels from touchy-feely to hatey-feely and back, Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 presents a story and set of characters that feel like they sprang from a one-dimensional kids version of the first movie that was then made inappropriate for the kids whose humor it seemed to cater to. In my opinion, it satisfies no one and fails to emulate the off-beat, rag tag hero charm that Guardians of the Galaxy was and should be.

To be blunt, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is probably one of the best action-comedy sequels of all time and the most fun you can have in a theater right now.  It's a bigger and more fun version of the movie you liked the first time around, with a bit more gravitas and emotional involvement making it more substantial.  

To delve into plot details would take us DIRECTLY into spoiler territory, so on this occasion I will refrain.  What makes Vol. 2 and its predecessor work are the characters, including its minor ones.  Chris Pratt's Star-Lord is as charming as you remember him and has perhaps the best plotline for a Marvel hero since the Iron Man movies or Winter Soldier.  He still has amazing chemistry with Zoe Saldana's Gamora and she has quite a rivalry with Karen Gillian's Nebula.  Gamora falls increasingly into the "straight man" role, ironically enough.  Bautista's Drax and Bradley Cooper's Rocket Raccoon are a non-stop riot.  And oh yes, Baby Groot is even more adorable than you imagined.  

The real theme of Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is about fatherhood and mortality.  Two characters in particular flesh out this theme.  First, we have Kurt Russell killing it as Ego the Living Planet (yep you read that right - the Marvel Cosmic Universe is nuts like that).  To say that Russell's work is multilayered would be a dramatic understatement.  I'm still trying to figure out his actual feelings and opinions in regards toward the protagonist and his mother, long after finding out his actual motives.  Ego is both a fun, likeable character and ambiguously terrifying and dangerous one.  In other words, he's a Greek god walking around the Marvel Universe.  The other would-be father is Michael Rooker's Yondu.  Yondu has always been a wild card, but his full character arc provides the true heart of the movie, and in the process, he steals the show.  Rooker has the right balance of grit and emotional gravitas that makes him compelling to watch and a great foil to Ego.  In fact, most of the characters on screen, both major and minor, have some kind of arc going on and they pay off in surprising ways.  

The soundtrack is the same cool mix of 70's and 80's pop and light rock, but this time it's timed more thematically with the subject matter onscreen.  The action is a bit less sloppy this time around, and the third act is vastly superior to the Infinity Stone nonsense of before.  Overall, I rate it more highly, if you couldn't tell.  This is a must see, and it will probably end up in my home video collection, which is already overstuffed.

GotG Vol. 2 is a fun follow-up to the original. The team of misfits still have great chemistry and we are introduced to some of the best villains the MCU has provided thus far. Like in Vol. 1, every Guardian gets their moment to shine and even allows new teammate Mantis to feel like an essential part of the group. Kurt Russell brings charisma to the A-plot villain Ego, who could've just been another lame one-off Marvel villain. But he leaves an impression. Elizabeth Debicki as the arrogant B-plot villain Empress Ayesha provides another great foil for the Guardians. Also, there are no unnecessary forced cameos from other MCU characters. Thankfully the Guardians remain outside of the Avengers' world. GotG Vol. 2 doesn't quite reach the greatness of Vol. 1, but is the best MCU film since Vol. 1. Bring on Vol. 3!

My greatest complaint about the first film was how shallow the characters were, that they would in no way ever have become besties by the end of that story. Gladly, this film made me forget the flat runtime rushed plot of the first film and enjoy a fun, silly, heart-string tugging movie with substance. The ad nauseam marketing of this movie to children made me wary of this movie from its inception. That said, I re-watched the original for the 3rd time and it brought back the nostalgic feelings of hilarity mixed with heart that so many of us enjoy in a feature movie. So I decided to give Vol. 2 a chance and boy do I regret it. I'm flabbergasted as to why this movie received such a high rotten tomatoes rating. This movie is a clear money grab hastily thrown together without any of the elements that made the first movie so special. First of all the movie's starting point was sloppily conceived and cheaply thrown together.  Chris Pratt's heart was not in this performance. This should be obvious to anyone watching with a clear head and unbiased motivations. Third, the plot was uninteresting and meaningless albeit forced in the grand scheme of the marvel cinematic universe. It took all of 5 minutes for me to lose interest in this pointless movie and an hour in I was crying on the inside wishing I was anywhere other than sitting in front of the screen showing this putrid excuse for a movie. This movie will make you dumber for watching it, upset that you spent money viewing it and wishing you had the 2 hours of your life back that you spent forcing your eyelids open.

The first one wasn't all that bad and had a few laughs to offer, but this one is only for kids. Sure there are incredible visual arts and effects which blow your mind, but they are in such a rapid flow that neither your eye nor your brain can really take them in completely, and after a while your mind simply gets overflown with those overtopped, ridiculously exaggerated images and lets you watch it all more and more like a zombie. In fact, each time there weren't any explosions anymore I simply nodded off during the senseless, brain dead conversations. But the worst about this flick is, right from the very, very, very, very start, driving one extremely, horribly mad and making one absolutely annoyed, even letting you wiggle in your seat from side to side in anger, hoping it would finally finish, is that overstretched, endless, childish, puerile, trivial, ridiculous scene (are you getting my drift) of Baby Groot taking up various minutes of the opening part, which is supposed to be a fighting scene, but only shows that little annoying creature dancing in the foreground. In fact, huge parts of the movie are concentrating on the little tree, making this flick something for 3-6 year old to watch. Summary: Great FX and IT graphics, zero story, forced ridiculous, only slightly funny dialogues, and a tremendously bothersome focus on that Baby Groot character. That "I am Groot" phrase, which, each time, can only be interpreted by the crew to its different meanings, lost its funniness by the end of the first movie. Riding on it even into the titles at the end makes it seem quite retarded. 4/10 points

Star-Lord and the team are BACK BABY!!
Guardians of the Galaxy was a lighting in the bottle experiment by Marvel and it paid off in spade at the box office bringing a whole new feeling to the Marvel Cinematic Universe the likes of which was would never had expected to see; instead of keeping us on earth or Asgard its taking us to the far reaches of space with a group of scavengers, Pirates, talking raccoons and a lovable tree...oh yeah and Drax too; who would have thought these band of guys would end up being in our hearts after the first movie was done....well looks like they return but i the sequel also that lightning in the bottle as the first movie.....not really, but it comes pretty close! 

The Good:

What's not to love about Star-Lord (Pratt), Drax (Batista), Gamora (Saldana), Rockett Raccoon (Voice of Bradley Cooper), And Groot (Voice of Vin Diesel) their chemistry is off the chains in the last movie but it seems so much more improved in this film. 

Just when star-lord thinks he has everything together; after defeating Ronan the accuser the Guardians had their hands fun you know Guarding the galaxy (While hustling some money on the side from their exploits) a hiccup comes in the form of Peter Quills Father Ego (played awesomely by Kurt Russell) who literally comes into his life after the fact of his mother's passing on top of that a race of aliens who didn't like the Guardians actions are hunting the group in every part of the Galaxy, and IF THAT'S NOT ALL Gamora's sister Nebula is still loose and they might need a bit of sisterly bonding themselves. AND IF THAT'S NOT ALL Yondu (Michael Rooker) is going thru a crisis of his own as well which deals with taking Peter as a kid and he also must deal with the repercussions of his past actions. 

I know it might sound like a lot is going on in this Marvel Galaxy (and it is!) but it all comes woven together throughout this movie and while it doesn't maintain the balance of seriousness and comedic moments; this movie focuses moreso on the full comedic aspects in said film and while it works in some areas and not in others the end result you have a film that hold the topic of "Family" and what true family and loyalty means. 
every character in this movie you will either love them, or hate them...but in the end when the movie is done they will hold a place in your mind and heart and that's something that I think James Gunn does so well with this movie. 
At the end of this film, when i was in the theater.....people men and woman had tears in their eye; while i won't spoil the moment this movie will get to you on a level that not even DC could even produce when they made 'Batman V. Superman'. 
The chemistry is super good, the action sequences were colorful and beautiful, and while the plot was more so all jokes there's a point where it gets serious and wow it was a bit jarring but it does hit you when the big twist comes out. And while there was one more character Mantis (Pom Klementiff) I didn't get to mention till now she was also funny and moments with her and Drax made the movie interesting and kinda made Drax a lovable douche lol.


The Bad:

As i've mentioned in the good there's A LOT of things going on in this movie...and while it worked out pretty good; it could have went the other way too and there were moments in this movie where it nearly did. I felt the emotional tones in this movie while they were good they went the way of using Jokes to get thru them instead of letting it play its course, and this happens throughout the movie at some points. I actually wanted the serious moments play out cause I personally felt that it would have made the stakes personal on most of the characters...but nope, they add comedy and then the stakes doesn't feel personal nor heightened it just feels like its placed on the back-burner for the sake of comedy. 
Going back to having too many stories in this movie...there was too much happening and while it was easy to understand they could have made the plot more streamlined but i understand that they had to get this out into theaters and that people like me was so much expecting this movie so i won't hold it against them. 
 

Overall:

GOTG Vol. 2 it not the lightning in the bottle that the first movie produced but it does come close second; its fun, action packed, light-hearted, and heart wrenching. 
once again marvel hit another Jackpot and i can't wait to see these guys work with the Avengers in 'Infinity war' Good job marvel, you did it again!

After the first Guardians of the Galaxy surprised everyone by being one of Marvel Studios' biggest (and arguably greatest) hits in its lineup, it only figured that we'd inevitably get a sequel. Though considering the studio's plans, I think they always intended to have more than one adventure with these colorful characters. James Gunn returns to the writing and directing seat with this sequel with the original cast, including Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, Dave Bautista, Bradley Cooper, and even Michael Rooker, Karen Gillian and Vin Diesel returning to fill their respective roles, all to a wonderful tee, in this hilarious, action-packed and even emotional sequel that's filled with amazing effects, great action sequences, and a lot of good acting, both from the notable main cast and the various cameos (some of which I didn't even realize were there). Honestly, I think that's all I got here. Go see it if you can, because it's amazing, and it won't be regretted by the end of it all.

Atrociously bad, which is very disappointing considering how good the first film was.  None of the characters had any agency, they simply reacted to everything happening to them rather than progressing the storyline themselves.  The tone was all over the place as well.  It went from bad child cartoon visuals to adult comments on reproductive organs and mass murder.  There were also a number of visual gags that could only be seen as funny by the incredibly young, followed by admissions of uxoricide and attempted patricide.  The villains were also a mess, there being 3 disparate groups that can fill the role in this movie who have nearly zero contact with the other villains.  

The worst and most vile thing in the movie, however, was the reaction many of the characters had to a villain's name.  It was a long running "joke", the crux of which was watching people struggle to act like they were hilariously laughing.  

The ending of the film was good... but it is absolutely not worth it to slog through the 80% of the film that is vile enough to make you question the quality of the first movie.  I would rather watch Iron Man 2 or Thor 2 than watch this movie.  Or both.  For a week straight.  This movie was torturous.

The first Guardians of the Galaxy is one of my favorite MCU films of all time, so I was beyond excited to spend more time with these lovable characters and go on another journey with them. While the Vol. 2 does suffer from the occasional tonal inconsistency and lack of freshness (which is a very common problem for a sequel), for the most part I had a blast watching this film. The thing I loved the most about this movie is the way writer-director James Gunn delved deep into the backstory of each guardian, making this particular installment a personal film while simultaneously making everything surrounding them bigger and louder and funnier and more visually dazzling. Not only is this absolutely exhilarating, but also emotionally very satisfying. This is the first (and hopefully the last) MCU film that made me cry. Hats off to Gunn, the cast, the crew, and everyone involved in the project. "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" is a damn good time.

Marvel has made a name for itself by bringing humor, humanity, and cohesiveness to their comic book films. The Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) has been a juggernaut of profits. Not only are there innumerable comic book heroes to bring to the big screen, but the very nature of comic books--serialized stories--means that sequels almost write themselves.

Marvel has been the king of comic book movies with films that appeal beyond the devoted Marvel acolyte to the general public, who enjoy brisk pacing, witty dialogue, and overall enjoyable, entertaining stories.

Marvel has an almost infallible recipe for creating movies, and unfortunately the new Guardians of the Galaxy, Vol. 2, while not a recipe for disaster, is a recipe for boredom.

The original Guardians of the Galaxy is one of the best Marvel films to date, taking the over-used formula for a hero--being a misfit (fill in the blank)--and turning the formula into an enjoyable, adventurous ride into the wild west of the galaxy. What made the original so compelling, lovable characters, fast-paced adventure, and humor, are unfortunately lacking in the second.

"It's Not Time to Make a Change"

Overall, the characters (and the acting) this time around feel strained and tired. Even the natural charisma of Chris Pratt (Peter Quill) isn't enough to make the character (and the rather poor dialogue) grow from where we left the character. At the end of the first film, our heroes fly off into the galactic sunset to further adventures. By defeating Ronan the Accuser, our unlikely gang of misfits have become a family.

In the second, the family is already on edge and falling apart, but the reasons for this are not explained and not believable. The differences overcome in the first film feel meaningless as the heroes bicker about who can fly the spaceship better. It's a false conflict that leads to false resolutions.

While there are standout moments (usually centered around Baby Groot or Drax the Destroyer), the writing in this sequel is so bland it hurts. Several times throughout the film, I found myself wondering if there had been casting changes for the second film. Zoe Saldana, a memorable character from the first, blends into the background and is so mundane to be forgettable. Chris Pratt, whose charm brought Peter Quill into comparison with Han Solo or Indiana Jones and arguably opened up entirely new acting roles to the comedic actor, can't seem to pull off the magic a second time. But again, how much is the fault of the actors and how much is the fault of the writing?

"Just Relax, Take it easy"

Foundationally, the problem with this film is its plot. The plot of this film is a traditional "find your father, realize your father is evil" plotline, and while the first Guardians of the Galaxy had a derivative plot as well, it's other attributes made it a fine film.

Vol. 2, without the witty writing and stellar acting of the original, floats in the doldrums of melodrama and Daddy issues. Part of Peter Quill's charm in the first film was the tension between his ordinariness and mysteriousness. At heart, he's a child of the 80's living the carefree life of a 20 year-old in a very extraordinary environment. He's almost a Tom Sawyer type character falling into adventure with boyish charm and slyness.

In this film, Quill finds out that his father is a "god" who has "phenomenal cosmic powers" (to steal a line from Disney's Aladdin). And guess what? Peter Quill has the same power as well! But, as in most daddy-issue plots, the father is evil and the son has to make the ultimate choice: Daddy or friends?

Star Wars did it better, and one can't help but wonder why, of all places to take these enjoyable characters, we had to end up in a mediocre pit of "Luke, I am your father" cliches? This film is only 15 minutes longer than its predecessor, but it feels much, much longer.

"You're still young, that's your fault"

There are plenty of enjoyable moments in this film, and there are moments that will make you smile. But the magic of the first film is not in its sequel, and overall the film is just another average action movie.

In the end, one wonders if the original Guardians of the Galaxy was an accident? A fluke of a more obscure comic book tale hitting a grand slam by happenstance?

I don't think so.

Instead, Guardians of the Galaxy, Vol. 2 suffers from a broader problem that Marvel is beginning to have. After so many films, characters, connections, and future sequel plans, Marvel has gotten caught in its own mammoth web. How can Marvel, with nearly a decade and 15 released films to its name, bring new stories, characters, and ideas to the big screen? How does one release film after film, in the same universe, without characters and plot-lines repeating one another?

The problem, of course, lies even deeper in that Marvel is a subsidiary of Disney, who is having a nearly identical crisis with its other subsidiary Pixar (see Christopher Orr's wonderful explanation of Pixar's slow death spiral at the Atlantic). With the end of Phase Three coming soon, can Marvel bring something new to the table?

We've seen more than our fair share of Marvel movies, the last being the psychedelic and egocentric "Doctor Strange." But if you think of a ragtime team of quirky misfits, only one series easily rises to the top. Kicking off the first of three MCU outings to release this year, "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" is, unsurprisingly, another surefire hit. Banding together Star-Lord, Gamora, Drax, Rocket and Baby Groot, it's a welcome reunion of unrestrained comedy and adventure. Known ubiquitously as the 'Guardians,' we find our heroes tasked by a group called the 'Sovereign' to protect valuable batteries from an inter-dimensional creature.  Like its predecessor, the film thrives on classic oldies, some intentionally less familiar than others. But this time around, Gunn opts for slower ballads, in turn missing a level of energy that emboldened the first one. Fortunately for us, the humor remains intact, utilizing each character to the best of their strengths, or in some cases, their weaknesses. Despite a cynical raccoon (aka "trash panda") and newly reborn tree being, the funniest of the bunch is none other than Drax the Destroyer. David Bautista is an irrepressible riot, becoming the bedrock that coincidentally unifies the characters. As relations are ultimately tested and frayed, 'family' becomes the overarching thematic, particularly for our lead hero. Kurt Russell joins the cast as Quill's (Star- Lord) father Ego, a seemingly remorseful yet powerful being. With motives unknown and a strained reconciliation, the film gradually becomes a retrospect of father and son. As a result, it's a slower build-up than before, spotlighting again the problem with most Marvel flicks: uninteresting villains. But Gunn makes up for it with spectacular visual effects, expanding the unexplored universe with colorful imagination. The aging effect, notably, is probably the best we've seen yet, and a stellar indication of just how far we've come in technology. While "Vol. 2" may not be the superior sequel that we hoped for, it definitely substantiates it's not just a one hit wonder. Note to the wise: hang tight until the very end to be treated by not 1, not 2 but 5 end credit scenes. (Thanks James Gunn.)

We just came in from seeing Guardians of the Galaxy 2 and enjoyed it. No, it wasn't as good as the first, but it was still worth the trip if you're a fan. My big disappointment was the unnecessarily crude and vulgar language. Douche-bag, dick,  shit, penis...and that's just what I can remember off the top of my head. It was over the top and the little kids in the theater behind us were just soaking it all up. It's because of their exposure to this kind of language, that they think it's funny and appropriate to use it in school and call others names like that. A parent in one of the reviews I read was ok with it because she said it's the same as the language her kids come home from school with. Well, how about if parents just stop exposing their kids to it "because everyone else does" and make it more of a point to let them know that it's not right. I do not agree with bringing a child under the age of 13 to see this movie.

Con una sobre carga excesiva de humor, Guardians of the Galaxy VOL. 2 nos hace recordar lo buen nivel que logró su antecesora, nivel al que esta nueva entrega no logra llegar a pesar de seguir siendo una buen filme.

James Gunn logra un perfeccionamiento en la personalidad de algunos protagonistas y les da mayor  metraje en esta entrega, es así como logramos conocer mejor las historias de Drax (Dave Bautista) y Gamora (Zoe Saldana) se exploran las dinámicas de amistad entre el equipo y se descubren historias que no impresionan pero si responden las preguntas que planteo la película original. Aunque la historia se sigue desarrollando al rededor del repetitivamente humorístico personaje Peter Quill (Chris Pratt) esta vez no roba tanta pantalla como antes. Disney pone su aporte con su estrella infantil Kurt Rusell que con todo que tiene canas, arrugas y  votó por Trump sigue siendo "Cool".

Con una gran cantidad de nostálgicas referencias ochenteras desde los trajes hasta la música, que en este caso llega a un nivel de obviedad un poco aburridor, sin embargo es uno de los elementos fuertes  que aportan a la película por la impecable selección de piezas musicales hecha por el director.

Humor (Excesivo) secuencias de acción que llevan al espectador al borde de la silla y una trama liviana, son las cualidades de "Guardians of the Galaxy VOL.2" otra perla del universo marvel que se une a un firmamento de geniales producciones que introducen la trama al díptico de "Avenger: Infinity War".

Por último y lo más genial de la película es el bebé groot, se roba el show por todo y todo, a pesar de que su lineas no pasan de un elocuente "I am groot" muestra que con esto es suficiente para tener mucha personalidad y muy buen sentido del humor. No olviden estar atentos a los "huevos de pascua" y las escenas finales que conectan a este equipo de supe héroes estelares con otros grandes héroes del universo Marvel.

The problem with that is that they it was rushed due to the choice to allowing a majority if the characters face time.  The most painful part if the movie was Drax. There is a big turn around of his character in that he is the comic relief. All the jokes and laughs concerning him was hard to watch or even believe as a part if his character. Baby Groot also had many screen despite the fact that the character had no advancement in story. He served as a fan service and sell Baby Groot merchandise.  The best thing in this movie was Yondu and his relationship with Quill. I wish they would have explored that relationship more instead of cramming a bunch of relationships in one movie. It would have been nice to know that there was more faith in the franchise that it has more chances to tell the other peoples story.  Still, not the best movie but enough entertainment to enjoy the movie. Not for the laughs, but the action and the very well written part of Yondu and Quill.

Though much of the same charm and wit survived from the first installment, GotG2 suffers from inconsistent pacing to the point that a couple CGI/3d-porn sequences just roll on endlessly to the point that forward momentum just stalls. Most folks I've talked with felt that scenes like the final battle, Yondu's extended arrow-kill and some similar - while visually impressive - needed to be trimmed to the point that a minute or two in, we were all waiting for something interesting to happen. Even the opening sequence - largely brilliant - lasted a few beats too long.
Mantis looks like a nice addition to the group and the further development of Nebula helped address her relative lack of depth from the first movie.
Sadly, the end credits were a lot of fun, but too many teasers made it a little unfocused.
Still, a great movie and worthy successor; I just wish someone had said "enough already" when editing those long action scenes...

2.5 Stars, actually
I've finally come to realize that I've sort of outgrown these kinds of movies. Is that sad? Maybe a little. Younger me might have loved this, but present day me just stares and waits for it to be over. 
The CGI is just SOOO omnipresent and in your face, and just plain overdone. Yes, it's well done, and lots of money has obviously been spent on it, but I can't help but feel sorry for the actors. They don't see this stuff! They stand in front of green screens and yell at placards. Definitely takes talent, though.
And then you have the overuse of pop songs and such playing throughout different scenes of the movie. I get what they are going for, but it's overdone. WAY overdone. 
Then we have the long played out Groot thing. It really feels like this baby Groot character was created just to sell toys. Especially to sell a "Dancing Baby Groot with hip swaying action!". 
I found the whole Daddy issues storyline incredibly cliche, as it's been done so many times before. We all knew exactly how it was going to play out right from the start. 
The best Characters remain Gamora and Nebula. It would be fun to get more story on these two. Gamora is so much more badass than Peter Quill. She should be the de fact leader of the Guardians, not him. 
Speaking of Chris Pratt...
There is just something about him I don't like. He has this smug look about him. His goofy face. His weirdly buff dude physique that doesn't seem to fit with the character, nor even the actor. It would be better to have a more normal looking(body-wise) geeky-type guy in this role, not a typical buff super hero. Maybe he just figured Marvel super heroes = muscle dudes, so he spends hours in the gym. It's just weird.  Plus, I just don't like Pratt in any role I've seen him in. 
The humor is ok, although much of it is forced. Plus, I hate teenage boy style humor, and there's plenty of it here. 
It's still decently entertaining which is why I give it up to 2.5 stars. Plus, these movies have a style and feel all their own, so they get points for that.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is overly sentimental - frequently even unbearably so - and extremely predictable, but still a lot of fun and it never overstays its welcome. The special effects are gorgeous and that entire planet felt alive and was fascinating to watch, the performances are quite good, the humor is solid and each character got their moment to shine.

Something about it felt amiss. They should have cut the first half in two and add the remaining part to the second one, which was much more interesting and exciting. The visuals were great too, but everything simply got drowned amidst the mess of some unneeded romance and unnecessary plot developments.
not quite as good as the first, but very entertaining - saw it in IMAX 3D and the special effects were amazing!

Glad to see the ragtag team back again, really lovable characters and a genuinely entertaining adventure. It doesn't surpass the first film but it definitely serves it's purpose as thrilling entertainment nonetheless.

There is so much to like about Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 and it doesn't really surprise me much as James Gunn hit a home run with the first one. Marvel has been on such a roll over the past few years and I'm sorry to tell the haters: They're not out of gas yet. I knew it would be funny from the trailers, but the humor hits you in different ways from the monumental to the subtle. It's sci-fi action that succeeds because of the funnybone at its core. For the most part it never takes itself too seriously.

Again, the trailers left me with certain expectations, one of which being that I had seen a good chunk of the good parts. Not so in the least. In fact, you remember that trailer scene where the Guardians are battling it out on the platform with the massive space monster? Yeah, that's just the first ten minutes. The movie is jam-packed with cool surprises that keep you on your toes even as the credit rolls. My lips are sealed, but be sure and stay on the lookout at all times for cool easter eggs.

I'll get off my praise horse for a moment to address my one gripe. While the film was excellent bordering on brilliant at times, I thought there were other times where it tried too hard. There were a handful of sentimental moments that were over the top reminding me of something I might find on a Lifetime movie. Gunn was forcing it, just as he found himself doing with a handful of the jokes that tried a little too hard to be funny. In his defense, there are few movies that get this completely right. In a film that feels like a walking punchline, there's bound to be jokes that fall flat. Not to mention it's better to try to hard than look like you never really tried at all.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 succeeds without there being any kind of plot to drive the ship. The cast's familiarity with each other shines onscreen. You have a better feel for these guys this time around which makes their actions and dialogue even funnier. Everyone will rave about how awesome and cute Baby Groot was, but I personally think that Drax steals the show this time around. He's over impulsive and his decisions tend to drive the direction of the group, mostly in directions they never wanted to go in the first place. The blunt way he puts things will leave you cracking up.

James Gunn returns to direct the sequel to his surprisingly different MCU movie that was the first Guardians of the Galaxy feature. However, where the first film succeeds this film is hit and miss. The first blended the comedy and drama well whereas this one seems to be so focused on making you giggle that the story takes a substantial hit. Volume 2 gives extra detail to the side characters such as Yondu, Nebula, and Mantis which is very refreshing, but some of the main characters like Drax, and to an extent even Peter Quill seem to coast on the first films popularity. Despite the unevenness of the film it does find room to surprise you from time to time. Michael Rooker as Yondu gives a show stealing performance, and Baby Groot is every bit as entertaining as you'd expect. For every triumph this movie has (The laughs, Supporting characters, ect.) there are just as many mistakes (The underutilization of Zoe Saldana & Kurt Russell, and those god awful golden people... to name a few). Though this movie is hovering around average on a broader film standpoint, if we just compare it to the outstanding track record of the past MCU movies, it's underwhelming to say the least.
I appreciate the level of depth this movie gives to its characters. I like how it explores relationships between them to add more stakes to the films final outcome.
Loved it! Going to see it again...
Terrible storyline and very disappointing. I loved the first one.

It's not as fresh the original, but works in its own way. Sure, there are twists you see coming from a mile away, but there is some great visuals, action, and humor that's worth the space bucks. In scope it might be smaller than the first, but the substance is what counts. Every very character gets their time to shine, some enemies become friends along the way, and the film takes on family matters in a most unusual fashion. James Gunn's desire to blend genres and trim the film's fine edges reigns supreme when he's at the helm. Plus, it's great that the Marvel films are now embracing the weird and wonderful atmospheres its comic book pages can offer.

A true thrill ride from start to finish, James Gunn beautifully balances his diverse and expansive cast of characters. When the humor works, it hits hard. When the movie wants to be serious, it knows how to conduct itself. Not to mention, it has an amazing soundtrack, with what is undeniably the best visuals and one of the best villains the MCU has ever seen. If Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 is anything to indicate the future of the MCU, it's looking pretty bright.

IT'S THE SAME OLD SONG - My Review of GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY VOL. 2 (3 Stars)

I'm gonna keep this one real short.  Anyone who has read my prior reviews know how much I loathe comic book movies.  Sure, there's a place for them in our pop culture, and obviously the rest of the planet seems to flock to see them, but for me, even when they're well-made, I just don't care.  Even at their best, I completely forget what I've seen the minute I leave the theater it happens.  

GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY VOL. 2, like its predecessor, is very well-made.  It's fun, fast, often hilarious, looks like a cotton candy factory exploded, and has a ton of the K-Tel hits you've come to expect from such an enterprise.  James Gunn is the right choice to direct and co-write these movies.  He loves watching THE BACHELOR, y'all, so he clearly has a taste for kitsch.  Even the cast seems to be having a good time, with highest scores going to Dave Bautista, Bradley Cooper, Chris Pratt, and especially Elizabeth Debicki in the uptight, Tilda Swinton role.  STILL, I don't remember a second of it.  Thankfully I took some notes.  Rather than recap the film, which every single person on the planet will see anyhow, I'm just going to present my bullet points and call it a day:

-The music is a fun treasure trove, with BRANDY by Looking Glass and ELO's MR. BLUE SKY used in the thrilling, funny and adorable opening scene being the high points. 

- Chris Pratt looks really good and STILL makes me ask, "How the hell did anyone see his physical potential when he played chubby Andy Dwyer on PARKS AND RECREATION?   He always had great comic timing and continues to here, but whoever said he's gonna be hot some day deserves 10% of his money.

- I'm wondering by now if Zoe Saldana is ever going to succeed in a movie where she isn't painted green or blue.

- Dave Bautista must have studied playground bullies while preparing for his role as Drax.  He has the point-and-laugh down pat and comes close to stealing the movie.

- Bradley Cooper, as he did in the first one, DOES steal the movie as Rocket, the highly expressive, ornery raccoon.  If I'm going to remember anything from these films, it will be how perfectly his face crinkles when he's annoyed. 
 
-To portray him as younger, the CGI work on Kurt Russell's face is incredible.  He truly looks exactly as he did when he made ESCAPE FROM NEW YORK.  Hey Kurt Russell!  Make another ESCAPE FROM NEW YORK!  Instead of the reported reboot, just bring back Kurt as Snake and power-spray his face with all that computer goodness. 

- Baby Groot is as cute as you would hope him to be, although he looks a little dead in the eyes as if he were possessed by those stupid Engineers from PROMETHEUS.

- Sylvester Stallone makes an appropriate cameo, but he's sadly upstaged by another surprise guest star who fits right into the zany spirit of the film.

- Michael Rooker brings the fun, but am I the only one who feels like he wandered off the set of BATTLEFIELD EARTH? 

- That uptight alien race amused me and caused me to scribble down, "CIS-ESQUE GENDERED GOLD PRIVILEGE".  Make of it what you will.  Side note, shouldn't all wars be fought with remote controlled drone-like space pod, silver marble thingies?  

- This is as good as a Marvel movie is going to get, and yet all I can think about is how much I can't wait to see THE LOVERS with Debra Winger and Tracy Letts.  May 27th can't come fast enough!
Loved it!!! Hilarious, captivating, emotional, suspenseful, beautiful & so well written & produced! Just a wonderful movie - new favourite!!

Plot wise, Vol. 2 feels a lot more like a fill-in-the-blank for about a dozen tropes, loosely strung together. Tonally, it is on a constant flip-flop: uncurated jokes are a constant and take up much more screen-time than needed, not to mention the constant gravitation around Baby Groot (who if, like me, you don't like will find to be more than you can handle).

The film shares the wild and bombastic action the first had, with some fun and unexpected guest stars as well. Many of the flaws from the first film have been addressed and improved, giving a fresh feeling to the whole thing. Unfortunately, it kept trying to shoehorn in character development in places it didn't need to be, and with characters we already knew about, while leaving others in the dark. It should be noted this movie is decidedly more "grown up" than the previous, featuring some real violence, strong and occasionally vulgar language peppered throughout, and some brief, graphically disturbing moments. That aside, it's a fun adventure that adds more depth to the team, and is really worth the watch.

The battle sequence seemed to be nothing more than a light show and the switch from good to bad character personalities gave me whiplash.  
At least half of the show could have taken place on Freud's sofa.   
Still it's not completely hopeless.  The humor was fun and baby groot was all cuteness.   Yondu really shone in this volume;  I loved what they did with his character.

I realized, after sitting through the final after-credits scene, that this was a children's movie. It was not marketed as one, but it clearly was meant for a young audience. In hindsight, so was the first one. None of the MCU movies have been targeted for adults. So, why was I there? 

I guess because it was a fun ride. It reminded me of the Saturday morning cartoons when I was growing up. It made me laugh. For all the violence, it had a feeling of innocence. I guess, part of me will never grow up enough to not want to see that. It felt good.

We arrived early, because we knew it would be packed on the first week. It wasn't. The more expensive XD 3D 9PM seats are more expensive and we got to sit where we wanted.. 

As we were approaching the theater, people piled out of the theater with     wide smiles on their faces. they were very happy. I did enjoy this movie and laugh quite a bit., but I had some problems.

The opening was -- colorful, but I never felt fear for any character in that scene nor any scene in the movie. No one was going to die. I will admit that the one death that mattered was touching. But you didn't fear that death coming. You saw it coming. It wasn't serious enough for me. No part of saving the universe involves Pacman.

There was some heavy stuff going on and frankly this could have been a Logan instead of a farce. Still, the movie delivered. 

I remember Yondu from the comics. He was deadly with that arrow. Perhaps too deadly. Who's going to beat him? He may be the one character made more tactically powerful in the movie than the comic. Gamora and Drax are far less powerful than in the comics.. I get a lot of grief about this but Drax looks like he has a pretty bad skin condition compared to the cool way his body is symmetrically tattooed in the comics. He's really hard to look at for me.

I didn't like seeing Ego come and go so quickly. He's been in too many stories to introduce here and then just kill.. 

Will I watch it again? Not in the theater, but on HBO, sure.

Really ambivalent about this movie. The writing is mostly so-so, the special effects are perfunctory, and often gratuitous. On the other hand, the final third of the movie somehow manages to pack a very gratifying emotional wallop. If the entire movie had worked at that level, I'd have labeled the film a classic and given it five stars.

However the tonality is all over the place, goofy jokes amid supposedly high-stakes, emotionally charged action scenes, funky music over an unnecessarily macabre scene of dead bodies floating down like rain (judging by the humour and basic-ness, I thought this film was for kids/teenagers!).
And frankly, once the villain' s plan was fully realized by our protagonists, I was ready for the thing to end. But no, there's like a 40 minute, drawn-out action scene to sit through. 
I get that this series is meant to be irreverent, I just wish they could be brave enough to be irreverent towards the cliche long action sequence climax. Just end it super suddenly!; THAT would surprise and amuse me.
