This film is amazing in so many ways. This film does push away from some of the ensemble feel of the first one making this film not feel as strong as the first one did by giving more development to other areas in the world that Guardians inhabit. It is amazing what James Gun manages to accomplish in this film. In this short he has managed to capture all the most important parts of the original making it more interesting and dynamic.

The first Guardians of the Galaxy was pretty much a 10 for me. I thought it was one of the funnest movies I had seen. Only being outdone by the Oscar wining film known as Birdman (which I watch once ever year). It is very naturally written and paced also extremely well. It was such a great film that was always going to be nearly impossible to outdo.

And in some ways it is better.

Vol 2 manages to give development to one of the lesser characters in the last film known as Yondu Making him a lot more interesting and a lot more dynamic as well. You come to care foe Yondu as a person.

The relationship between Peter and his father is also very well done and has a lot of heart.

And for the first time ever the Marvel movies actually manage to make a really amazing and captivating villain who matters!! This film also has a legitimate death in it. James Gun has done it people. He has broken the Marvel formula!!!

Sadly it is still to the defeat of the ensemble feel of the first one as the rest of the cast while still great and fun aren't being as highlighted as they were in the first one.

The jokes are more like Age of Ultron jokes with a few being really funny.

And the final act of the film feels like every superhero movie ever.

Overall though Guardians of the Galaxy is still a fun movie that you will still very much enjoy despite some of its flaws.

I don't go to Marvel movies expecting to have profound emotional experiences, but this movie gives you all the feelings. I mean I really felt all the things. The jokes land, the tears are properly jerked, the vengeance scenes are satisfying (-ly mirderous), and the beautiful moments are just beautiful. Also, I always appreciate when the seemingly obligatory overdone/forced romance stuff is left out. GoGV2 does a good job of keeping those elements as undercurrents. Of course the visuals are phenomenal. Personally, even among all the colorful and dynamic eygasms going on everywhere all the time, the young Kurt Russell stuff was just PERFECT. Its obviously really hard to cg real human faces (see Jeff Bridges in Tron) but this was simply seamless. 

Not 100% flawless, it was a little obvious at times, and a few character motivations and plot driving exposition left a bit to be desired (looking at you, Ego), but the obvious parts were still well delivered and the plot/character development flaws were minor.

My biggest complaint (not sure if this counts as a spoiler. But just I'm case.... Sort of spoiler alert) is the use of ANOTHER giant amorphous blob of evil and destruction in a superhero movie. Galactus, Parallax, Dormamu, I'm sure there are more examples, and now this. Can we not do that anymore?

I would put it on par with the original...  expanded storyline, good story line, a good run thru the emotions with character you can get behind and emote with.

The motley gang of interstellar freebooters in the Guardians of the Galaxy are split up into a tangled assortment of subplots that all converge on Star-Lord (Chris Pratt) meeting the sentient planet who turns out to be his father (Kurt Russell). The plot of this sequel is scattershot, but I get the impression that this was a deliberate choice on the part of writer/director James Gunn. This movie has plenty of badinage, action, adept soundtrack choices, and visual spectacle, but the focus tends to remain on characterization; this gives Dave Bautista, Karen Gillan, Zoe Saldana, Bradley Cooper, and Michael Rooker plenty of moments to shine. I guess it's debatable as to whether this movie completely recreates what made its predecessor such a fun ride, but (in my humble opinion) I'd say that Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a rare case of a Marvel Studios sequel properly recapturing and expanding upon what made its cast of characters so appealing in the first place.

Logan, 2017's first Marvel offering, was a movie I loved because of just how little it relied on its comic book origins, completely forgoing the superhero tropes and going in its own unique and totally enthralling direction.

Guardians 2 however, is a movie I loved because of just how intensely it embraced its comic book origins. The Kirby-isms shine through brilliantly and every couple of minutes I found myself grinning like an idiot at some new reference or stylistic choice.

Logan might be the super hero movie for people who don't like super hero movies. Guardians 2 is the super hero movie for people who have steeped themselves deeply in the lore of super heroes. But I absolutely adore them both for the same reason: How they made me feel.

It's finally here! I was a huge fan of the first Guardians of the Galaxy, like most people. So, I was super excited to see the sequel to one of my favorite marvel films. And I am happy to say that this film delivers. Is it as good as the first though? I don't think so. But that does not mean that this movie is fun as hell. Firstly, the positives: the characters. Director James Gunn knows how much the audience responded to the characters in the first film so he chose to make these characters even more developed and even more likeable in this film. Peter Quill, Drax, Gamora, Rocket and BABY GROOT are all.... perfect. Gunn gave even more background to these characters that makes them even more interesting than they were in the first film. Another positive is the comedy. This movie is very funny. There are some jokes that do fall flat and sometimes feel forced. But most of the time the comedy lands. Especially with Baby Groot. He steals the show every scene he is in and is the cutest thing ever. The action is fantastic in this film. The opening scene in this film is worth shouting out for being one of the best scenes in the film and incredibly well shot and incredibly funny. The last positive that I have is the addition of a few characters. Kurt Russell is in this film. I'm not going to say who he is just in case you stayed away from information, but all I say is he is great. It's freaking Kurt Russell. He's awesome. And one of my favorite characters form the first film Yondu, gets more time to shine and he is SO GOOD in this film. He was so badass and just so cool. As for negatives, like I said earlier, I feel that some of the comedy didn't work as well as the first film. And my biggest negative for this film is aspects of the story. I think that Vol 2 does not have as strong as a story as the first. Sometimes weighing the film down. And last negative, I had the same problem with the character of Nebula in this film that I did in the first. I think Karen Gilan is not good as that character and think she is very over the top in every scene she is in. But other than that, I think this is a great sequel. Lastly, I was endlessly impressed with James Gunn's directing because I was surprised to see that this film is very emotional. Towards the end there are a lot of scenes that I got an emotional punch in the gut from. 8/10

Amazing! I laughed. I cried. That opening sequence is one of the best on film and the ending was so touching and just perfect. Anyone who criticizes it for not being just like the first is missing the deeply layered character work that is going on here that is just as thrilling and builds the excitement of the action scenes even more. The moments of strong emotion highten the other emotions by showing the audience contrast. For example, it was interesting to see how jovial Drax is here which is a testament to his relationship with the Guardians. Perhaps he was more like this before his family was massacred but those events made him the dour creature he was in Volume 1. And it made the moment he was sad makes it even more so. So I guess you could say I loved it.

The crass and lovable Guardians return in a more self aware and cartoonish sequel that delivers big laughs and surprising character moments.  The cast as a whole has some fantastic chemistry, with each main character dishing up some incredibly memorable moments of snappy comedy (Yondu steals the show with his classic reference) as well as some heartfelt moments as well that balance the adventure nicely.  

I'm not as big of a fan of the decidedly more cartoonish humor, as it really feels somewhat bizarre despite how irreverent GotG already is at times.  I can appreciate, however, the times when Guardians gets weird with it's world-building as it still features some of the strangest and creative fiction visually - its neon soaked landscapes and bizarre alien cultures/species make it a feast for the eyes.  

The plot revolves around Starlord and the gang meeting Peter's Dad, discover more about Peter's past, shake up the ravager fleet, and once again save the galaxy.  It's a decidedly more focused plot as compared to the first, and it has some juicy twists in the latter half (along with some comedy gold too).  It's also way weirder as compared to the almost grounded original.  

And what of the "Awesome Mix Vol. 2" music selection?  I didn't feel that it was as strong and as perfectly integrated into the film as the first, but man are there some excellent picks throughout.  

The original is a tough act to follow as it had the element of surprise on its side.  Despite falling into the expected trappings of sequels, it's weirder and more creative than the first - not better - but still a wildly good time with some of my favorite Marvel characters.

Showtime, A-holes. The MCU is back with the weirdest, most bizarre, and out there comic book films to ever come out. That also includes Howard The Duck. And it has a lot to live up to given how everybody was waiting with abated breath to see if Guardians Of The Galaxy would live up to the insane hype that included a wise cracking raccoon and a sentient 8 foot tall tree that says three words. Well the MCU once again hits another one out of the park with an even stranger film but with everything that everyone loved from the first. With new, interesting characters, uproarious humor, shocking twists, heartfelt moments, engaging character development, and explosive action, the Guardians are back to show comic book movies and summer blockbusters in general how to do fun and have fun while doing it. These bunch of A-holes are just what the doctor ordered.

We finally embark on yet another adventure with the biggest and our favorite screw-ups this side of the cosmos, the Guardians Of The Galaxy. They're still the same idiots and lovable losers as before but now with the responsibility of being tasked with taking on the galaxies hardest tasks and fearsome creatures. Set six months after the events of the first film, though closer together with time and experience with one another, they are still miles apart in other areas. Which makes the overall aspect of this would be family that much more engaging. Even with their criminal records expunged at the hands of the Nova Corps, they still can't resist from giving in to their past habits. This makes sense from a story standpoint since it hasn't been that long since Guardians Of The Galaxy. One shouldn't expect them to change immediately overnight even if it comes at the risk of losing their lives. It makes for an overall more entertaining movie as the internal squabbles and arguments that encompass the film has more meaning overall by the time it ends.

The group's selfishness and ability to trust one another in the first movie lead to disastrous results at the behest of their overall goal. By the time the film ends, you buy that they are all friends and really care for one another based on their overall growing experience. While the group isn't trying to kill one another, there are still issues to be had and arguments that continue to fervor. The movie doesn't forget that these people have many problems and have done terrible things, leading to major repercussions. It doesn't paint them with a single broad brush but with added dimensionality that makes them stand out among other comic book characters. It's a testament to James Gunn's writing that he can wring out that much more emotion and heft from these characters after delving in so much in the first film. There is a progression that feels natural even if one has seen some of it before while still being able to surprise at the same time. Gunn didn't simply rehash the emotional beats of the first film; he explores other themes that weren't able to be covered in the first film. It makes for the perfect companion piece and sequel for allowing the Guardians Of The Galaxy to not only grow as individuals, as a team, and most importantly as a family.

And this is what sets it apart from the Avengers and their films. The overall feeling and tone of the team feels more like coworkers sometimes than a close knit family. A lot of that has to do with the Guardians living lives of endless torment and emptiness, turning to a life of crime, and living with one another on a ship and not these individual massive egos living in different parts of the world. Given that the Avengers have argued and fought one another for three films, with a huge break up in Civil War, how they will make up to be strong enough for the mad titan Thanos while teaming up with a whole league of vastly diverse heroes is particularly exciting. This makes the eventual meeting and possible confrontation with the two superhero groups that much more tantalizing. When Infinity War comes out next year, the Guardians will have been the galaxy's protector and lived with one another for four years and that also will be interesting as such a huge time jump hasn't really been done before in the MCU between movies.

The acting from the cast was predictably great with each character, new and old, getting enough screen time to delve into their insecurities and emotions and present another side to their very complex personalities. Chris Pratt has charm, charisma, humor, and overall likability for days on end. Star-Lord's tragic past is delved into as he meets his father, a mysterious being with powerful capabilities. He also tries to woo Gamora into a more meaningful relationship while trying to keep his emotions in check while seeing the father he's never met before. I have said this previously before about Guardians Of The Galaxy, but It's a little Star Wars-esque with a roguish hero with no parents attempting to court the beautiful, strong willed warrior born from royalty who eventually meets his father under tumultuous circumstances who has unspeakable power. Like George Lucas said of the prequel films, "It's like poetry, sort of. They rhyme."

I really liked where they went with Star-Lord who was able to move on from his mother's death but then goes through another set of emotional problems when he meets his father. It also makes sense for the sequel to focus on him meeting his father given that Yondu and Kraglin pondered on the decision to not deliver Star-Lord to Ego like he was paid to do. Gamora is forced to be the more rational and adult of the group, questioning if a certain direction is the right way to go. Still guarded as ever with her emotions, Gamora remains ambivalent to Star-Lords pelvic sorcery, casting doubt in the future of the evolution of their relationship. All the while engaging in yet another battle to the death with her still ever so pissed off sister, Nebula. With the first film, I wanted their relationship and backstory more fleshed out and it's thankfully revealed here where you get the sick and twisted upbringing they had to endure while living under the supposed guise of normalcy by a mad titan. Nebula is one of my favorite comic book characters and she is even more so now.

The bitter rivalry, contentious jealousy, and hidden love between Gamora and Nebula were very well handled in that it didn't feel forced or sappy. You could tell that it won't ever really be all right but as long as they have each other, it will be ok. Drax The Destroyer damn well steals the whole god damn show by sheer force of will. He's even more hilarious this time around, more obtuse, and increasingly goofy to an insane degree. Rattling off one-liners with a steady, dead pan, serious delivery, he takes over a scene whether it involves the size of his shits or the unattractiveness of another woman. He always says the most inappropriate things at the most inopportune times, asking questions with a childlike wonderment. Rocket Raccoon also helps steal the show with another devastating heart to heart while being a sort of father figure to Baby Groot. I liked how Rocket can't help but act like an asshole to everyone all the while trying to keep Baby Groot in check. It presents an interesting dichotomy in character.

Yondu just may be the MVP of the whole movie, exploring dimensions I didn't think were there while maintaining that gruff, badass exterior. Michael Rooker has that southern redneck charm that just oozes throughout to be one of the more engaging characters in comic book movies. It's a testament to Rooker's acting who so effortlessly acted as one of the more unlikable characters in The Walking Dead as the racist, redneck asshole Merle to become one of the more interesting characters in the entire show. Not just merely a supporting character, he is crucial to the internal webbing of the whole movie and the most important emotional moments. Mantis is something completely different when it comes to these characters. Being in the employ of Ego for her entire life, she presents a naiveté to essentially everything around her and unaware of the most basic of social conventions. And it's played very well when going off of the unfiltered Drax, someone who doesn't know much socially against someone who says whatever he feels. Pom Klementieff pulled off an amazing performance not just with her unique high pitched voice but her facial and body movements. Everything she added just made it into a vastly complete performance in so many aspects. You can't help but be engaged every time she shies away from something she said or acts in a weird way in response to something she hasn't seen or experienced before. It's the more unlikely of relationships that just further adds another bizarre, complex, and endlessly unique pairing that just makes all the more sense the longer it goes on.

Kurt Russel is simply put a cinematic legend and one of the greatest action heroes of all time. And it's about damn time that he was put into the MCU as the father to another action hero in Chris Pratt. Ego is an interesting character in that he is vastly different from essentially any other character in the MCU and is by far the most powerful thus far. It presents a different set of questions that separates himself from other characters in that he has such massive power and has been alive for such a long time. His ideology differs from others in such a drastic way that even when you break it down, you can understand him and maybe even sympathize with him somewhat. Russel brings his usual gruff, scenery chewing bravado that just takes over a room. He leaves an imposing trail before him where you can't help but be caught up with him. But he also can bring it down a few notches and be serious at the right moments, leaving him to be an even more imposing figure.

Baby Groot once again is the best character ever regardless of his form. The best decision the MCU ever did besides casting Robert Downey Jr. as Tony Stark/Iron Man was having Groot "die" only to be reborn as Baby Groot. It just opens up the story possibilities that much more when one of your main characters is rebirthed in a different form. It's a cliché that TV and film have done before but it feels fresh in this aspect. Baby Groot is by far the cutest and most unlikely character to ever come out of the MCU. It presents new challenges and ideas for not only the character but the team as the previous version of Groot was the biggest and strongest of the group, not to mention he had a more adult brain. With a smaller and more childlike Groot, it has advantages and disadvantages which makes for more comedic, cute, and inventive moments which make up some of the bets parts in the entire movie. One moment in particular just breaks your heart when you see Baby Groot being put through the wringer and you'd do anything to not see him sad or cry.

Ayesha, the golden High Priestess and the leader of the Sovereign people was even interesting and far more engaging than Ronan and the Kree. While not necessarily evil or even bad, they're a race of people who were born to be mentally and physically perfect. It's a good use of opening up the galaxy to different races and characters who may be introduced in future films. The Ravagers got a lot of screen time with Yondu's right hand man Kraglin getting a bigger role than before and opening up those characters to new exciting opportunities in the future. Sylvester Stallone has a really cool cameo that is very befitting of his stature as an action god. There is also an amazing brief cameo from an 80s icon as well as a great usage of another 80s icon. Stan "The Man" Lee of course had the best cameo and probably the best cameo he has ever done as it's just way too perfect. The entire foundation for most of these characters is that for all they have went through with one another, they still have a lot to go. There is great use of pathos throughout the film while not meandering on sappy overindulgence. They are far from perfect which makes me like them even more. The surreal and diverse conglomerate of characters is among the best for any action/sci-fi flick, let alone any comic book movie. The way that GOTGV.2 introduces a slew of new characters while teasing others and giving just enough time for everyone is rather impeccable and quite refreshing to see. It's a rare franchise that knows how to build a separate universe within itself and not be bogged down the slightest by everything that is going on all around them. it doesn't lose track of anything that it tries to juggle, doing everything effortlessly.

I loved the story and the natural progression of characters, allowing for nice development all around. Everyone has a moment to lay their emotions on the table, even Baby Groot that fits right in with their characters. Essentially, its broken down to everyone is an asshole in some way, shape, or form to someone else to where they eventually learn of their asshole-ish ways. It's a tale as old as time, but used very well here. everyone has a reason to act like a dick even if it may be disastrous to others. it was managed very well with everyone working in pairs to reach some sort of emotional growth as a person. I probably liked the Gamora/Nebula pairing the best but the Rocket Raccoon and Yondu/Baby Groot was also very good. There was much to like seeing all these characters interact with one another that actually progressed as the movie went along and giving the story that much needed depth to anchor everything. The story is a little less involved than the first where there isn't a power structure and underlings vying for control of the galaxy.

And since the Guardians are acting alone without interference from the Nova Corps, it frees them up to save the galaxy by themselves and not rely on a ruling authority for help or assistance. The final plan was utilized well where the entire galaxy was actually harmed by what was happening, putting the danger at a different level as well as the Guardians importance to the safety of the galaxy. There are macguffins like the first film that help drive the story forward but in no way is that a slight against it and even if they may be cliché, if used correctly can be very beneficial to the overall story without bringing it down. As you would guess as the first film centered on Star-Lord moving on from the death of his mother, the sequel focuses on the role his father had on him. While the first hit the emotional beats rather hard, the second hits them even harder with much proficiency to present an all-encompassing arch that's perhaps the best in all of the MCU.

Vol. 2 probably has the best moments overall in an MCU movie and maybe a comic book movie. It is chock full of memorable scenes that just flow from one to another, leaving it impossible to just pick a single one. It starts off with a bang, and much how Baby Groot stole the entire film by the ending credits of GOTG, Baby Groot once again nearly steals the entire film in the beginning credits of Vol. 2 in one of the most memorable opening credits themes ever. Backed by a classic 70s rock staple, it would move even those who are the hardest of stone and coldest of hearts. But it doesn't stop there as it presents amazing action sequence and moment after another amazing action sequence and moment. Rocket using his ingenuity and quickness was fun, Baby Groot acting like well a baby, as well as Yondu kicking some ass with his telepathic arrow were all standouts. The violent to the death rivalry between Gamora and Nebula was thrilling with some real stakes at the end. the conclusion of the film was very effective with the final battle being a battle set in space like most space epics. But it was fun and engaging while showing you can utilize factors that are used in other films of the genre and not have it be tired or overdone. It made for a perfect backdrop while opening up the franchise to new possibilities when Volume 3 comes out in 2020.

The soundtrack was yet again a classic piece of 60s and 70s pop, rock, and soul used to perfection for the most emotional, thrilling, and potent moments. I'm not sure yet if it beats the first but its damn close. I'll have to see Vol. 2 again to really let those moments and songs sink in. James Gunn truly is a master of matching up a great moment with a catchy, classic 70s hit. Given how the ending played out, I don't know where the soundtrack can go for Volume 3. But if there is anyone to challenge that and deliver, it would have to be Gunn. The GOTG films continue to be the most gorgeous and most vivid comic book and action films with special effects that continue to dazzle in the most spectacular way. I didn't see it in 3-D as I'm sure it would have been worth the price but it looked incredible without it. no other movie seems to grasp the splendiferous magnitude of space, bringing iconic imagery like the Pillars Of Creation to life like no other film can. It's just another aspect that sets it apart from essentially any other film like it. giving everyone in the theater even more of a reason to stay after the film ends; it gives the audience a whopping 5 after credit scenes ranging from just straight up funny to teasers for future films and characters to that one single question that has eluded us for millennia. It was essentially a big cherry atop the most delicious sundae ever, leaving me with just the right amount of comfort to hold me over till the sequel in three years. Or till Spiderman: Homecoming is released in several weeks.

As director and writer, James Gunn can simply do no wrong and is fully entrenched with these characters and this ever expansive world. It's a huge sigh of relief to know that he will return to direct and write Volume 3 as I cannot see anyone taking the reins from him in any way, shape, or form. He knows how to shape a character in one way only to shift it in another direction with such ease that it doesn't feel out of place. Everyone has a funny and heartfelt moment and Gunn equally disperses the action, comedy, and more emotional elements to create a great overall popcorn blockbuster. A bizarre complaint I read from a snooty, high-nosed critic said that it relied too much on juvenile humor like the size of Drax's craps. But he seemed to forget that Star-Lord made a joke about the Milano being covered in semen in the first film. If you've seen the first film, you know what you're getting into with the sequel in regards to its lowbrow humor. It's not high art meant to be compared with the likes of Coppola, Kubrick, or Hitchcock. I went to Guardians Of The Galaxy Vol. 2 for many things and one of those was to laugh at stupid humor and it delivered.

I don't want to be one to sound the alarms, but I think Warner Bros. and the DCEU are in some serious trouble with GOTGV.2 performing so well. Suicide Squad desperately wanted to be like GOTG that the entire film was upended so there could be more humor added in. Not to mention the influx of classic radio hits were present throughout without any of the effort made to have the scene elevated by the usage of song choice. The rag tag bunch of losers cliché coming together for a unified effort to stop a world ending threat is nothing new but the trick always lies in the delivery. And the GOTG just inherently knows what it is and what it wants to do. The Justice League can't try to be anything other than itself and not try to force what someone else is doing. It'll always lead to failure and as someone who is a fan of comic book movies and someone who did not like Suicide Squad or Batman V. Superman: Dawn Of Justice, that isn't what I want.

It tried so hard to compete that it fell under its own hype to be merely a semblance of what it wanted to be. It may be too late for the DCEU, but GOTG came from out of nowhere with no major characters while being set in space with a talking raccoon and a tree. There is always hope that they can rebound. The DCEU shouldn't think like their the big guys on campus and no matter whatever they'll do, their shit will not stink because everyone else will just eat it up no matter what. They have to think and act like the underdogs. Robert Downey Jr. was basically cancer to Hollywood, blacklisted by everyone but a long shot turned out to be the most profitable casting decision in the history of film and kicked off one of the most impressive franchises ever. The Batman franchise was brutally eviscerated and nearly left for dead 20 years ago only to rise up like a storming phoenix from the ashes less than a decade later. If there is one rule in Hollywood, it's that you can never count anyone out.

Marvel is playing with house money now that each new weird and bizarre installment like Ant-Man, Doctor Strange, and of course Guardians Of The Galaxy have been outright successes with audiences and critics and GOTGV.2 is no different. It inherently knows how odd it is and isn't afraid to show it while reveling in its childlike antics. This is essentially part of its charm. No other comic book movie can be so goofy and dumb while showing heart and being serious all at the same time. The first installment blew away everyone's expectations to deliver an original comic book story with bizarre characters while being set in space atop a retro backdrop of music and pop culture references. The sequel had a lot to live up too, as do most with the original being so well beloved. This can harm a film drastically even before it comes out in theaters as DC can attest to that. Thankfully it delivers on all aspects to further flesh out these complex characters while introducing interesting new ones with a hefty side helping of heart, pathos, comedy, knee tapping soundtrack, dazzling special effects, and thrilling action sequences. The Guardians Of The Galaxy continue to be a shining star amid countless others of its ilk, treading its own path amid the lofty cosmos. Five games of catch with a cosmic ball and your long lost father who is a powerful super being out of five.

May 5, 2017

Supposed definition of a good Hollywood sequel: a movie that continues, rather than simply repeats, the original story and develops the characters further. If this is true, then "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2," a sequel to the much-beloved "Guardians of the Galaxy" (2014), should be considered great. Not only does it continue the original's story and expand the characters' personal stories, it does so with wit, humor, and, surprisingly, emotion. And it's real, earned emotion, not sappy or artificial. Nevertheless, fans of the first film, based on a lesser known Marvel Comics property (of course), can rest assured knowing "Vol. 2" retains the same irreverent, flippant attitude to keep things spicy and moving. It's a sequel all right, but it's fresh and exciting and not preoccupied with merely doing the same things as before.

This is all the more unexpected given how financially successful the original "Guardians of the Galaxy" was, which would make one think the studio and filmmakers would try to recreate the same magic to better ensure fan turnout, and thus, profitability. But to the credit of writer-director James Gunn and his crew, the goal seems to be creating another kind of magic, and with new, interesting characters at their disposal and new depths applied to pre-existing ones, they're able to do just that. 

Plot-wise, things more or less pick up from when we last left our squabbling interstellar friends-Peter, a.k.a. Star-Lord (Chris Pratt), a sort of Han Solo wannabe; Gamora (Zoe Saldana), a green-skinned alien with superhuman abilities; Drax (Dave Bautista), the former human turned muscle-bound being who often breaks out into uncontrollable laughter; Rocket (voice of Bradley Cooper), the competitive, foul-mouthed raccoon; and Baby Groot (voice of Vin Diesel), a talking tree with limited speech and intelligence but an undeniably adorable face (it remains a mystery to me why Vin Diesel was even cast given that his voice is so electronically manipulated, but never mind). 

After the events of the first film, this motley crew of former thieves and hunters have been charged with protecting the chaotic cosmos in various ways, shapes and forms. Their latest job finds them battling a giant, slug-like space creature in order to retrieve valuable batteries for the Sovereign race, and of course the team members are all arguing with one another about how it should be done. Peter thinks Gamora should use a sword instead of a gun; Drax thinks punching it from the inside will do the trick; Rocket thinks he has a better chance of maneuvering around the creature compared to Peter; and Baby Groot, well, he just drowns everything out while listening to E.L.O.'s "Mr. Blue Sky." This diverse unit still has a love-hate relationship, but they know, just as we do, they've become not just a protective mercenary group, but an unorthodox family.

In fact, it will be their familial ties that get tested the most as the plot continues to unfold. After the Guardians defeat the monster and deliver the batteries, the Sovereign leaders hand over Nebula (Karen Gillan), Gamora's sister, who holds a deep-rooted grudge against Gamora for not protecting her from their adopted abusive father when they were kids. Nebula vows to destroy Gamora the first chance she gets, and as if she weren't enough trouble, Rocket, for no other reason than to prove he can, actually re-steals the batteries they just returned. The Sovereigns consequently send a fleet of drones after the Guardians and nearly obliterate their ship, but they're rescued by the mysterious Ego (Kurt Russell), who reveals himself as Peter's long-lost father (his romantic affair with Peter's mother opens the film). 

Ego invites Peter, Gamora and Drax back to his paradisiacal planet and explains he's a Celestial being, or "god with a lowercase 'g'", and that Peter himself is a half-deity of sorts. What Ego ultimately has in store for his son, I'll not reveal, but Ego's pet empath, Mantis (Pom Klementieff), with her bug-like eyes and antennae, has the ability to feel what others feel, and she knows a truth about Ego that she almost reveals to Drax as they develop a relationship of their own.

Meanwhile, Yondu (Michael Rooker), the excommunicated, blue-skinned Ravager who kidnapped Peter as a child because "the boy was good for thieving," answers the Sovereigns' call to destroy the Guardians. But circumstances and changes of heart complicate matters, and it just so happens Yondu and Rocket become unlikely allies against Yondu's once-loyal band of followers. 

All of these plot threads eventually come together in a rather traditional climax, replete with all the usual battles and explosions, including an entire planet getting destroyed, but each carries its own weight, and Gunn doesn't allow any of the storylines or characters to get short-changed. He balances all the working parts exceptionally well, and as action-heavy and "comic book-ish" as it is, we become invested in the narrative on more than just a silly and funny sci-fi adventure level. We come to really care about what happens, even more than we did with the original, and respond emotionally to the characters' struggles and growth. The integrity with which Gunn treats the "light and mindless material" encourages us to not let our expectations of the genre dictate our overall impression and we appreciate "Vol. 2" as a thoroughly entertaining movie with lots of heart and intelligence.

Of course, the production values are also top-notch, although with a $200 million budget, how could they not be? It's clearly been money well spent, as the special effects in particular are right up there with "Dr. Strange," another Marvel Comics Universe entity. And for anyone who's seen "Dr. Strange," which I'm guessing will be a lot of the same people who see "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2," that's saying a lot.

If nothing else, and whether or not you're familiar with the material, the movie is just a whole lotta fun and embodies what's best about Hollywood blockbusters. Its mix of playfulness, sarcasm, emotion and romance reminded me of the first three "Indiana Jones" pictures, and just like those classics, Star-Lord and company, and the actors who play and voice them, have a lot of chemistry that makes them likable and down-to-earth. Plus, with music artists like E.L.O., Sam Cooke, Jay and the Americans, and Cat Stevens on the soundtrack, it's hard to walk away from "Vol. 2" not feeling happy. 

It's funny, but at the end of my review for the first "Guardians of the Galaxy," I commented on the idea of a sequel by writing, "I would encourage the filmmakers to combine their attitude with more depth. As amusing and appealing as the characters are, I'd personally like to see them in a more original story-one with a greater purpose. It'd be great if the filmmakers could retain the movie's current wit and audacity but expand upon the substance." I'm almost certain the filmmakers didn't read my first review, but I am certain they've answered my call.

It has been nearly three years since the first Guardians of the Galaxy surfaced, and after surprising the galaxy with a bang-up job (5 stars from me), it was foreseen in the stars a second (and now third) would/will soon follow.  The first Guardians tied loosely into the overall Marvel Universe with the Infinity Stone mostly to get everyone familiar with all the new faces we would be seeing over the next few years, but GotG2 firmly stands alone with its own conflicts and resolutions.  It has all the bright lights and flare of the first with even more colorful characters and CGI set pieces to boot.  The action is still quality and the music is still grand.  However, GotG2 lags behind its predecessor due to multiple plot threads involving nearly every character and then some. 

Chris Pratt as Peter Quill once again takes center stage as the main hero.  We got bits and pieces of his alien heritage back in the first film, but James Gunn seems to have firmly rooted the second in finding out who his father really is.  For story purposes, it is an enlightening dynamic and great added background for the character.  It ended up being the climax of the story, but I felt the movie lingered a tad too long on this thread without enough of a punch.  Kurt Russell, Ego the living planet and Quill's father (no spoilers there), gave a stoic performance as the celestial, but as is tradition in most Marvel movies, the villain lacked any real punch.  How many times have we seen a god-like being try to take over the universe with only a few added scenes thrown in for good measure to make it look like what is happening right in front of us on screen with our heroes is affecting the rest of the galaxy?  

In fact, the added side conflict with The Sovereigns, who were hilarious in their own right, and the sister-sister conflict of Gamorra and Nebula AND Rocket's internal emotional struggle AND Yondu's conflict with his own crew made the entire GotG2 feel more like a comic book with so many things going on at once rather than a traditional movie with a focused plot.   Credit is due though for at least wrapping up most of these (save one for the third film) so we aren't left waiting another two or three years for certain story lines to get resolved.

The plot convolution was really my only big gripe for this film, but enough to knock it down to 3 1/2 stars, especially when compared to other Marvel movies we've seen in the past few years.  Let's face it...all Marvel movies (except Iron Man 2 and maybe one other I can't think of) have been duds.  They continuously knock it out of the park thanks to a blossoming cast of some of the best stars (too many to name).  However, a true show stealer, Baby Groot was always going to be the one character who really suckered us into seeing this film.

GotG2 expands on its universe by including a plethora of new characters for us to get invested in and new worlds and easter eggs to recognize and look for.  Performances are beefed up but not ham-fisted.  There is a delicate balance of emotion with action and the visuals still invite you to take second and third glances.  it's just so packed with story lines, keeping track of everything in just over 2 hours makes you wish for a longer run-time.

On a single viewing from the time of this review, I would say that this movie has a TON of issues, from technical problems, to creative inconsistencies. The first 2/3's of Guardians 2 is probably some of the worst content that marvel has created in a long time. It's unfocused, poorly edited, just all over the place, and NONE of the jokes land I've never been in a comedy, with a more dead silent audience. Basically every joke is just drawing out some quirky character trait of one of the leads, and/or a really intense moment, followed by a melancholy reaction from another character, and you can see where each joke is going, a mile away. All of that could be forgiven, because humor is subjective, but I refuse to forgive the fact that the movie is so intent on distracting from the actual drama of the story, which is SO GOOD. I'll let a bad joke slide, but not when it's in the way of something that's 10000 times better. That is the first 2 acts in a nutshell.

The final third act is full of a tight, focused, emotional story, that made it VERY difficult not to tear up in the theater, and it's one of the very few movies that works with over-the-top, on-the-nose dialogue about the morals of the story, and not only does it work, i can't imagine the same movie without it. Sure, it gets kinda cheesy after the 5th time a character recites the theme to me, but I can give it a pass because of the rest of the story's effectiveness. 

In summary, if I walked in to the movie about two hours in, I'd be over the moon, raving about how brilliant this movie is, but as a 2hr 18m movie goes, there are two glaring issues, that keep me from loving this movie- Inconsistency, and most importantly, FAKE DRAMA. The drama that presents itself is SPECTACULAR, but the whole reason the drama even exists is because of an egregious moment, where the character mantis telling Drax about the true intentions of the movie's antagonist, is interrupted by something as simple as Gamora interrupting their conversation! She was GOING TO TELL DRAX, and they could've handled this LONG before all of the stakes were in place. Something so blatantly simple, stands in the way of an otherwise fantastic story! I'm so torn on how I feel about this movie, because every part of me knows that it's bad, but I can't help but feel an extreme sense of overwhelming emotions in those last 30 minutes. If I were asked, "do you recommend this movie?", then I'd have to say yes to the average person, but only a maybe to a more analytical, critical person, if given, I could tell them, "just wait."

I loved the opening few minutes. And then I felt like it was getting into typically bland Marvel movie cliche territory when the second act came along. But when the third act exploded onto the screen and was followed by a wonderful ending, I started to love it all over again. What I'm trying to say is that "Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2" has some typical and uninteresting moments within, but the insanely high highs made me forgive those parts.

To explain what those bland parts were, I'll just say that there was a couple chunks of the film in the middle that felt like things I'd seen before in every other post-Ironman superhero film. I didn't find them interesting, and I felt that there were too many hit retro songs thrown in just because people liked the soundtrack of the original. It wasn't like it became a bad movie, it just stopped being a new and creative one.

But, when I said there were insanely high highs I really meant it. For every unnecessary pop song there was a B-side gem that's lyrics and melody paired beautifully with what was happening on screen. And for every boring, Marvel-mandated plot shart, there was an eye-popping visual effect or an unexpectedly person character moment.

I don't often rewatch the superhero films that have been released in the last five years, because they're generally too formulaic for me to find anything new in a second watch through. But "Volume 2" felt different. I think it would've been better if Marvel didn't require all their films to be connected, but it still managed to stand out. And it obviously gets extra points for the Hasselhoff-related scenes.

Proper Perspective:  It is impossible to not qualify a movies quality based on the original or its predecessors, but for Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2, try to do that. The first one was lightning in a bottle and the follow-up was a ton of fun as its own movie, building on the lore and characters we were all introduced to in Vol. 1. After seeing it twice, let's talk about Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2...

Official Synopsis: Set to the backdrop of Awesome Mixtape #2, 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2' continues the team's adventures as they unravel the mystery of Peter Quill's true parentage.

Plot: Once it is revealed who Peter Quill's father is, the Guardians are split up and have to work together, through new and testing challenges that will try their will as a "family."

Take: Vol. 2 may not have the same overall sound and nostalgic pull as Vol. 1, but it is equally terrific for some of the same reasons and a few of its own new reasons. There is a lot to unpack in this movie, so how about a quick paragraph overview? Ya, okay good:

The Guardians are good guys for hire and go to protect some batteries for the Sovereign People... Then they meet Star-Lord's (Chris Pratt) father, Ego the Living Planet (Kurt Russell) and Mantis (Pom Klementieff) while unraveling the story of Star-Lord's past... The Ravagers are not happy with Yondu (Michael Rooker) so he, Rocket (Bradley Cooper), and Baby Groot (Vin Diesel) have to deal with that fun... Gamora (Zoe Saldona) and Nebula (Karen Gillan) continue their sister-ly relationship... Oh, and a dude named Taserface (Chris Sullivan) factors into all of this.

Got it?

While there are a lot of stories unfolding at once answering questions from the last movie, setting up future movies, and closing loops in this story the pacing and story unfolded great. 

James Gunn has a signature style of writing with humor, character, and depth that allows you to connect with all of the characters no matter their overall screen time. For example, in Vol. 2 Sean Gunn is in a handful of scenes, but you are invested in his arc as a Ravager that is frustrated with Yondu, but not in support of Taserface. He just wants to do the right thing.

This movie nails character. Even Taserface.

The jokes really landed in this movie as much as in Vol. 1, where the movies differ is that while the first act doubles down on the jokes, the second act is focused on building story, and there is a level of drama and heaviness that will stay with you. As much as these movies are alike they are very different. 

Great direction, awesome pacing, fantastic writing, fun characters and performances, and overall a fun time in the theaters.

Recommendation: Sure, this may not be as memorable as the first movie, but it has merit to stand on that it is an equally fun and entertaining movie. I've seen it twice, once with adults and beverages and once with my kids and both audiences loved the movie from beginning to end...

Funny, fun, action packed and colorful. Definitely worth a trip to IMAX 3D but with that being said it's a bit stilted in spots and tries to hard to be like the first one which in my opinion is a better movie. Also, the third act falls apart and gets a bit ridiculous.

Guardians of the Galaxy 2 is a crowd pleaser through and through, and there is absolutely nothing wrong with that. Following the tremendous success of the first movie, it was bound to disappoint as a superhero movie regardless of how they spun it. So instead, director James Gunn decided to focus on making people happy instead of pushing a plot. Opinions will differ on whether it was the smart move or lazy move, as well as whether it worked, but personally I think it was brilliant. If you go in wanting to learn more about MCU and how everything will set up for Infinity Wars, you will come out very disappointed. But if you just want to be entertained for 2 hours, this is the movie to watch. Light plot for the most part, funny dialogues, and parent company Disney truly showcased how far ahead they are than everyone else when it comes to special effects and visuals. Overall, Guardians 2 was a very entertaining visual feast, nothing more, but certainly nothing less.

Near the end of Guardians Vol. 2, one of the characters remarks in response to another character calling the squad his friends, that they can't be friends because of how much they yell and argue with each other. This is a fleeting moment, but it registers with me because while Vol. 2 of this nice departure of films from Marvel, advocates for the idea of family, these characters often bicker at each other almost relentlessly in these films, that when they suddenly realize they love each other, it feels half-heartedly dropped into the film. Don't get me wrong, Vol. 2 is often fun and even quite moving near its end, however, the consistent snarkiness from the cast of characters that is supposed to elicit laughs, starts feeling rather cynical after a while. The most pleasing dynamic represented in this sequel might have to be the relationship between Gamora and her fiery sister Nebula. Their relationship is fleshed out so much in this film, I wouldn't mind seeing an origin story with the two. Kurt Russell plays the father of Chris Pratt's Star Lord, and things aren't necessarily how they appear. The plot takes us to some unlikely places with their past and while Pratt sometimes struggles with the dramatic acting moments, the film finally allows for some catharsis near the end. While never as hilarious or as thrilling as the original, Vol. 2 successfully capitalizes on the success of the first. It's pretty to look at enjoyable to watch, but is occasionally diminished by the sheer harshness of the characters to each other (I'm looking at Rocket on this one). Drax nearly steals the show. Guardians...Vol. 2 will definitely please fans of the first film (i.e. basically everyone) in the irreverent space-saga. Sure, it's bigger spectacled and deeper themed, but its real strength lies in its smaller moments of character and humor. In fact, when the words being spoken aren't jokes, corny exposition and telegraphed subtext sneak to the surface ("Sometimes we don't realize what we need is right there all along."). Thankfully, director Gunn deftly redeems each less-than-stellar story moment with cheeky jokes and surprising humanity.
If the first was New Hope, then Vol. 2 is Empire, as we find Starlord (Pratt) dealing with his own daddy issues (Russell), as the universe at large is fighting a bigger (though possibly related) battle. The action scenes have cinematic flair and dramatic heft, but the charm is still 100% dependent upon its tongue being so firmly placed in its cheek in subversive and unexpected ways. The music is a smile-inducing mix of 70s and 80s power pop, Rocket is still drolly hot-headed, Drax is still hilariously literal, Baby Groot is adorably violent, and new addition Mantis fits in snugly.
So why isn't this consider among Marvel's best for me? Well, as a longtime Marvel Studios zombie, I hate to admit it, but these MCU outings are finally starting to feel a bit same-y. Lots of parental problems, brightly colored CGI, a standard build in impressive action scenes to a final with the Big Boss, all punctured with good-natured humor. Luckily, the formula is a good one, and with Guardians, what it lacks in dramatic intrigue, it makes up for with irreverence for its own seriousness, helping it stand out from the larger superhero pack.

Resisting the temptation to tinker with a winning formula and go dark or go bigger, Vol. 2 continues in the same flippant, frivolous and often very funny way as its predecessor did. Furthermore, just like Vol. 1 models after Star Wars: A New Hope and so it is that Vol. 2 has an air of The Empire Strikes Back to it  not only in its narrative structure (thank you, Bazza, for pointing that out) but also in the father/son relationship that is so central to both films (with further homages to films such as The Blob and North by Northwest for keen cinephiles out there).  I will admit that the central theme of family as people you choose to be with as opposed to those you are actually related to, is a familiar and corny one, and the story here is thin to hang a movie thats over 2hrs long on; but luckily the pacing never lacks momentum and the simpler story line means that the film has more time for character development for every member of the growing cast, with Nebula (Karen Gillan) and Yonda (Michael Rooker) in particular gaining both screen time and dimensionality to their previous simplistic villainy.  While Vol. 2 has lost the element of surprise and the underdog status that Vol. 1 made full and effective use of, it retains Chris Pratt as its charming anchor and writer-director James Gunn, who subtly yet confidently handles the well incorporated CGIs, 80s visuals and sight gags and kickass soundtrack in an intelligent and amusing way, delivering a structured and well thought out summer blockbuster that is just too joyful to resist. With that difficult second album well and truly conquered, I, for one, cannot wait for Vol. 3.

My largest example being Gamora in the "desert", sitting, and the Nebula coming to gun her down; I literally thought it was a random dream sequence at first, the way it was jumped unexpectedly to, the way it was shot, the way the colors were presented. Absolutely bizarre. 
However, past that complaint, it was good! I enjoyed it. I can't wait to see it again.

Back in 2014, not many people knew about the Guardians of the Galaxy. Many felt that it was Marvel digging at the bottom of the barrel for profit. When the film came out, people were hooked. It was a hilariously fresh take on a rag tag group of Superheroes. After the great first entry, I was hoping that the second installment would be a hit. Well personally, I feel that Vol.2 is better than the first.
This story shares a lot of similarities with Empire Strikes Back. However it does it in a way where it's not trying to copy the formula it just seems that it flowed perfectly with this universe. Much like Empire, the main characters are split up and the characters have to deal with a huge dramatic conflict. Star lord has to deal with his father, Gamora has to deal with the sibling rivalry of Nebula and Rocket is dealing with a crisis of conscience. Drax doesn't have that much of a story, however he makes up for it with the humor. A majority of the laughs comes from Drax. Baby Groot is just cute. The film does the opposite of what we expect a sequel to be which is bigger. There's not a lot of action sequences compared to the first film. It works however because of the characters, this film is more focused on building the characters backstory. The first film is really good at tugging at your heart strings. This one had me holding back my eyes from watering up. Why....because when you realize the relationship of Starlord and Yondu. You realize the expert writing of the story. In the first film, Yondu seemed like a villain, however in this film you understand the actions of that character. Growing up watching films, Michael Rooker has always been that actor that is so good that he makes himself unlikeable. My parents would always watch those back in the day Civil Rights movies and Rooker was always the go to guy for racist asshole. Rooker was just that good to play as a racist with the accent. Then I saw Henry: Portrait of a serial killer and didn't like him even more. Well finally he has redeemed himself with his portrayal of Yondu, his character is more heartfelt in this film. 
Characterization like this is the reason why not only James Gunn is the perfect director/writer for this film but it also shows how important it is to have fewer writers. So many blockbusters have more than 2 writers which causes a lot of inconsistencies.
The music as always is great. Ever since the first film, DC and other films have tried to utilize the same soundtrack formula. Taking older songs to promote their films. The reason most films and when I mean most I mean Suicide squad failed. Is due to the fact that they didn't understand the purpose behind Guardians use of the music. The mixtape songs were given to Peter by his mother. In a film that takes place across the galaxy it is great to hear familiar songs to keep us grounded. The songs were carefully picked as to what a women would listen to in the 70's and 80's. Which explains why the set list has a wide array of pop songs. Another key thing to the contemporary music is using songs that we are familiar with but haven't heard in a while. The songs are more of a B-Side that hasn't been heavily exploited in other movies or commercials. Which is why the first few minutes of Suicide Squad feels more like a top 100 commercial.
Many probably had a lot of doubt as to if this film can live up to the hype of the first film and it does...it exceeds it.

This is the first movie I really liked watching in theaters down to my core in a while. I felt like I was a kid in the 90s again, it was that good. There's something to say about Chris Pratt's acting, his innocence, badassery, and honesty. All of the actors really shined in their humor. Bravo! I love, love, loved the dynamic between Mantis and Draxe, and between Nebula and Gamora. It was crazy, I mean, I feel like the actors had fun acting, and you could tell. So, yay! I'm sure a lot of the movie was computerized, so the chemistry between the actors had to be quite real :)

James Gunn, Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana and co. return to the deepest reaches of space to bring us "Guardians Of The Galaxy Vol. 2," a worthwhile sequel that may world-build and crack wise to a definite fault, but, still - a worthwhile sequel it remains. The eye-catching visuals and infectiously entertaining set pieces will undoubtedly entertain, but as things unfurl on the narrative front, the more you may or may not start to realize just how flimsy and directionless things are this time around. Still though, there's enough charm and character in this particular piece to power through some of the slower, more aimless portions of the story at hand. Indeed, it definitely does not feature as clean and clear of a narrative as its predecessor, but this "Guardians Of The Galaxy" sequel ultimately *just* lives up to the standards set by the Marvel brand.

I felt that Marvel is pandering to a crowd that now expects these movies to be funny rather than worth a story.  It's sadly why nobody takes these movies seriously anymore. And I fear we will never get to go back to the beloved time of super hero movies that aren't cookie cutter to the same old tune.   This movie has some amazing qualities, but sadly has fallen victim to the Marvel machine, that has manufactured yet another bland, story-less, crowd pleasing carrot to feed to the starving masses they have created.

This sequel adds extra dimensions (besides the amazing 3-D, oh my god!) not only to the Guardians but for some of the "villians" of the original. The only problem: the story. Not because the plot is lame or confusing but it is abit jumbled, choppy & disjointed at times; lacking the focus, balance & urgancy of Vol.1. That being said, Vol.2 is an overwhelaming hoot, packed with so many amazing delights & top-notch surprises to care about the narrative shortcomings! - 8/10 (B+)

The Guardian's second adventure around is a subplot mosaic of familial drama crudely strung together by a larger story of universal takeover by an all-powerful space god.

More than often this makes the narrative feel like a bumpy ride at best but Marvel makes great strides to smooth things outs with extravagant set pieces and a shotgun of laughs.

GotG2 creates intrigue by juxtaposing the seemingly small nature of personal dramas and putting it on a backdrop of extraordinary scale that is the great expanse of space. The final product often finds balance within its visual ecstasy and comedic punchlines but really isn't as cohesive or funny as it believes to be.

Nevertheless it's a truly commendable entry into the MCU and refreshing in that it doesn't have the same conventional film-making issues of their other franchises.

Lots of special effects but no movie. I know that it is a superhero movie but the better superhero movies have characters with at least some depth. here is no depth in this movie. It is all surface and splash and much too long.

Thinly put together story, Not showing you anything you didn't see in the first movie movie ..the resulting mix is just ok. Even the special effects weren't very special. Underwhelming esp in light of the overachieving nature of Vol 1.

Who would have thought baby Groot could get any cuter. Not only did baby Groot get cuter, but the Guardians of the Galaxy kept their cool, their style, and that uniqueness that sets them apart from the rest of all Marvel superheroes. The Guardians of the Galaxy make a comeback with a sequel that strives to be better than it predecessor, and it succeeds, taking that working formula from the first movie, and adding a bit more whimsy and excitement on top of it.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 starts out with the Guardians on the job, as they are hired to defend valuable batteries, owned by the Sovereign Race, from being stolen. This sets the opening for the real plot, which follows Star Lord's relationship with his father, after they meet for the first time. The story develops into an interesting plot twist, when Quill needs to decide between following the family he was born in or the family he has chosen.

The story is packed with new characters and side stories. There is a lot going on for those of us foreign to the comics. However, as much as everyone would love to learn more about the background of the new characters or even the Guardians of the Galaxy, I have learned to accept this is not going to happen. There is too much information in Marvel movies already, and this would only extend the run time... by a lot. Rather, I prefer to look at what they can do with the information they give you, how good can the alternative plot lines fit into the main story, and how everything makes sense.

Looking at it in this manner, gives you a greater appreciation of the plot. Director James Gunn does an amazing job at developing the story, skipping over any serious or dull moments and challenging its audience on how much humor they can take. The film manages to be full of heart while making it clear that sentimentalism is not allowed. A film designed for everyone to have a good time.

Volume 2 follows the same recipe as the first movie: Witty and sarcastic humor, amazing visuals, and an entertaining story. It manages to go farther than the first movie in every aspect, and it is hard not to love the characterization. I don't know about you, but I cannot wait to see Groot next to Hulk or Rocket next to Iron Man. There is no doubt that Guardians of the Galaxy is a beautiful addition to the Marvel universe, and Volume 2 just made it even better.
The movie was as great as the the first and more.

With the first Guardians of the Galaxy I went (or at least wanted to go) into the film with little to no expectations. Of course, with Vol. 2 it would be next to impossible to do the same unless one had skipped the first which, of course, would then only mean it would be next to impossible to fully understand or better yet, appreciate, what this second film has to offer. And so, despite having some expectation for Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 there wasn't much beyond suspecting that writer/director James Gunn might hand pick a new list of late seventies/early eighties hits to set something of a remixed version of the original's events to while pushing whatever story points the Marvel overlords needed pushed forward. If this sequel teaches us anything though (and it does try to teach if not at least say something significant) it's that sometimes expectations aren't detrimental to the overall effect a piece of art can have. That's right-I'm calling a Marvel movie, and Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 specifically, a piece of art as well as stating that it surpasses all expectations. I'm saying this loud and clear because I feel like it would be easy to think otherwise about the rather unconventional super hero movie that Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 actually is. It seems it might be easy to be disappointed in the sequel because it doesn't exactly fit into the conventions we've become conditioned to expect. How does Guardians numero dos buck this trend that Marvel has so perfectly perfected as of late? Well, the first thing it changes is that of setting up a convenient villain in the form of another Thanos crony looking for world domination (Gunn literally thought bigger this time, going for galactic domination) while also giving our heroes a real and emotional investment in the plight of the antagonist. Sure, the film opens with the guardians on a for hire mission that sees them doing battle with a large CGI monster for the purposes of getting paid handsomely by a race of snobby and rather pretentious Goldfinger/Goldmember lookalikes, but this is essentially only a framing device and reason to usher Michael Rooker's Yondu back into the fray. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is instead mostly about the relationships between the members of the titular team and developing those dynamics in exchange for progressing the overall Marvel arc. Where Vol. 2 really exceeds though, is in balancing the exploration of these relationships with that of still telling an effective story, the guardians story, and there's just something special about a ginormous, big-budget, special-effects extravaganza that feels this personal.

Engaging and well thought-out further character development on this one.  I see a lot of critics trying to pan this; claiming that the banter between the core group is lacking, but they're wrong.  The core group is a family now so the bickering and the back-and-forth is not only expected but kind of priceless.  Tons of effort has gone into the visuals for this film, so much so that I defy you to watch this and find any scene that's not interesting to look at...James Gunn has knocked it out of the park with this and this move deserves a stack of awards!  HIGHLY recommended!
Just as fun as Volume 1, but with the added character development.  Great fun!!

GROOT & ROCKET ARE BACK!!!!! Oh...&...the other guys...of course.

GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY VOL. 2

Where to start? Oh, I know, the music, IT'S FLIPPIN' AWESOME!!! The soundtrack was mainly songs from the '60s '70s & early '80s, pretty much the only music I grew up with, plus a couple newer songs which fit in pretty well with the rest!

The plot is perfect, nothing felt out of place! Everything that's set up early in the film has a purpose (purpose being the overall theme of the story). The happy moments, the sad moments, the comedy, drama, action, & truly human moments, even what some might consider forced exposition (which it wasn't); it all flowed into the narrative, like a river.

The actors & their characterization were great! Everyone played their part spot on, while providing new insight into them, as much as I cared for these characters, they got me to care for them even more!

The action was great! Space battles, shoot'em up style fights, hand to hand combat, & stuff I can't get into without spoiling things. Everything is paced well, so folks can have a break between action sequences, so it feels less...relentless.

The effects were a perfect blend of crystalline CGI, & practical makeup & sets that, combined with the acting, made everything feel so real, I half expected to see starships flying overhead instead of planes as I walked out've the theater.

5 stars out of 5, I felt so many different emotions throughout the course of this film, & I was never bored. It held my attention during even the quiet moments. And it made the original GotG film look like Fant4stic. I am not recommending this film to anyone, I am telling everyone, you NEED to see this film, what ever your taste is, it has something for all of you; it's better than Avengers!!!!
I am Groot! I am Groot, I am Groot and I am Groot. I am Groot I am Groot, I am Groot! I am Groot...

One thing this movie did right was the comedy. Thats the only consistent thing with Marvel these days though. First of all, when the Guardians are running from the gold people (not sure their species so im calling them that), they chase them through an asteroid field. In the field, the Guardians and the Gold People are about the same speed. However, when they get out, some of them went around the field. Not only did they catch up, but they also passed them. If they are faster then the Guardians, how did the ones in the field not catch them? When Ego destroyed all of the ships, that raises another question. How did he find them in that exact position? Space is MASSIVE, the chances of running into them is next to 0. Sure, hes a God, but the only powers he exhibited is the ability to manipulate reality, and know what happens on his own planet. How would he know where to find them? The fact they defeat Ego with a bomb made in 2 minutes, Ego telling Peter that HE gave her Cancer, the old trope where the villian has to kill them AS SLOWLY AS HE POSSIBLY CAN, WHICH ENDED UP LEADING TO HIS DEATH. The introduction of Peter's powers then just getting rid of them at the end, underplaying everyone but Peter, the fact that Peter is not only half of his fathers species, which should logically mean Peter's powers would be weaker, but the fact that Ego has had MILLIONS of years to master his powers yet gets beaten by someone who should only have half of his powers, but also JUST learned how to use them properly, all make me dislike this movie. A lot.

This movie provides the spunk of the first while still capitalizing on the same fun cast, with some nice side characters like Mantis and Yondu. Another nice feature of this movie is how central the theme of family is, making it relatable, yet at times it seems like a bit forced. Overall a good movie with another great soundtrack.

Exceedingly fun and entertaining, this sequel is more of what I thoroughly enjoyed about the first. Moreover, it layers in some great character development. We get a bit more of Quinn's origin story. And you get enough heart out of what's going on, you even start to care about some of the bad guys. And what can I say about the special effects, except utter perfection. And that's actually where we lose the half star. There's so much, at times it feels like animation, and so much so certain scenes are too unrealistic. But, this movie, much like it's predecessor is among the best examples of why I love cinema.

This sequel spends no screen-time re-establishing plot or character information from the first installment. It's just as visually inventive, almost to the point of overstimulation, in some moments. The new characters acquit themselves well - not an easy thing, to find the right tone in this unique kind of space adventure. The original cast's chemistry, the pop soundtrack, and the comedy are all as strong or stronger than before. In fact, this plays like the second act in what could potentially be a seamless trilogy. I trust director Gunn to stick the landing. This may not be quite as strong as Vol. 1, but I expect it will be more rewarding to re-watch.

The formula for great sci-fi movies is simple: Interesting characters, awesome spaceships, creative worlds, massive action, multi-dimensional plot. This movie delivers in every category.

This sequel runs into the problems that often plague the second film of highly successful franchises. It retraces the successful terrain of the first, but in a less organic form of storytelling which comes across as forced. It also re-tells some of the most popular jokes, with less impact. The last pitfall is making the visual effects "bigger and better," but they are less important to the story and becomes more of a spectacle for its own sake. This film also had an emphasis on the theme of family and reconciliation, which in and of itself is a noble topic. However, like much of the film this storyline seemed (at least at times) heavy handed. Let's hope they overcome these pitfalls for the third movie.

GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY: VOL. 2-2017(PG-13)-May 6.
By:Clem The Movie Guy.

That lovable band of outcast heroes is back in the sequel to the 2014 smash hit Guardians of the Galaxy. Set to the backdrop of Awesome Mixtape #2, Guardians of the Galaxy: Vol. 2 finds Peter Quill/Star Lord (Chris Pratt), Gamora (Zoe Saldana), Drax (Dave Bautista), Rocket (voiced by Bradley Cooper), & Baby Groot (voiced by Vin Diesel) hired by the Sovereign race to battle an inter-dimensional monster in defense of precious batteries. When Rocket pockets a few of the batteries, the Sovereigns, on command of their leader, Ayesha (Elizabeth Debicki,) take relentless pursuit. When the team crash-lands on a nearby planet, they are rescued by Ego (Kurt Russell), a god-like Celestial & his pet empath, Mantis (Pom Klementieff). Ego reveals himself to be Peter's long-lost father & escorts Peter, Gamora, & Drax to his distant planet, while Rocket & Groot remain behind to fix the ship & keep watch on Gamora's jealous sister Nebula (Karen Gillan.) Unexpectedly they are captured by former greater Ravager community member Yondu Udonta (Michael Rooker) & his crew. Back on Ego's planet, Gamora begins to suspect something isn't quite right with Ego. When they learn the truth, the Guardians must once again save the galaxy from destruction. James Gunn returns as writer & director, & although the original Guardians was a much better film, has still made a ridiculously exciting & wildly funny summer film. The performances from the cast were solid while the cameos by well-known stars left me wondering what the point of their being the film. SEE THIS FILM in 2D, 3D, & IMAX 3D & stay for five post credit scenes.

Man is it hard to come back with a sequel that rocks just like the original, but Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2 comes pretty darn close.  The first one was so much fun with the humor and  soundtrack (and  no need to tell an origin story) it really surprised us all.  What made the first one so good though was it had all the good and did it with true emotion as well.  Volume 2 has the jokes, the action and yes some good emotion, but this time the emotion feels a little forced, or maybe not as genuine.  The first act of the film is top notch, second act drags some, and the third act falls in between.  I enjoyed the fact that Marvel still made this a stand alone film, and didn't feel like it was necessary to do some huge Avengers tie in with it.  The soundtrack once again is top  notch, and the little Baby Groot almost steals the entire movie.  If you enjoy these movies, this is a must see.
While it was enjoyable for the most part it still remains passable as whole.
With a mediocre and rushed story, crass humor, and a lack of energetic acting, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 hits a whole new low for Marvel's live action films.

What seems to be a growing trend within the Marvel Cinematic Universe is a feeling of apathy towards the final showdown in each film. The stakes don't feel high. Here we see our quipping heroes return and battle an entire planet, and yet, the suspense is just not there. While the characters are as fun and memorable as before, and the directing is fine and beautiful, the story feels tired and formulaic and lacks the ingenuity the first film brought. Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 is a fine film that will delight fans, but showcases that bigger isn't always better.

*sigh* i wasn't a fan of vol. 1, definitely not a fan of vol 2.  way too much character development of peter quill (star lord), some of that could have been chopped out.  there were attempts to be dramatic in the dialogue when there really shouldn't have been.  drax was overly dramatic and it came off corny.  baby groot was cute, he came out kicking ass and dancing.  i will definitely say the second half of the movie was better than the first.  if you've seen the movie, then you know what the turning point is and where it gets real.  that's when i finally perked up from a slight slumber.  i hated to see the downfall of yondu.  i didn't like him in vol 1., from the get go of vol 2 he was painted as the bad guy yet again, when in reality, he was actually doing the right thing, but it was too late.
I couldn't have asked for a better movie even though the whole movie plot was spoiled when I found out Kurt Russel was playing Ego.

Exactly as expected, Guardians v2 delivered all the explosions, oddly interspersed witty banter, toilet humor (literally), forced awkwardness (thank you Drax) that we wanted. Some of the jokes felt a little forced this time around, but I wouldn't let that distract you from the rest. There's some deep character development (for a superhero movie, anyway) that adds a somber aspect to the ridiculousness.

Loved GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY VOL 2 today-- a strong sequel that goes into family disfunction and the communities one makes to make life better. Special mentions for Kurt Russell and his easy charm (remember what his name is and some of the film makes more sense) and Dave Bautista as the literal Dax--hilarious and emotive. See it!
