At the end of the day, I ask myself, "was I entertained?".  Yes, I was absolutely entertained.  
That being said, I was disappointed.  The first movie was focused, funny, and fairly original.  This second installment falls victim to cliche and story lines already seen in other superhero movies.  
The biggest strength of the film is the script.  Where movies like Star Trek Beyond made you feel like they were putting in one-liners just for the sake of it, 95% of the one-liners in GOTGV2 were spot-on, from all characters.  
The biggest weakness of the film was the story line.  I wish Rocket had stolen something of a bit more consequence to make Ayesha attack with such vengeance.  And the Egos storyline was just cliche.  The scenes in his homeplanet showing the "scenes" of how he met Peter's mother were lifted straight out of Man of Steel.  The climactic scene at the end was no different than the totally bombastic and over-the-top scene with Dormamu in Dr. Strange.  
So, was I entertained?  Heck ya.  Would I go back to the theater to see it"  Absolutely.  But it's far from a perfect film.

Forgetting everything that made the first film so enjoyable, Guardians 2 is a mess. From the boring plot to the underwhelming character arcs; the cheap excuses for humor to the underwhelming action sequences; from the tone deafness to the occasionally cringe-worthy moments of "heartfelt" dialogue. While exceptionally well directed with great cinematography and shot composition, the film was boring because there was nothing I could relate to, no character or point in the plot where I was able to engage myself. If I could love a movie entirely based on the technical aspects, this would be a definite five stars. But for the many, many faults, I can't give it anything more than a middling grade.

The first Guardians of the Galaxy took on a huge risk, it was introducing this entirely new and wacky cast of characters in this expansive universe of even more colorful creatures and locations when compared to it's earlier Marvel counterparts. If that movie flopped, the idea of introducing the cosmos and celestial elements of the Marvel universe might have been abandoned. Thankfully, it succeeded with flying colors and became my favorite Marvel movie thus far. It's sequel however, doesn't hold up the same. While the action, visual effects, music, and humor were all present and in full force just like the first film, this sequel has some issues. The pacing, the story line, over acting in some places, the execution was just not on point and the movie did not flow the same as the original. As someone who fully engrosses themselves in movies as much as I can, I found myself being thrust out of my immersion due to choppy execution or long sections with little purpose. The fun and exciting and humorous parts of Guardians of the Galaxy are still here though, which makes it just enough to get a passing grade. This is not a flop by any stretch but it is a far cry from a great Marvel movie.

James Gunn crams it all in a planet with Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2.

Jumping across the universe at a lengthy 2 hours and 15 minutes, the film delivers humor and action in heavy doses, which leaves the plot details a little light.  While a little simplified at times, the story has more than enough from start to finish, and well through the closing credits, to leave an amusing after taste.

Like much of the film, the action is heavily reliant on CG.  The colors are vibrant which does wonders for the eyes.  Possibly seeming over reliant on the CG, Guardians of the Galaxy manages to hold everything together without getting caught up in the visual spectacle.

Chris Pratt is the life of the film.  Zoe Saldana continues to fill the shoes of Gamora.  Dave Bautista, Karen Gillan, and Michael Rooker benefit from much more time and dialogue in the story.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 molds together into a successful adventure in the cosmos.

For those who are waiting for Marvel Studios to drop the ball and make a completely terrible movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, get ready to keep waiting.  Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 picks up right where the first film left off.  It has a very similar feel, as it blends fun action and adventure with a fair amount of comedy and some classic songs.  You can tell that the same writer/director took the helm because James Gunn made it all cohesive with the stories and characters that were established in the first movie.  While I dont think I liked this movie quite as much as the first, it was pretty close, and my opinion might improve when I see it again.

Aside from the pure and simple fun brought from the action and comedy, what impressed me so much about Guardians 2 is all the character development they pulled off.  There are 9 different characters who all show some growth as the movie progresses, and yet it never felt cluttered or bloated.  The mistake of including too many characters has been an infamous pitfall for so many comic book movies in the past, but this film just proves it can be done with a good script and solid actors.  I have no complaints about any of the cast, they all deliver even when some of them are forced to play against type for select scenes.

Ill willingly admit that there were two flaws I saw in Guardians 2.  First was an odd feeling that James Gunn didnt trust his audience enough.  Character motivations were spelled out for the audience, plans were all articulated verbally, even some relationships are vocalized instead of experienced.  More subtlety was called for because we could have figured things out for ourselves. The other flaw is the relative predictability of the plot. Once things get in motion you can see where they are going. There were a few events that surprised me, particularly one at the very end, but there isn't much I'd call unexpected. The movie follows a familiar formula. 

Those things didn't bother me all that much, though. Perhaps I'm just an easy mark, but I forgave any minor transgressions in Guardians because I was smiling and laughing through so much of it (and even crying once.) The effects were second-to-none to the point where I never even thought about the fact that Groot and Rocket weren't really there. The IMAX looked great, and this movie might have had the best 3-D I've ever seen in a movie that was converted (not filmed) in 3-D. The Guardians of the Galaxy might be the oddest group of characters that Marvel has brought to film, but they also seem to be some of the best. I wanted to watch it again almost immediately after leaving the theater.

Overall I had lots of fun but there were just a few issues with Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2. Let's do Pros and Cons.

This storyline was near-perfect and drastically cleaned up a lot of the problems I had with its  predecessor (which I was quite ambivalent towards). I was disappointed in the lack of Thanos, the ho-hum storyline of family strife between Gamora and Nebula, and Rocket taking on a presence that was more annoying than funny. However, these shortcomings were made up with a major improvement in humor from Drax, a plot that was willing to take risks, and an overall solid story direction - all aspects I missed in the first installment.

The first Guardians movie was one of the biggest gambles for the new Marvel Studios. Its success put the "universe" in "Marvel Cinematic Universe." With Volume 2, the story trades in the cosmic scope of the story into a more personal one, albeit no less planetary. Each of the Guardians gets many moments to shine. I was pleasantly surprised at the hilarity of Drax; unburdened from his blind quest for vengeance that ended in the first Guardians, Drax exposes a gleeful side that makes his rage in the first Guardians all the more tragic. 

But at the end, it's about Peter Quill meeting his father, and about what it means to be a dad. The cameos alone are worth the price of admission, and this is a space opera sequel that combines elements of both Empire Strikes back and Wrath of Khan.

Guardians of the Galaxy vol 2 presents itself as a great transitional film to the obvious next sequel. It's not as iconic as the first film since by now we recognize the banter and raw characters that are trademark of a James Gunn film, it still proves to be entertaining if you don't hate predictable formulas. This movie provided the development for plenty of major and minor characters and still felt crammed into a two hour movie. Backstory was thrown in and dialogue mentioned cool stories we never got to see. There was plenty of time made for unnecessary moments that didn't push forward the plot, but these scenes add personality to a Gunn film rather than the standard marvel plot line which is what makes GOTG movies their own standard. There was still plenty of suspense to make up for the lack of action sequences and exciting set up for the next movie. Though it was disheartening for the (spoiler) new guardian Yandu to self-sacrifice, and for Peter to quickly lose his unseen before god-like powers, there is enough that happened in this movie to affect the next one, making this one a must see for fans of the guardians
It was a lot of fun to watch and was very funny

Most of the comedy diminishes any sense of uneasiness you had previously. I advise you to watch this only if you're fan of Marvel, otherwise, there's no enjoyment.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 was AWESOME!!!

Not as good as the first, but still very good and hugely enjoyable. 
The only problem with this film is that it's trying too hard to be funny, so much so that Drax is entirely reduced to comic relief. Baby Groot fairs only slightly better by having one key plot scene in an otherwise cutesy comedic role. 
The use and expansion of the characters Nebula and Yondu are welcome, bringing a little gravity to the film which also seems to be readying Nebula for her important role in Infinity War. Mantis too is a welcome addition, even if she's mostly just a comedic foil for Drax. 
The rest of the film is good and despite my complaints, I did find myself laughing out loud through much of the film.

John Wenzel, from the Denver Post, said he hopes volume 3 captures the first film's heart, because this one was "hollow". That fool is smoking ALL of Denver's weed. You can't GET more heart than this movie had. What an absolute moron. I don't even know what people are looking for anymore and I can't believe people are saying this isn't as good as the first one. The first one was good SOLELY because of the 5 main characters. The plot and the villain were TERRIBLY weak. This, however, was basically like an origin story in the form of a sequel and paid off things from the first movie in a truly touching and fun way.

The continuing adventures of Marvel's raggiest, taggiest team of interstellar misfits. This one picks up right where the first volume left off, with the gang collecting bounties from odd alien races, taking missteps (and making enemies) despite themselves. I loved the first one, consider it one of the best the MCU has to offer, and this sequel is right on the same level. Unabashedly chaotic, recklessly entertaining, cheeky and silly, emotive and sweet, it touches many of the same nerves that made the original so well-liked and even goes a step or two further. Given such a quirky, offbeat opening take, there's always the risk that sequels will come off as forced or derivative, but that isn't the case here. The humor still feels sharp and appropriate, the core cast shares the camaraderie (and constant personality clashes) of a real family, the greater universe remains intensely deep and well-populated. And there's still plenty of time to develop ancillary characters, be they new foils or uneasy old allies. In fact, one such dose of potent character development efficiently shifts a minor player from the first act into a significant part of the story this time around. Quick with wit and with the cannons, never afraid to let its inner weirdness shine like a beacon, brimming with vibrant life in every scene, it's vast and rich and sprawling and completely enjoyable. Guardians Volume 2 made me thoroughly happy. How long until the next one?

Updated thoughts after a recent re-watch (2018):
Just as loose and entertaining as the original, though less tentative, no longer compelled to prove itself as a viable, if offbeat, property. In other words, Volume 2 is free to let its freak flag fly, to fully embrace its inner weirdness. And wow, what vibrant, colorful, unimaginably rich spoils it reaps. Each setting feels unique and cultured, from sleazy ice brothels to the ornate, richly detailed architecture and stunning, unexpectedly lively landscapes found upon Ego, the living planet. It's a visual feast, backed by another groovy, excellent soundtrack, finely-tuned comedic timing and a sweet, resonant set of character studies. Tons of fun to watch, impossible to hear without shaking a hip, meaningful and memorable from a long-term storytelling perspective. An impressive step up from what was already one of my favorite films in the MCU.

While this sequel doesn't have quite the charm and fast pace the first film had, it is still fun, zany, and loaded with humor and 80s pop culture references. The main theme is family and while Quill bonds with his celestial dad, the rest of the team tries to figure out their own place within the group. The story gets tangled up in a lot of family drama this time around, but writer/director James Gunn fills those moments with some crazy space action. The subplot with the gold people was unnecessary and only served to add more action the climax. The soundtrack is once again an awesome mix, the opening credits is a crowd pleaser and Baby Groot is going to sell a lot of toys.  Chris Pratt seemed more subdued this time around. Dave Bautista and Bradley Cooper get most of the funny lines, but it is Kurt Russell and Michael Rooker who steal the show. Yondu's story arc and the final 15 minutes is what elevates this movie and gives it weight. James Gunn knew we were all going to stay during the end credits, so he gave us a lively end credit sequence. Finally, end credits worth sitting around for. VOL. 2 is a fun sequel that expands on its characters, gives the best Stan Lee cameo ever, and maintains most of that off-beat quirkiness we fell in love with the first time around. 

Grade: B+

For me, GotG 1 was good. Vol. 2 was great. True, the plot's weak, but the abundance of character development and chemistry between the actors more than made up for it. (I bawled for the entire last ~10 minutes of the movie, and spurted out a few more tears during the first after-credit scene). Newcomer Pom Klementieff was pretty great as well. The comedy was a tiny bit forced at times, but didn't detract from the movie at all - and this is coming from somebody who doesn't enjoy comedies!

With its great humor, stellar action, surprisingly emotional twists, and gorgeous effects, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2 is by far the best MCU sequel not having Captain America in the title. Dave Batista as Drax was by far the funniest of the Guardians with his deadpan way of talking as well as his fits of laughter when he finds something funny. Peter Quill's development continues as, and we learn a surprising fact about his parentage.  This is one of those movies where giving a five star review as the plot is a bit thin and simplistic, but the characters and the meaning of what family is brings it all together and the glue that makes this a movie a strongly recommend. Even if your not a super hero fan, this movie will have you excited, laughing and even crying at the end of its emotional climax. Go see this film. Its a perfectly fun filled time! ^^

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" (2017) - 5/10 - or 8/10 if you like the first one, or big superhero movies in general
I stopped watching mainstream superhero movies in 2013 and have mostly avoided them ever since.
They offer nothing to me personally and I'm honestly surprised at their huge commercial and critical success, given that almost all of them are just more of the same, copying the genre trailblazers such as original X-Men" and Iron Man".
I don't have the time nor energy to still watch the same thing over and over again after 15 years or so. How many times can you enjoy watching two guys hurl through air, repeatedly punching each other, for example?
There are some exceptions to this of course (Logan") but superheroes nowadays are better off in TV or streaming series such as Luke Cage" where the makers get the chance to put freshness and depth on the table.
The first Guardians of the Galaxy" collected over 770 million dollars from the cinemas in 2014, so the sequel is, of course, very similar. A true-blood superhero movie, just like the grandmother used to make.
It's loud, brash, full of colors and explosions and always ready to gently tease about superhero and sci-fi movies' tired cliches, without bringing anything to replace them.
Yes, the result is full of energy" and much fun", but if you don't particularly care about the paper-thin characters or picturebook world they inhabit, it's difficult to hold interest after 30 minutes or so.
And how can one care if there's never even a slight feeling that any big character is really in danger, no matter how large the explosions and enemy guns! It's all sound and fury, signifying nothing, as the late great Shakespeare would say.
The story is trivial as expected and thus would work better in small doses... but the movie format is much more profitable, so we get about 140 minutes in a row.
Nevermind that there's maybe 90 minutes worth of story here, every self-respecting Hollywood epic must last over two hours. I am Groot!

Vol. 2 is a sequel that builds off of the groundwork laid by the first film. Gunn has fleshed out all his characters further and kind of gets to push the restart button with Groot with nods to the first film specifically Groot and Drax's relationship. Some aspects and songs are better in the from the original film, but in other respects this film manages to reach in better levels of emotional pull. There's a more emotional villain, deeper relationships to delve into, and plenty of beautiful space battles to enjoy. I'm not sure yet where I would rank this in the Marvel Cinematic universe yet, but it delivers so much fun, action, and packs an emotional pack that it is among the best for sure. All the original cast is marvelous and it is great fun to see Kurt Russell make his presence felt, but for me the driving force of the film is Michael Rooker's Yondu.

Sequels always seem to be hit or miss and Guardians Vol 2 for me was a hit... for the most part.  The characters are what make these movies and they were once again terrific in the sequel.  They all had their amusing moments and Gamora was given more to do which made her an improvement over the first Guardians and Yondu was surprisingly good as well.  The story was was simple and easy to see where it was heading but the way there was entertaining.  Special effects?  The best of course.  Humor?  Part of the reason the first film was among my favorite Marvel films was the jokes and banter between the Guardians and this sequel increased that... which in this case was a mixed bag.  While plenty of the jokes hit the issue for me was that there were so many of them.  Rapid fire they often came, joke, joke, joke.  Sometimes got in the way of everything else, wanted to see characters breathe or more world building and constant joke cracking got in the way of that.  Emotional moments also were dead weight for me for the most part like the attempt to tug on the heartstrings with the relationship of Starlord with Ego and Yondu.  Really didn't work for me.

Still, the positives certainly outweighed my issues with Vol 2, while this won't be on my Top Ten list this year unlike the original back in 2014, it will get an 7/10* and is a solid sequel.

The short of it is, if you enjoyed Guardians of the Galaxy, Vol 1, you're very likely going to enjoy Vol 2.
Most know why Vol 1 faired so well, because like Ant Man, the MCU has been able to take obscure characters and stories, and breath colorful and engaging life into them. Some recent comic-based movies have taken too many liberties with their IP (or overthought them), while Marvel Studio has found a seemingly perfect balance of respecting IP and carefully crafting their own narratives; and this is very true for GotG Vol 2. While I'm not a huge comic book reader anymore, I do enjoy reading about character background while waiting for a comic movie's release. I've found that most of the changes, or added story that Marvel, or in this case James Gunn, have made are both equally respectful and creatively cautious with their IP.
Vol 2 has everything you'd expect from a GotG sequel: comedic antics, perfect choreography, amazing visuals, exciting action and appropriate drama; James Gunn even knows how to handle a believable romance. There's only one real cringe worthy scene in my view, it's all of ten seconds long and some might not even find it that cringy - it's a somewhat "playful" interaction between Starlord and a relative and was either meant to be sarcastic or ended up a little unbelievable.
Nothing about this movie was a letdown and while some reviews seem as though this movie missteps at times or runs too long, I wonder how they felt about Vol 1? This movie is on the upper half of the best MCU movies. I'd suggest they watch the movie again, stop over-analyzing it and just enjoy one of the best cinematic experiences they'll have this year.

The Guardians of the Galaxy sub-franchise of Marvel's behemoth cinematic universe continues to stand as their finest and most unique work, solidified now by the utter blast that is Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2. There's still some lingering problems that plague the other movies of the MCU - namely, some humor that just doesn't hit at all, although perhaps that's just inevitable with such a huge influx of it - but in essentially every other aspect, this is a nice change of pace for the formula we've come to expect from Marvel. With all of the character introductions out of the way, James Gunn focuses now on individual character arcs and relationships, and does a solid job of making sure every character has something to do. There's a mighty large cast of characters to juggle at this point, but every one of them has a reason to be involved in the plot, and have meaningful closures for their arcs by the film's end. Even the smallest of characters, like Sean Gunn's Kraglin,have key moments and feel very much welcome in the overarching scheme of things. Baby Groot is probably the single exception to this rule, as yes, he's here mostly for comedic relief and the obvious cute factor, but even he never feels like a blatant merchandising ploy.

As far as the actual plot goes, it's perhaps the deepest we've seen in the franchise. With Peter Quill and crew coming across the enigmatic Ego, there's all kinds of discussion of family, beyond the idea of a close-knit group of friends being "family", fatherhood, and life and death. It's easy to compare it to something like The Empire Strikes Back, as the second entry in a space fantasy franchise that deals primarily with a complicated father-son relationship, and the comparison isn't necessarily invalid, but perhaps the biggest similarity between the two is the focus on emotion and character more than anything else. For all the huge action setpieces and colorful new vistas (it's admittedly nice to see a Marvel with such a wide color palette and distinct visual flair), Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is, simply, a movie. A very well-crafted movie, with a director who has such clear passion for these utterly lovable characters, working with a cast of wonderful actors having the time of their lives playing them. In the ever growing MCU, where every film feels hopelessly tied to one another in some way, it's nice to see a movie that's sole focus is to tell a meanwhile story that stands so strongly on its own. Like the opening song in the film, the skies are looking nice and clear for Mr. Gunn's next endeavor in this universe.

What a difference a sequel makes. Instead of just being like the first installment and solely offering a "good time" on the big screen while jettisoning everything else, James Gunn and co. offer more warmth and more character to go along with the jokes. The viewers can invest in these people and their stories more because more time and care are given to the characters' subplots and their weaknesses. While the jokes are flying fast at the audience, as many (or more) of them fall far from the mark as the ones that do make theatergoers chuckle; most of them worked for me, however. David Bautista, Pom Klementieff, and (especially) Michael Rooker bring joy and life to their roles with excellent performances, whereas Chris Pratt and Bradley Cooper are mostly relegated to utilizing their comedic talents. Unfortunately, that leaves Zoe Saldana's Gamora with little to contribute aside from helping Nebula's (played by Karen Gillen) subplot and stoking the "will they/won't they" fire opposite Pratt's Quill/"Star Lord." I did not necessarily find Baby Groot to be as delightful or engaging as the trailers indicated, but at least it did not get as far as annoying, either. Most of the flick's problems are similar to the original movie's issues -
 clumsy storytelling. In the first movie, we dealt with one incomprehensible/confusing and forgettable storyline, but in this film, we have THREE (and honestly, the one about the Sovereigns' and Ayesha's subplot should have been cut). In the end, though, those good elements make this a more successful film than the first volume for me.

This is the first marvel movie to make me laugh so hard I cried and it was almost the first to make me actually cry, but that doesn't mean it's the best. For all the jokes and fun, this one had so much character development that, at times, it felt a bit bloated.

With that being said, I'm not sure what else they could have done without completely rewriting the plot.

Of the three sets of character arcs that dominate this movie - Peter Quill's, Rocket/Yondu's, and Gamora/Nebula's - only one could have been cut without making the plot nonsensical: Gamora and Nebula's. However, the drama between these two sisters focuses on Thanos, their father. The next time we're going to see the Gaurdians for a full movie is in Infinity Wars, where they fight Thanos. Given that the main cast for that monolith will be in the double digits, most of the characters need have their arcs finished before we get there and thus was the sister's plot necessary from a greater universe standpoint. Plus, it is legitimately interesting so, while I would have preferred to have it held off for another movie, I don't regret that it was in this for any reason beyond pacing issues.

None of that means that I wouldn't recommend this movie. I saw it with 10 other people and all of us loved it. It's just got some flaws that bare pointing out so that you don't set your expectations too high. If you enjoyed the first one, then you'll enjoy this, too.

Since the soundtrack of the first Guardian's movie is more ionic than the soundtrack of some musicals, I'm sure many will be curious if the sequel maintained earworm status. After much debate, I've decided that it did. While every song in the first movie felt perfectly chosen, there were several in this one that just felt okay. However, the songs that did work, worked far better than any of the ones in the first movie. Nothing from volume one made it onto my playlist while I've already listed to tracks from volume two multiple times.

Solid Sequel that Builds the Franchise 

The first GoTG was a fresh mix of fun irreverence, action, interesting characters, and and both eye and ear candy. The second movie keeps all of those, adds an engaging new character, Mantis, and delivers an engaging and emotional story line that sets up the next installment. 

I thought some of the crude humor and language was gratuitous, unlike the first (Jackson Pollock reference for example), but this is what Hollywood does. 

Ego, played by Kurt Russell, was a winner, and the "young Ego" was done brilliantly. The back story of Ego is worth paying attention to, and adds complexity that was not obvious; which is refreshing as story lines are so often dumbed down so much. 

Peter Quills character gets the development it needs, as do Gamora and Nebula. Yondu, a character that seemed too complex for the role in the first movie becomes the emotional center of the second, and cements the Ravagers as a deep well of future characters. 

Bottom line, go see this movie, and if you never saw the first one, view it before you see the second. This movie is equal to the first, and will leave you hungry for number three.

Possibly, the most difficult kind of sequel is one that follows a surprise hit. Three years ago, few people had ever heard of Star-Lord, including those within his own movie. Who knew this reluctant group of heroes consisting of an egocentric womanizer, a green assassin, a wisecracking raccoon, a tri-syllabic tree, and a giant with autism could win moviegoers' hearts...and pockets? If the first movie had a theme, it was selflessness from selfishness. If Guardians of the Galaxy 2 has a theme, it is that family is thicker than blood. I cannot say much more without giving away some significant spoilers, but know that though the movie is not as big of a surprise as the original, it has just as big of a heart...and brain. In fact, you could say the two are at odds with one another at times, but nevertheless, the whole movie pushes the right buttons. It is as humorous and touching as the original and well worth a second trip to the stars?and the Cineplex.        A -

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 1 was a summer surprise; I didn't even know about the characters before I came to know about the flick.  The movie was loads of fun, visually spectacular and never felt like a drag. Unfortunately, the same can't be said about the sequel. While Vol. 1 did create a standard that is hard to match, it felt like its successor didn't even try. I totally get how the movie tried to make us connect to the characters down to a personal level, and it deserves brownie points for that. But that shouldn't be an excuse for a weak plot and a lacklustre villain who never seemed very menacing. The pace, the urgency and an entirely goofy plan to solve problems which worked hilariously well - all of what made Vol. 1 such a success are thoughtlessly missing. Yes, one can argue that the moviemakers don't have to resort to the same gimmicks to make things work, but they should have at least come up with something better if not equally enthralling. Instead, Vol. 2 became a mishmash of character and team building whose sole purpose is perhaps to make them fit in the upcoming Infinity War. Not a total letdown, the sequel does have its moments, but it felt more like a placeholder than a good movie on its own accord.

Whilst not quite reaching the heartfelt and well earned heights of the original, James Gunn' s more stylised secondary volume in the Guardians franchise seeks nobly to expand its universe with an intriguing story arc, powerful character developments and a dynamic visual galore. The evolution of the characters and most importantly the journey of the main protagonist Peter quill (Pratt) works with the same enthused wonder of the first instalment. But whether or not the underwhelming soundtrack, CGI saturated scenes or forced melodramatic character interactions are to blame, the sequel never full clicks in the same way as it's predecessor. Audiences are left with a 'close and good enough' feeling as the combined ingredients are maybe now too bloated to result in the same smooth and heartfelt story that hit home for so many unsuspecting individuals. In many ways the awkward finale of the film is an apt summary of the film's success and trajectory in the MCU. From an initially mesmerising feeling which evolves into a sense of uncomfortable fan service
I already get see Last Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2 with my Wing Men?

Fun but slightly disappointing sequel that while doesn't quite match the original, is still well worth viewing.  The cast all returns with to their characters superbly, and developed nicely in new areas, from Gamora & Nebula's bond as sisters to Peter & Rocket's strained friendship.  Of the new additions, Kurt Russell shines as Ego and you instantly buy him as Star Lord's father.  Behind the camera, James Gunn brings lots of the visual thrills & fun of the original, but the story is over-stuffed with too many plot threads.  The middle section is where the movie particularly suffers, when the cast is separated and it just drags.  While it is nice to see some nods for fans, it feels more like a setup for the overall 'Cosmic Marvel Universe', than a movie on it's own.  Thankfully, the final act is action packed with an emotional gut punch at the end, reminding you the Guardians are about people trying to be a family.  Overall, not the classic that is the original, but a bunch of fun and well-worth seeing.

Even Chris Pratt becomes less of the lead actor and more of a supporting character. Not Pratt's fault, his Starlord character is not as well written in Vol 2 as he was in the original. Vol. 2 has its moments of fun. Moments, especially the prison break scene with Rocket and Yondu...and the scene between baby Groot and Rocket and a bomb. These are fun moments, but nothing more than moments, which are very sporadic across a 120 minute plus film. As a whole, sporadic moments do not make this movie worth wild, and Vol. 2 is this. Yet another home run that Marvel Studios has pulled off on us since the beginning of the MCU. This addition to the story of our five favorite galactic criminals introduces us to so many characters that sets up the rest of what is to come. It delivers a story that can move you to the the other side of the universe with twists and turns and gut-wrenching plot spirals. This may not be as good as its previous installment was, but it will set a new bar for future Marvel films when they come around.

The comic book movie genre and I are in a weird spot these days. After so many years spent following the various releases from the studio, each of which part of or attempting to start a big, shared cinematic universe, it's only natural to hit a point of exhaustion with the genre. One I didn't feel could get elevated.

However, the strong quality from the likes of the Lego Batman & Logan more than justified the money spent to go see them. They represent the best qualities of the genre and an example of how just making a movie can do more wonders than assembly line products that're essentially little more than trailers. 

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2, from what I heard pre-release, seemed to fit into this category as well. A more creatively driven venture where the scales were smaller and the story far more personnel among other tidbits which gave me hope for a third, strong entry in the 2017 lineup of comic book films.

And what a total jackass I was for thinking the third time would be the charm because GotG Vol 2 may just be one of my least favorite movies of the past few years. If you were someone expecting a smaller, more directorially driven movie about fatherhood and the value of family, you have two choices. 1) go fuck yourself or 2) go watch Lego Batman and Logan as they do everything Vol 2 attempts to but with far greater success it only makes the latest MCU venture look worse by comparison.

Not that it isn't perfectly detestable on its own merits because it certainly is. The structure of the film is fucked in a way I've never seen before. The film literally has nothing approaching a plot, story or structure to either besides a generic final blockbuster act that undermines whatever aspirations the film had tried to build up. It feels like someone took a 10 episode season, cut it to shit and then smashed the disparate elements together into a 2-hour film. The end result is a movie that just has stuff happen that are barely connected to one another until bringing them back in one of the worst attempts at a "let's set em up then knock em down" attempts I've ever seen. 

Now, a non-existent plot can be used to give the characters something to do but the issues are in the multitude in this regard. Almost everyone with the exception of Gamora is an obnoxious caricature of themselves from the first film. If Rocket was a damaged individual who tried to hide it through violence, expect the sociopath angle to get taken to an obnoxious extreme. If Drax was too literal, he is a bonified idiot in this film, not oblivious, a total, borderline pants shitting idiot. So much so he resembles his character the least from the last movie.

Baby Groot is probably the most blatant Disney thing ever to appear in the MCU. He literally has nothing approaching a personality and he's just there to look cute and sell merchandies, he is a big load of nothing at all. Chris Pratt's Star-Lord has fallen into the RDJ trap where he assumes we'll all love him unconditionally just for being here so he reacts to discovering his dad with the same reaction he does to being under attack or being sarcastic: with an expression of constant eye bulging and barely present "wit". 

The humor is another major issue that perpetually infuriates. No matter what kind of scene you're watching, whether it's trying to be dramatic or somber or heartfelt or anything, James Gunn will, fucking WILL end it with at least one dumb joke or gag (if God has mercy on your soul) that will totally undermine it. This movie never knows when to shut the hell up and give its audience another reason to care about what's happening. It always thinks it's being funny and clever by infuriating the shit out of you when it isn't: it's just infuriating you.

It would be one thing if the jokes weren't majoritively cliche or downright obnoxious but they are and good lord does they add to the feeling of tone deafness permeating throughout the whole viewing experience. There is a moment where, and I shit you not, Ego is explaining his loneliness in the cosmos and how he's attempted to overcome it by spreading himself out into the universe only for Drax (because he's a borderline pants shitting retard in this) to ask Ego if he has a dick (yes, really) then go into a bizarre exchange between himself, Peter and Ego about Ego's dick and Ego having sex with Peter's mom. What a way to emotionally invest your audience into the plight of an ancient, lonely God!

Not that you should care because Ego is little more than a cliched cartoon villain, entirely destroying any semblance of nuance concerning the themes of fatherhood and family so the movie can have a boring, mandatory let's blow the hell out of everything climax. 

Imagine if Logan stayed the exact same for the first two-thirds then the last half hour was some Avengers or MoS level destruction event where everything else that made you invested got its throat slit in favor of a shitty climax that ups the cartoonishness of the proceedings. It literally gets so bad that characters blatantly expose out the morals and parallels between one another. If there is ANY Marvel picture that treats the viewer with obvious contempt on every conceivable level, it is GotG Vol 2. 

When I finished watching this I asked myself "What the hell happened and how did I like the first one when the same exact people just shat out something like this?!". A sequel should never do that, leave you to mind blown in the worst way possible you start to doubt the previous movie(s) you liked and want to rush out and see them again just to convince yourself you weren't snorting some serious cocaine without even knowing it.

Which is appropriate because the only way you won't want to blow your brains out an hour into this multi-layered disaster of a movie is to BE high as all fucking hell.

*** This review may contain spoilers ***

The Guardian's of the Glaxy is a film so in love with its own cuteness that it forgets the audience might want something more than, for instance, laughing along with a CGI tree stump dancing across the opening battle with a big pink monster. I welcomed the first movie as new space opera to stand along the Star Wars and star Trek universes but the focus of Vol2 is on character relationships and another Hollywood take on men with Daddy issues.

Chris Platt's Star-lord is troubled because he never knew his father, who exists in his memory as a David Hasslehoff look-a-likee. These feelings of loss run so deep that they are given one line of dialogue in which they are established. Cue the arrival of Kurt Russel as 'Ego' Star-Lord's biological dad. Comic book fans will recognize the name from 'Thor' where Ego, as here, is a living planet no less and one of Jack Kirby and Stan Lee's 'God figures'.

Needless to say, the family reunion doesn't go as planned. I desperately needed to take a leak after scoffing a large piece of coffee cake (oh the joys of diabetes) and chose the films climactic battle to leave the room. I didn't feel I missed much. By then, the film had undercut any involvement by relentlessly using bathetic humour to undermine almost every scene. The script feels afraid that the audience will lose interest in the film if it isn't laughing at itself. This becomes a weird self-fulfilling prophecy. Post the God versus Guardians punch up, we are suddenly asked to engage with a profound revelation - it doesn't matter who your biological dad is, your real father is the man who brought you up - in this case Yondu, the blue finned gang boss who took a paternal if not exactly unselfish interest in Star-Lord and taught him in the ways of ravaging. Now, I am adopted and have met my birth father so I should have been moved by this. I wasn't. Because it was too much to ask me to engage in any depth with characters who had only been taken seriously as straight guys setting up quips, put downs and jokes. 

The sister-act between Gamorah and her angry sibling Nebula would fare better that Peter Quill/Ego conflict because at least the two women are treated seriously. However, audiences forgive me, I couldn't remember who the heck Nebula was or what role she played in the last movie. A quick scan of Nebula's comic book history reveals that I have managed to miss her appearances in the comics. That at least explains why my mind kept confusing her name with Nebulon, 'the celestial man' (sic) another cosmic character. Except that, stop the boat, the film may play with this confusion too because the star beast the Guardian's fight at Vol 2's opening looks a bit like the non-human form of Nebulon - go image search it.

The wider conflict is between a race of haughty golden people called the Sovereign race who are first helped then scammed by The Guardians - well by Rocket Racoon actually, who takes offense at their upper crust ways and snobbish attitude. Cue a space battle played out as an arcade game, a joke that wears thin even as it is being told, but in case you missed the gag the film tells it again.

But never mind the plot what about the music? A consideration deemed so important to the film that Marvel's plot outline here promotes it to the first line of its synopsis. Sure, this collection of big, bold but ultimately banal songs helps while away the time and helped me forget the film is only ever moments away from slipping to just the wrong side of terrible (THAT terrible side being the god awful Star Trek V (pun intended). But this is no Tarantino movie sound track. In his films, the music sets up all sorts of frissons. Here, the pop tunes just make the ride pass easier exactly like a tape mix in a car's cassette player (does anyone remember Eight Track?).

If, after the next Avengers movie, there is a Guardians Vol 3 I can only hope that it takes time to developing its wider fictional universe and has the courage to take that universe a little more seriously- by that I mean respectfully. One of the five in-credit sequences reveals a cocoon containing Adam Warlock, one of my all- time favorite characters, and I want a better world for him to be born into.

Guardians of the Galaxy 2 is clearly the least of the whole Marvel pack so far. It tries very hard to recreate the joyful nonsense of the first volume, but fails consistently, rather targeting one-off jokes than investing in its characters that jump, fall and evade bombs, bullets and lasers like Tom and Jerry in space, with no sense of tread whatsoever. Star-Lord himself, while still central to the "plot", seems strangely impersonal, dutifully reacting to events around him rather than guiding the action. The movie takes forever to end and offers no surprises on the way.

At the end you realize that it has all been nothing but a setup for the next volume, like a cut from an endless Marvel sausage, served shinier than ever but with not much taste.
Love, love, love this movie!!

Fans of the original will not be disappointed with the second instalment in the 'Guardians of the Galaxy' franchise. Like its predecessor, it's full of action and humour. The visuals are impressive with most scenes bursting with life through bright and vibrant colours. Chris Pratt is just as charming and humorous as the lead protagonist, Peter Quill, and we see him finally meeting his father, Ego, who is brilliantly portrayed by Kurt Russell. One of the biggest themes of this superhero sequel is family. We see Zoe Saldana's Gamora trying to repair her relationship with her sister, Nebula (Karen Gillian). However, since the previous film, the titular Guardians have become a lot closer and their relationship is enjoyable to watch. In the midst of all the action, romance makes an appearance as Quill tries to develop a relationship with Gamora who is more focused on saving the galaxy and fixing her relationship with her sister. When I first watched 'Guardians of the Galaxy', I wasn't the biggest fan. However, this sequel beat my expectations and I really enjoyed this sequel a lot more than the first. I recommend this to those who like action films and enjoy tongue-in-cheek humour.
Awesome, hilarious, more character depth, and a good twist, all makes for  a great successor to the first movie. My favorite movie of the year so far.

Let me begin by emphasizing the the original Guardians of the Galaxy was the movie I saw in theaters most, three times during its run. I was looking forward to this for the characters, wit and visuals. Unfortunately, only the visuals were not compromised.

To be blunt, this movie is not funny, and some of the comedy is cringe-worthy. I felt the length of the film during these scenes. Baby Groot is part of the problem, he loses his appeal after a scene or two, and does nothing interesting the rest of the movie. The gold religion from the trailer doesn't really have their arc resolved at all, and all we get to conclude them is a teaser in the after credits scene. 

When the characters are just in idle banter, its pretty hit or miss, which is unfortunate considering how funny the first movie is. The characters here feel like a set of traits interacting rather than developed. This just comes back to the script failing to land its comedic beats, which destroys the pacing too frequently. 

There is a good deal to like, particularly visually, but there was far more that I wanted to like but couldn't enjoy.
Easily one of the best Marvel films and one not sullied by the presence of Downey Jr.'s overly smarmy Iron Man.

I have to start by saying the first film was my favourite film of the last few years and I'm a huge fan.

This film had a weak, bloated story. Almost every scene filled with forced, cheap gags. Unbelievable and disappointing bad guys who tried to wise crack their through and lost any menace. Acting was poor apart from Yondu and Nebula who was woefully underused.

This was was like a comedy parody of the first film. A goofy, TV sequel that had none of the magic of the original blockbuster.

At one point Drax wisecracks that he does big turds. I'd venture none as big as this one.

9.5 out of 10:

I LOVED this movie! The soundtrack was awesome, and this movie takes you through every emotion in the book. Can't say much without spoilers, but I will say I laughed til I cried, and then cried until I laughed with joy!

It's just as good as the first movie if not better.
James Gunn is back with the same wisecracker superhero team: Star Lord, Drax, Gamora, Rocket Raccoon, and Groot. Some of the fun supporting players like Yondu and Nebula are back as well.
Fresh new faces this time around are Mantis, Ayesha, and Ego (Peter's long estranged father)
The Guardians are hires now looking to vanquish any threat the universe has to offer for pay
After making a deal with a race called the Sovereign, Rocket makes a big mistake that puts a price on their heads
They head out further to escape and come across both Mantis who is a powerful empath that can read people's feelings as well as change them, and Ego (the Living Planet), Pete is just as shocked to see his dad after 34 years and he's not a big fan of wanting a relationship with him now
Kurt Russell really does the human form of Ego quite well with a charisma and swagger, Ego wants to make up for lost time but Mantis may know something everyone else doesn't
Drax now being accustomed to having a new family is much more sensitive plus he always speaks his mind in the literal sense
Rocket now has the task of taking care of Groot whom is now in a younger state of being; he's just so darn adorable and practically steals the movie 
Yondu and Nebula get more of a chance to shine as well digging deep into themselves showing what's really going on and what we didn't know from the first movie
This film is about the team being a family whereas the first movie was about becoming it, all of them have their own personal demons to overcome so the film is much more character driven not to mention the comedy is just as sparkly like the effects
There are some hilarious cameos too that'll knock your socks off
Of course the movie isn't without a bit of human emotion to go with the action set pieces
You don't have to watch all the previous MCU films to enjoy this one as it can be a stand-alone adventure on its own
I love the action, the effects, the chemistry among all these people, and I love the newer characters, too!
Anxious to see what Vol. 3 will do next

This was a really good sequel.  Was it better than the first no, was it bad no, not by a long shot For me the 2nd  Guardians is just ask good as the first one. And the ending is probably one of the best endings to a superhero movie(besides Logan) that i have seen in awhile.  Drax in my opinion  was one of the best character in the movie, he will have you laughing out loud.  All in all this was a  great movie and if you liked the 1st one you will love this one also.  If you were not a fan of the 1st then the 2nd will not change your mind.  Another hit from Marvel, so definitely go see this. I will say Disney had a heavy hand in making sure Groot was everywhere to push merchandising, they focus on him a little much in some cases, however I wouldnt say it ruins it at all. I hope by the 3rd he is full grown.
Great to see Kurt Russell in the marvel role, he delivers as always. Zoe Saldana gave a better performance in my opinion, same goes for Dave Bautista, he said he wouldn't stop taking acting lessons after getting this role. 
No dancing Quill but still the same humor and badass mix as well as more emotional range in his character this time. Rocket of course is Rocket, he is great.
A little more back story which brings in more dramatic scenes then the first but that is expected also from a sequel in a franchise. However Guardians pattented ability to instantly diffuse tension with humor doesn't fail and in many ways shows itself more then in the 1st.
CGI is very very heavily used but it is to be expected again and it is top notch. The finaleâ?? is a mad house of CGI which is mind blowing if watch in 3D. Still fun and visually awesome to see.

All in all a great addition to the Guardians franchise.

Although having a few weaker entries in their franchise, the Marvel Cinematic Universe has yet to have a bad film, at least in my opinion. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 only furthers that notion, stating that this franchise is around for the long haul. Even though it does feel like filler throughout the majority of the film, it's about as good as filler can possibly get. We now find ourselves in the beginning of the preparation phase for the biggest film this franchise will ever have, in Avengers: Infinity War, so most of the films this year will probably feel like an appetizer. The biggest criticism this film has been receiving is the fact that there isn't much of a story present. I have to whole-heartedly disagree on that. Here is why I believe Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is an absolute blast from start to finish. 

On the surface, this film really doesn't have a plot at all, due to the secrecy of certain elements. The trailers for this film give you that it's about the team going on missions, getting tangled up with Peter's biological father, and exploring new parts of the galaxy. When you boil that down, that's not much of a plot to go on, but once you watch the film all the way through and look back on it, the plot is pretty obvious. For the sake of a twist, the plot details are kept under wraps, so I won't get into any spoilers. I thought that was a very bold move by writer/director James Gunn, because he could've easily lost the interest of his viewers. Once the plot of the film becomes apparent, I thought the film became great, and that is not the fanboy in me trying to defend this franchise. I throughly enjoyed this film from beginning to end. 

In the first film, the standouts were easily Groot and Rocket Raccoon, and even though they definitely capitalize on the fact that Groot is a baby in this film (which is incredibly loveable by the way), the standouts to me were all the side characters. From Yondu to Mantis, this film gives enough for these characters to do, making audiences love pretty much every single character on-screen, which is very hard to accomplish. Drax is definitely utilized as the comedic relief throughout the majority of this film, more so than the first, which was fine by me. If you go this film to gawk at baby Groot, laugh at endless jokes, enjoy some action, and especially to connect on a very emotional level with each of these characters, I think you'll be satisfied. 

At its core, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a character study, plain and simple. Where I think the biggest flaw lies with this film and where I can see many people dozing off, is the fact that there are quite a lot of scenes involving characters opening up to each other in order to explore everyone's backstory in depth. For myself, I was fully invested in these scenes and thought it only added to the emotional impact. It can definitely feel like a film with a bunch of scenes slapped together, which is how I feel some people may view this film, but I thought it was great. It's pretty ballsy to make a film solely on character development, but when that is the goal and the end result is this good, you won't ever find me complaining. 

In the end, if you're not aware that this film is going to be much more of a character study than anything, then please take this as a warning, because there is a lot of it. Filled with much more emotion than the original, much more comedy, and some pretty exciting action sequences, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a great follow-up to its predecessor. Although lacking the stronger story that was held by the first, this film makes up for it in every other way. I won't be able to score this film quite as highly as the original, simply due to the fact that the freshness level isn't quite on par. That being said, I left this film feeling completely satisfied from the amount of emotion and entertainment I received. I can't wait to see more from these characters. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is more than worth the price of admission and is among the best of the sequels to come from the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

The Guardians of the Galaxy are back and they do not disappoint. Once again, the plot is simple, they must save the galaxy from utter destruction but the question is, from whom? The plot is up in the air for most of the film and at points, you'll feel like you're going nowhere but eventually, everything comes together. The cast is great again, with tremendous chemistry to go around and Kurt Russell fits in well alongside them with his "rugged good looks" and arrogant charm. I didn't particularly care for the other, new characters but that does not mean they were bad, just less impressive. In volume two we are given what feels like more comedy and larger than life action than the first one. However, this time around the movie is not as fresh or original like the ?one preceding it, which had come out of nowhere and was a huge success. The famous Walkman played soundtrack is still fun yet seemingly less memorable than the first one. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is worth watching none the less and for those who enjoyed the first one, you'll more than likely have a good time.

This movie is every bit as fun and exciting as the first. Right from the opening credits, you're hit with same kind of punch that Gunn dealt with the original. For the first third of this movie, I would say it hit you left and right, joke after joke, and that's what I liked the most. It focused mainly on the comradery of this group. What sells the first Guardians of the Galaxy for me is the chemistry between the group, and the back-and-forth they all have. The way Gunn writes these characters, and how he layers the dialogue to create a perfect symphony is incredible. And we got that for the first third of this movie. Then, the characters split up. While what each of them were doing was interesting enough, that comradery and that chemistry was missing. It left a hole in the movie, and the static energy of go go go came to a halt. I don't think these characters are compelling enough on their own. If we ever got a Drax (Dave Bautista) or a Gamora (Zoe Saldana) spin-off film, I don't think it would work. Even Star-Lord. It's when they're together, and they are playing off of each other, that's when they are incredibly compelling. But separating them in the manner that Vol. 2 did just froze the momentum...

You can read our full review here: http://www.themovieparadise.com/2017/05/guardians-of-galaxy-vol-2-spoiler-free-review-chris-pratt-marvel-kurt-russell-james-gunn-zoe-saldana-bradley-cooper-vin-diesel.html

However, the aesthetics were nice, quite a few of the jokes were pretty funny, the action was generally solid, many pieces of the first movie's stories were either clarified or resolved, the story pushed the Marvel MCU storyline a little, the teaser at the end of the credits was intriguing,  and the Stan Lee cameo was probably my favorite thus far. 

Overall, I liked the movie. I didn't like it enough to purchase it when it comes out, or watch it again, but it is a good single - watch film, in my opinion.

Fantastic art direction and substantial character development, coupled with masterful visual effects and a replete attention to the whole of the production from beginning through end credits; Guardians of the Galaxy 2 was a surprising delight that exceeded my expectations.  Though there was a tad bit of an extreme bend toward humor, that element was balanced by a serious, if even somewhat psychologically shocking villain.  In net effect the film provides an engrossing space odyssey with effective humor, genuine drama, dynamic action, and substantial relational development--setting up the narrative for its movement into the upcoming finales.

"Volume 2" could have been about twenty to twenty-five minutes shorter, but overall, I think the movie is very good.  The cast has great chemistry together.  They no doubt make a great team.  Bradley Cooper is a riot as the voice of Rocket.  Also, you have to like a movie that uses music from recent Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductee Electric Light Orchestra (ELO) on its soundtrack!  Remember to stay through the credits as you usually would with Marvel movies (Except with "Logan".).  You are sure to have just as much fun watching this movie as you did its predecessor.

Reviewed 5.5.17.  As an admitted fan of the first GOTG movie, perhaps I'm being a bit soft on the follow-up.  It certainly isn't as fresh, and the ambitious storyline falls clumsily short. But its particular brand of charm remains intact.  And while the narrative threads fray, the comedic writing remains taut, along with the stellar deadpan delivery from the leads.

While the visuals are a step up from the first, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 caves under a weak plot and overall bad writing. You COULD rename the movie as "Guardians of the Galaxy: How to be a Family", because its the obvious overarching theme that isn't even creatively presented. Everything is so bottlenecked into this idea (sister-sister relationship, father-son relationship, outcast-outcast relationship, etc. etc.) I had to wonder if I was watching a movie or listening to a sermon. The result is a team dynamic with this veneer of empathy to cover up the fact that no real evolution of the characters have happened since the first movie. 

The humor in GotG2 is also something which feels forcibly shoved to the forefront of the movie. Joking and sarcasm appear with such frequency they effectively deaden the situations where there's a "serious" emotional moment. It's not believable, and it's hard to take anything that happens seriously because of it. And the humor? Not really that funny, with a good portion banking off the cute-ness of a Baby Groot to the point of my own physical pain. The amount of sexual jokes eclipse the latest Power Rangers movie, further alienating the franchise from younger audiences (very strange, considering all this Baby Groot movie time) and successfully transported me back to fifth grade. If the theater wasn't packed with people, and I wasn't wearing my Cinco De Mayo cowboy boots, I would have left the theater- that's the honest truth.

IF the movie would have focused more on the action and visual elements, even without improving the story and humor, it would have been a much stronger movie. There are some awesome space fights, environments, and an interesting alien race introduced. And not all the funny was unfunny; there is some good comedic writing peppered within everything that wasn't. Even so, Guardians 2 is a bit of a galactic mess for the stated reasons, aside also from the inconsistency in plot/characters/emotions, and the increased vulgar language which comes across as "we can do what we want, we're cool, yo". Well yo-- pay me next time to watch your movie, cool?

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a zany continuation of Marvel Studio's most surprising origin story flicks and mostly works. While Volume 2 lacks a compelling story to keep the film on track, it ends up feeling like a character study for most of our established characters, which isn't a bad thing. There is a bigger focus on comedy this time around and a lot of it hits, but a good amount of it made me role my eyes, particularly most of the Drax comedy. While this chapter isn't nearly as compelling as Volume 1, it's a welcome entry into the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

6.9 out of 10. Entertaining fun all around, with characters that still maintain their charm. The story and villain have improved since the first film but just barely, those are my only positives sadly. The humor just didn't hit as hard because after a while you can start to feel the pattern of james gunns comedic beat and start anticipating punchlines before they happen. The plot kicking in in the last act also makes the film seem a bit episodic. The music (both soundtrack and score) felt extremely forced in as well. But my biggest negative has to be the visual effects, at times it felt as if i was watching Spy Kids 3D, james gun abandoned practical sets and stunts in favor of just using greenscreen which makes everything look staged and so fantastical that in ungrounds the film from reality.

If you liked the first Guardians of the Galaxy, you'll like the second one. There's great character moments that are earned, but the story sizzles to nothing; leaving no substance to be earned from Volume 2.

I personally loved the first Guardians movie.  A big part of that was the lack of any expectation going into it.  Therefore, it exceeded my expectations. Going in to Volume 2, I had fairly high hopes and the movie ended up meeting those very nicely.  Volume 2 captures the characters and dynamic from the original and dives down into multiple levels of their interactions, motives and desires.  The movie is visually stunning and the character developments and arcs are meaningful and fulfilling.  The same humor is captured in Volume 2 and even cranked up to 11, landing many jokes and tropes that are inches away from flopping.  Because the characters push the envelope a bit more (in a creative, not crude, way) with their banter, Gunn is able to really capture a lot of the secret sauce from the first installment.  A few jokes fall flat or pop back up when they didn't need to but it didn't take away from the overall pleasure.  Because the characters were the main focus, the actual plot of the movie did not capture me quite as easily.  In fact, because Ego is an actual planet, much of the plot and locations are not really a plot or location but it's another character.  For most of the movie, it didn't really concern me where the guardians were or what was going to happen next.  What mattered to me was hanging on to every word from every character because the meaning and purpose of the movie was to dive deep into the team.  With that said, the progression of any real accomplishments falls a bit short.  Instead we are left feeling an extremely strong connection with the guardians, happy to see where they are at now and how much they themselves have grown since the first movie and even more after this second movie.  Because of this strong relationship, stems the desire for more galaxy saving.

At some points, his lack of depth or care is the vehicle for some of this franchise's best humor, which stands in strong juxtaposition to what seem like some Hamlet moments in this installment.  While I thought Kurt Russell was awesome in the movie, I think him as a planet/god actually saddled the movie a bit.  I really liked the comparison of Ego to Yondu as father figures.  Some of the references (Mary Poppins and Pacman) were awesome....loved them.  And the tape bit and Taser face bits were great too.  In the end the viewer is tossed between "take me seriously" and "don't take me seriously", which I thought was better balanced in the first one and less so in this one.  Seinfeld is the guidepost, I think, and can't wait for the Vol. 3.

"Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" (PG-13, 2:16), much like its predecessor, is one of the most creative movie mash-ups ever. When I reviewed the original, I noted how much it had in common with "Star Wars". My 2014 review called it, "a movie about a group of rebels of different races getting together to save a planet from the power of a mysterious deadly orb," described the group as including "a good-looking outlaw pilot who is used to only thinking of himself, a large brown creature who makes sounds that others seem to understand as a sort of language, a tough woman with a royal background who has no patience for nonsense and a small, wise creature who provides guidance to the others," and noted that the group had to "battle an evil henchman with warped religious ideas who dresses in black and only answers to an even more powerful evil being who always seems to be sitting in a big chair."  To all that, add significant daddy issues and you have the Guardians films. Well, plus aspects of "Star Trek" (discovering strange new worlds), "Independence Day" (several people playing crucial roles in defeating interstellar evil) and even "The Fast and the Furious" (a diverse group of friends regarded as family).

And let's not forget that Guardians is a Marvel property. "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" is the 15th film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. The movie contains Easter eggs tying it to other Marvel film franchises and hints at future cinematic overlap. In terms of how this one fits with the others chronologically, according to IMDb, "the film takes place in 2014, 3 months after Guardians of the Galaxy (2014). It takes place a year after Thor: The Dark World (2013). Before or after Captain America: The Winter Soldier (2014) and a year before Avengers: Age of Ultron (2015)." Speaking of Tony Stark's cohorts, shortly before the first Guardians movie was released, Walt Disney Company CEO Bob Iger said that the goal with this franchise was actually to create "another Avengers". The Guardian series does have that feel to it, along with some of the comic sensibilities of "Deadpool", another Marvel film franchise born in the mid-2010s. Now, having said all that (and ensuing cinematic cross-pollination notwithstanding), the Guardians movies have definitely created their own niche within the MCU - and their own sense of fun.

Picking up just months after the action in the original, "Vol. 2" sees Peter Quill / Star-Lord (Chris Pratt), Gamora (Zoe Saldana), Drax (Dave Bautista), Rocket (voiced by Bradley Cooper) and Baby Groot (voiced by Vin Diesel) adjusting to their newfound fame, their role as galaxy guardians and the dynamics of (and their individual places within) this team - slash - family unit. Early on, four of them battle a monster known as the Abilisk (looking like a much bigger and angrier Jabba the Hutt - with tentacles)... while Groot dances to Quill's music. A gold-colored race of people known as the Sovereign reward the Guardians for defeating Abilisk - and protecting the special batteries that it was trying to steal - by turning over a prisoner, Nebula (Karen Gillan), Gamora's estranged sister, who has a bounty on her head. As the Guardians leave the Sovereign, Rocket steals some of those valuable batteries. The insult of such a theft sends Ayesha (Elizabeth Debicki) into a rage and she sends her fleet of remotely-piloted drones after Rocket and company. Due to some nifty flying - and a little help from a mysterious ship which suddenly comes to their aid - the Guardians survive, but crash land on an unfamiliar planet.

That mysterious ship lands on the planet too and out steps a being called Ego (Kurt Russell)... who claims to be Quill's father! Ego's story seems to check out, so Quill, Gamora and Drax let Ego take them back to his planet so Quill can spend some time with his pops. Rocket is left behind to repair the ship, take care of Baby Groot and keep an eye on Nebula. As Quill and friends get to know Ego - and Mantis (Pom Klementieff), Ego's pet empath (a being who can experience the feelings of other people by touching them and even temporarily alter those feelings), Rocket has to defend against an attack by Yondu Udonta (Michael Rooker) and his crew of Ravegers, whom Ayesha has hired to retrieve the batteries and kill the Guardians. The Ravegers capture Rocket and Groot, but Yondu's reluctance to pursue Quill leads to a mutiny by Yondu's crew. His lieutenant, who calls himself Taserface (Chris Sullivan), imprisons Yondu, Rocket and Groot, gets rid of those loyal to Yondu and teams up with Nebula to catch up with the rest of the Guardians, who, in the meantime, have run into some pretty serious trouble of their own. 

"Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" has a better plot and visuals and is even more fun than the original. In the first movie, the Guardians became a family, but in this one, they have to learn how to BE a family - while Quill and Gamora each have to deal with serious conflicts stemming from their own original families. Freed from the confines of establishing the Guardians' cinematic world and forming their relationships gives returning writer/director James Gunn the freedom to do more interesting things with the story - and the characters, which are now more developed - and more entertaining - especially Groot, who's as adorable as any Minion, but much tougher (which also happens to be pretty adorable). The music is great, while the scenery is vibrant and the action is exciting (and deserving of 3D viewing). Sometimes, there's almost too much going on... visually, but also aurally, as the sound effects and music compete for attention with the dialog. As a whole, Vol. 2 is a good step forward for the franchise and (with help from five short scenes and embedded graphics during and after the closing credits) builds anticipation for more Guardian adventures, including some Marvel-ous crossover action. "B+"

Best Marvel Studio movie since Captain America: Winter Soldier. I was getting so bored of Marvel Studios during Phase III. Everything in 2016 was a let down. My prayers were answered. Gunn did something that the Russo Brothers were able to do with Winter Soldier: Make a great sequel (The Russos just screwed up the third installment of Cap). The story was better than the original Guardians. I left the original disappointed, but learned to like it after watching it with the kids a few more times. The story was funny, it built on introducing a very important character. It gave closure, even though it was painful. This is officially my third favorite movie in the universe. I am hoping this is a trend to continue with 2017 with Spider-Man and Thor. Drax was very funny, Rocket showed why he was a comic bad-ass, and Groot was not over powering the storyline. Yondu was vindicated and it sets up the story for a great Infinity War premise. Another great issue was no Thanos. Kurt Russell was great as Ego and that was the best part of the film. It didn't go all Wizard of Oz like I was expecting. It turned out more classy.

Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 is a movie, not a superhero movie. It's just a movie. 

Okay, now I got that joke out of the way...

Guardians of the Galaxy is a superhero film produced by the Marvel Studios and directed by James Gunn, it is a sequel and it is the fifteenth film of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. 

The story is follows up on the team of Guardians of the Galaxy, consisting of Peter Quill (Star-Lord), Gamora, Rocket, Drax, and....Baby Groot, where they later get Nebula from the Sovereign race in trade of protecting special batteries from getting stolen. Let's skip to a certain part where they somehow split the team because Star-Lord meets the dad and Rocket and Baby Groot somehow was led into some other adventure with Yondu. 

In the first half of the film, I think it felt as if the film is missing all the action the first movie have but it felt better later in the second half because a huge spoiler happens near the conclusion. What kept the first half of the movie flowing were the ongoing jokes coming from Rocket and Drax. Maybe pit Bradley Cooper and Dave Bautista together for a comedy. But that is why I'll give this a 4/5 for because of that second half of the film. Yondu did his part really well and you would wish to see more parts from him and Rocket together. 

Snake Plissken.....I mean Ego, played by Kurt Russell, revealed his role well and you need to see how much of a father figure he is to Star-Lord. In parts, you would see a young version of Kurt Russell, yes, that CGI they did with Rogue One at the end was done again in this film. It was well played. 

Volume 2 is better than the first but I might give the first the better of the action sequences. The ongoing jokes and the near-conclusion of the film were pretty much how I felt that I'll pass this movie with a B+. If added the action in the first half with all that element leading towards the end, maybe it'd be worthy of an A+. The following review contains spoilers and is only for huge nerds:

There are some slight alterations to the canon, but all in all hats off to James Gunn and the whole crew on this movie. The fact that they are bringing to life some of the characters that they are is pretty remarkable, especially when we haven't even seen such important characters like Captain Marvel and Nova yet. The movie uses humor, music, as well as excellent character development to make the movie a fun time for the people who genuine do not care about these cosmic adventures. The script is written to be palatable by those who are "alien" to the comic references, while still slipping them in when they can. So overall, I'm head over heels with this sequel

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 did a great job introducing some key comic book characters. I was excited to see Yondu and Nebula coke back. Mantis is a great addition to the team. I thought that the presence of some other members of the GOTG from the older comics (Starhawk, Martinex, and Charlie-23) was a great check in the box, but I'd love to see more of them in the next GOTG. Besides not actually being Peter's dad, Ego was a delight to see in the film. Howard the Duck shows up yet again. The Watcher shares the screen in another great Stan Lee cameo. Ayesha was a great way to introduce Adam Warlock, if maybe a little late.

Much in the same vain as the original(silly quips, tons of space related action, pretty awesome soundtrack), I think this one ups the ante here. It's not without at least some eye rolling dialogue and lame clichés, but at least it's nothing that sours the overall experience. It's a fun movie with some pretty hot space babes(especially the Asian one, Mantis) and a satisfying enough ending. So yeah it's got some minor flaws, but I definitely liked it better than the first.

Guardians of the Galaxy 2 is a good, fun movie. With the 1st movie being a plot driven affair, this movie is instead a character driven film.  The theme is Family. It gives us a glimpse further into each of the Guardians. There are a lot of laughs, and some very heartfelt moments. 
I would recommend this for kids 10+ years of age. There are a few sketchy moments and a few disturbing/ scary imagery that might not be appropriate for kids  younger than 10 IMO.  Still a very pleasing movie that further develops the characters. I think Yondu was the surprise of the movie. I think Nebula is a fascinating character and her relationship with Gamora are fleshed out even more.

And unlike some of the MCU such as Ant-Man and Dr. Strange, you don't know where they might go or how it'll turn out in the end.  That alone makes it a nearly flawless movie.  And like Age of Ultron, it may be looked at as a disappointment for some but respected greatly in hindsight.

From the opening credits to the final battle, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is highly entertaining. I think I like this sequel more than the original. It's a bit silly for adults, and it's a little too dark for children, but it feels just about right for teenagers. Is it a perfect movie? No. Do all the (many) jokes land? No. That doesn't really matter, though, because if you just sit back and enjoy the ride, you'll realize this is precisely what a summer blockbuster should be.
