Admittingly, I was not a fan of the original. I found the first film an eye-candied substandard science fiction yarn only suitable for a Saturday afternoon. Obviously emboldened by unexpected box office gold, director James Gunn decided to ramp up the volume to an '11' for this sequel.

(Spoilers!) Aiming for a grandiose villain this time, Ego the Living Planet, as played by Kurt Russell is a toothless tiger. We are treated yet again to another end-of-the-world or better yet, end-of- the-universe scenario complete with sub-par special effects that threatens a total of three planets in the whole universe (I counted three, and that includes Missouri, USA, representing Earth). With Dr Strange anticlimactic ending alongside this anticlimactic last third act, one wonders if Marvel Studios is cutting corners when it comes to effects.

This time round infantile jokes revolving round adolescent concept of fornication are abound. They are only worth a chuckle once and repetitive reiterations only serve to reveal Gunn's sense of humour. Since he's contract-bound by Disney's kid-friendly ratings, most of the jokes fell flat. To put it bluntly, if you want to tell sex jokes, go all the way like the American Pie movies. 

As other review sites have noted, the first act is the most energetic, providing a shot in the arm only for the first 15 minutes. The second act which lasts around an hour drags as there are only two settings: Yondu's Ravager's ship and Ego's planet. One couldn't care less about Chris Pratt's absentee Dad's hangups. Spielberg does it better than Gunn in his earlier movies. It was so dull that I actually dozed off more than a couple of times.

The preposterous third act recalls Batman Vs Superman's "Martha" resolution to the said conflict. But since everyone who fervently follows MCU's episodic TV serial-like movies have a short memory span, they would probably forgive James Gunn for being such a genius when he uses basically the same plot device to snap Peter Quill out of his hypnosis. Superheroes do have a soft spot for their mothers...

The Ego/Peter Quill fight scene recalls the now dated and badly- rendered fight scene between Neo and Agent Smith in Matrix Revolutions. I groaned at the Pac-Man transformation scene. I know many people like the 70s/80s pop cultural references but this scene is bordering on being ridiculous. If one wants a nostalgic trip down memory lane, 'Boogie Nights' offers a more superior experience. Then again, the target audience for this film would not be old enough to view that fine film.

Taken in totality, this film is more banal than "Civil War", many of the jokes were unfunny and falls flat. The whole film is filled with so much colour palettes, it hurts the eyes. To summarise bluntly, watching this film is akin to binging on fizzy drinks to a whole new diabetic level.

I feel like a drone. Every year Marvel comes out with its new set of movies and every year like drones we all go out to see them. And for this reason Marvel makes tons of $$$ without any quality improvement or originality, because as drones, we all just gobble it up. It's like we have been given a command: "This year you will see the following movies and not hold them to any standard, kapeesh!!" 

Marvel movie story lines have been declining while at the same time special effects and better actors getting hired has been increasing. Like how winning an Oscar now lands you a role in a super hero/big budget production rather than another artistic role: Brie Larson in Captain Marvel (and the horrible Kong), Lupita Nyong'o in Star Wars (ok, that's not Marvel, but still a huge franchise.), Jared Leto as the Joker (DC, I know), but you get the picture. This creates a conundrum in our heads: good acting, great special effects, bad story writing, so, hmmmm.......does this mean that I liked it? Should I go with the flow and say I liked it, because critics aren't gonna diss a movie that's sure to make $$$ and I don't wanna seem like a killjoy or shame myself in front of my firends? You know, I'll see the next Marvel movie and then decide.

And so this year, the cycle begins with us giving our money to Guardians of the Galaxy V2. Expect nothing more than what the trailer has to offer. Or see the first one again and it'll be the same as seeing V2, you'll just save money. The story does advance with Kurt Russell starring as Starlord's dad. Kind of a rehash of "No/Luke....I am your father." It's good when they hire good actors. Make-up and special effects are great. But in all, I wouldn't use the words "enjoyable" or "exciting." I'll just say, "Ritual completed, onto the next superhero movie."

Hey I'm a victim here nonetheless. I'm not criticizing people for seeing Guardians, as I also did, but I'm getting to get critical of us who every year, dish out our money for these superhero movies, which are in fact not becoming any better in quality, and studio execs thinking that they are creating masterpieces because of the gross $$$, hence thereforth making no extra effort to make a better movie. 

So see it, or stay at home and stare at the wall...it's up to you. If ya got nothing better to do then what else should ya do??

At the time of writing, there are only 7 out of 120 user reviewers that did not like the movie. I know I will receive a multitude of unhelpful votes for voicing my honest feedback about this movie. However, I hope that my feedback will be helpful for people who are able to judge a film in an objective manner so that they, at least, will be able to save their hard earned cash.

Firstly, the main antagonist is a Marvel character that has been completely changed for this movie. It bears no background similarity to the character in the comics whatsoever. I understand that the Marvel movies are all about making a spin on the comic book story arcs, but this difference was far too large for me to accept.

Whilst watching the movie, I had to ponder whether I had stepped into a Marvel Superhero version of "Fast and Furious". There was a continuous message that family is important and how the protagonists became who they were due to disenfranchised childhoods. Whilst this is a valid point, I do not feel that it belongs in a superhero action movie as it serves no purpose. Worse was when the message contradicted itself when we see Peter Quill betrayed by his Father. The clumsiness of this contradiction did nothing to alleviate the sickly sweet message that the movie was trying to convey. I get that James Gunn is trying to send out a message to the younger generation but I would think that kids go to watch a superhero movie for the action, and will not really appreciate or acknowledge the message that he is driving.

Unlike the first movie, there was a distinct lack of character focus and their abilities. It could easily have been an action movie without superheroes. In fact, the movie seemed to be focused on two characters when it came to showcasing their abilities. One of these had a sequence that was inspired by the Quicksilver scenes in the X-Men movies. The other was extremely underwhelming and was defeated far too incredibly when you consider the differences in age and experiences. None of the characters were interesting with the exception of Nebula and Mantis. However, Pom Klementieff played her role like a stuttering female cyborg that I even thought the role was played by an East Asian actress before I checked the cast members. The actors paid to play the new characters were miscast in my opinion. Sylvester Stallone's performance reminded me of his Judge Dredd and not in a good way.

It was clear that the popular factors in the first movie were taken and overdone in the second movie. Drax was made to look like a dumb fool once again but even more than in the first movie. While the CGI effects were good, the cuteness factor of Baby Groot served only to market the movie to kids and geek girls, and to rake in merchandise profit. There was also constant mention and focus on the cassette mix which was totally unnecessary (again, for merchandise promotion).

With the exception of Captain America and the first two Avengers and Thor movies, why do the Marvel movies have to be over-saturated with humor? It's one thing to market the movies to a wider audience but it's totally another thing when it's taken too far, and the humor becomes so clichéd.
A flashy production with no substance

The first Guardians film seemed to take audiences by surprise. It felt fresh and different and meeting the crew of eccentric characters for the first time was all part of the fun, and it utilized the element of surprise to kind of brand its unique (in the Marvel universe anyways) sense of humor and chemistry. 

Vol. 2 recognizes the general adoration of Voi. 1, and sets out to give us more of the same, just on a bigger scale. So, whether or not this works for you will likely depend on your expectations. It loses a bit of its edge, but it gains in terms of developing a much larger mythology (and the end credits suggest it will get bigger yet). 

I read an interview with Gunn where he discussed his desire to really exercise some creative freedom when it came to Vol. 2, and in many ways he sees it as a built in universe with no real rules. The opening sequence stands as a good example of the kind of things we can expect as the film moves forward, taking a larger than life galactic battle between the Guardians and a space monster and narrowing our perspective onto a prolonged... and almost awkwardly prolonged scene of Baby Groot randomly dancing through the chaos. The scene is genuinely funny, and what is rather brilliant about the way Gunn approaches it, and subsequent scenes that play out in a similar way, is that he never cues us on when the laughter should start or stop. He just lets these moments linger, and the generating effect, at least in my case, was a theater experience where the laughing never really stopped through the entire film. 

That is not to say that the film allows the humor to get in the way of the story. There is a definite emotional heart woven into Vol. 2, one that is ever more deliberate and poignant than Vol. 1.. And, for me anyways, the emotion definitely landed in a very real way. What's interesting to consider is the overlap in actors and themes with Fate and the Furious, and what Vol. 2 really celebrates is the idea that family does not need to be defined by blood or divisions, and the theme of family and fatherhood permeates the entire thing in a neat way, beginning with the reveal of who Quill's father is. 

Something else to note in Vol. 2 is the way it takes the collective group of Vol. 1 and splits them up into different partnerships for the majority of the film. This means that the collaborative chemistry in the first film is given some different opportunities to develop into smaller more intimate relationships in the second. So while the overall pacing ends up a bit more erratic and undisciplined (the story in Vol. 1 was much tighter), the moments between characters, moments that don't feel obliged to rush or move anywhere, in particular, do gain a greater authenticity. For example, we really get a chance to appreciate the voice work by Cooper, along with the striking animation that helps to bring life to the fur and facial futures. It is quite astounding. And we are also given some unexpected dynamics, such as the shared revelation between Rocket and Yondu about their family past. 

So, if you feel inclined to ask (and I think it is a natural question to ask), is the second film better than the first? The same? Not as good? I would say it is all a matter of perspective. That sounds a little too obvious an answer, and a bit of a cop-out. But I think it is very true when it comes to Vol. 2.. You might end up feeling the loss of the surprise of the first film, and if you did, I think that would make sense. You might love the sprawling world and larger mythology that Vol. 2 opens up, and if you do, that makes a whole lot of sense. You might get frustrated with scenes like the extended opening sequence because they feel a bit ecelectic and undisciplined, especially when set up against the rest of the Marvel universe (which get surprsingly little attention here in Vol. 2). Or you might love the freedom that this represents. You might miss the group playing off one another in Vol. 1, or you might love the more intimate relationships that Vol. 2 builds. 

However you come at this film, I am fairly certain that most viewers will end up having a really good time with it. I know my theater never stopped laughing through the entire thing, and that says a lot. It film is uber violent on the surface, but sentimental and heartfelt underneath. it takes a sort of self-aware approach to the over-the-top space opera, but it also knows how to inject it all with something that feels very relatable and down to earth. It is full of humor, but it also wants to give us some touching moments that will stick with us. And while it doesn't do all of this perfectly, I think it does it all admirably. Well worth a viewing if you ask me.

Writer/ Director James Gunn's "Guardians of the Galaxy" from 2014 (wow, that was fast) is not only the best entry in Marvel's box office-busting Cinematic Universe in my opinion; it's one of my favorite films of this decade full stop. Gunn's hand-made aesthetic and an ever-present love for his characters and source material (along with stunning technical merits, gorgeous effects and color palette, game cast, and perfect comedic timing) cemented "Guardians" as the pleasant surprise of the year and a bonafide critical smash. Expectations were justifiably sky high for a follow up, then in steps "Vol.2." 

Luckily Gunn and co. stick the landing with only some leg wobble. Yeah, much of the surprise is gone. We know these characters and we know the quirks. But the characters are still fun to be around and the quirks a joy to roll with in an MCU of near endless iterations and routines. Most satisfying, the ensemble of outcasts (our heroes) have evolved from the last outing. Rocket isn't just comedic relief. Baby Groot isn't overused. Drax is as giddy as a hyena. If Starlord isn't as charming or charismatic as the last time it's because his relationship with his father, Ego (Kurt Russell), is the dramatic center of the show. Gamora is underutilized but her subplot with her sister Nebula hit home. Most surprising is Yondu (Michael Rooker); who is given so much depth and emotional gravitas that he emerges as the most memorable aspect of the film... and maybe even the single best thing about this installment. 

Unlike it's predecessor, "Vol.2" is a comedy first, and a space opera second. This is a bit of a problem, especially in the first act. Vol.1 used humor to spice up a believable sci-fi world and awesome characters. Here, it feels forced: notably in a first half hour that's part franchise reintroduction and part stand-up routine. The comedy does become less scattershot however, as does it's relatively lose (and sometimes distractedly unfocused) plot, the further into the running time we get. Equally unfocused is the development of Ego, Peter Quill's father, who is seminal to the plot. I always love Kurt Russell, and he's as solid as ever here. I just wish so much of his role didn't involve lengthy exposition. 

But like "Vol.1," Guardians 2 is a brilliant piece of visual film making. The colors pop, the action's exciting, and Gunn infuses all of this with his now signature handmade, fanboy energy. There are also moments of pure joy and heart that rival (if not surpass) the best bits of the first film. The final half hour or so is pure bliss. We are still firmly in the upper echelon of summer blockbusters with this one.

Many were expecting perfection with this one... expectations that could possibly be never met. But "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2" delivers a brash, funny, action-packed delight that's hard to knock. It's heart is in the right place. It's characters? More than welcome for the inevitable "Round 3."
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is funny and action-packed thanks to its slick pacing, dazzling visuals, engaging action sequences and charming performances from its entire cast.

Though the movie may lack some of the freshness of the first one, it still maintains that movie's scrappy wit and irreverent sense of fun. Director/writer Gunn injects the movie with visual dazzle and a surprising amount of emotional depth, thanks to a talented and committed cast. Mix in some exciting action sequences, another vibrant soundtrack and you get an entertaining blend of summer movie escapism.

El denominado Vol.2 nos demuestra el "marvel way" de hacer cine de hoy en día, cuando se supondría que estamos ante una película de superheroes nos topamos practicamente ante una comedia sobrecargada pasando por chistes pésimos, malos, buenos y ...nadamás. Y es que cuando debería estarnos contando una aventura que colaborara a la cacareada fase 3, tal parece que se prestó para el relleno simplón. Durante el transitar de las acciones uno esta a la expectativa de que la trama se asimile de una u otra manera y esto nunca sucede, la trama navega en el origen de Starlord, dejando de lado a el resto de personajes sin desarrollarlos dignamente. Los motivos de la trama son un tanto obtusos, con un villano plano sin carisma y mientras Starlord divaga en sus asuntos, asistimos a una pelea de hermanas, situación comica, otra situación de comedia y sí... otra más. No podemos dejar de mencionar que el film entero esta colgado en el bebé Groot como si de una película de pixar se tratara al grado de que si anularamos al personaje de la película probablemente quedaría sin estímulo para el público al que va netamente dirigido.
 En fin, se rescatan aquellos momentos reconocibles del universo Marvel ya sea visuales o de inspiración histórica y la amenidad de corte familiar para manejar los hechos, efectos visuales así como la siempre funcional música.
 Los Guardianes ya estaban presentados al público, lo habían logrado e innovado y Gunn perdió la oportunidad de darles un desarrollo digno y cohesivo con este universo en esta fase vital, incandose servilmente a la clasificación infantil.

Gaurdians 2 might well amount to Marvels biggest, weirdest movie to date, it's not quite as new and effortless as the first movie, indeed it forces those elements that made the original so wonderfully unusual, the Cool soundtrack, irreverent humour, and anarchic attitude feel less natural, like the film is struggling for that same vibe, trying a bit too hard to uncork that bottle of lightening. It can too be said that the film sadly falls victim to a number of the narrative and aesthetic crimes of the modern blockbuster, namely the plot is a little unfocused and a bit too freewheeling (though not crowded feeling, bludgeoning and overindulged, and thats an important distinction because thats what makes these big films feel fucking exhausting to watch these days) and the other misstep, a thing that happens more and more now is where the last half hour of these films descends into computer generated chaos, where all sense, weight and meaning disappears amid an insane maelstrom of pixelated nonsense that doesn't feel tethered to anything, it feels like these movies are almost obliged to become a big "lets all race to stop the big thing that destroys stuff" type ending. That sadly is the case here, the longer the film goes on the more over the top everthing becomes and the more you want it to just calm the fuck down and stop trying to appeal to the ADD kids in the audience who simply love all the bright, swirling colours. But im being a little bit of a dick here, because Gaurdians 2 is a joy, it's not quite the first movie but if anything is even bigger and crazier and more outlandish. The science fiction is more rich and imaginative, and there are truly awe inspiringly odd and beautiful things to behold (Egos planet is a wonder, like a 70's album cover come to life)  director James Gunn clearly being given licence to go full on mushroom fulled drug trippiness with his crazy on screen universe, and theres even a looser more ragged feel to it, especially when it settles down to simply give us time with these terrific bunch of dysfunctional tearaways (Drax is the movie stealer once again, but dialled up a notch, Dave Bautista is truly hilarious) the real attention grabber here is the legendary Kurt Russell, gloriously channelling his 80's persona into living planet Ego, he is a total joy, every bit the Kurt of Big Trouble In Little China or Escape From New York, that wonderful glint always in his steely blue eyes, he appears as youthful and vital as he ever has here and it's a true pleasure to see the beloved cult superstar just swagger around, owning the joint, that Jack Burton cheekiness radiating off him (yes im clearly in love with the man, deal). Notable too is just how damn adorable Baby Groot is, he's the source of many laughs and some off the most standout moments (including an opening set to Mr Blue Sky by ELO, that nearly matches the Come And Get Your Love opening of the first) i feel Marvel separating themsleves more and more from formula in movies like this, i mean theres still that adherence here and there, the whole "foil the villains nefarious, galaxy threatening plot, save the day" is still the fall back, but even so it's done here in a more off kilter "Gaurdians" way. There's also heart a plenty, even a few moments that might bring a quivering tear to your eye or two. In a world going to hell, i think we need more heart and humour and hope, and this movie gives you all this in droves, i think we might be needing some more soon. Oh yeah, theres a theme tune sung by Hasselhoff , how fucking great is that?

The film gives off minimum plot but gains massive occurences with regards to the story.

Apparently, it did make it up to the standard that the predecessor sets up, but with its familiarity, a little predictive storyline and sub-plots makes a huge loop hole. The guardians never did get a huge team work as what they've done from the first one, making them rambunctious all over the movie but deliberately gives 'em their own spotlight. GOTG vol. 2 gives as much for what 'action-comedy' entertainment is. It is indeed familiar but never a cliché. That apparently, is why it gained its unique quirky traits as authentic as the first one is; making Guardians Of The Galaxy vol. 2 a memorable sequel.

It also seems like everyone in the film has family issues this time around, not only does Peter want to find his dad, Gamora and Nebula have a sister bonding moment, Rocket and Yondu have a similar moment together and then there is the soppy one at the end. Also, is it just me or is everyone practically invincible in this film? Sometimes they fall 20-30 stories and just land on their feet and keep running, I get it's a marvel film but it took away the element of danger you felt for the characters. Last but not least, there were so many moments in the film that were simply convenient, fallen down a massive hole with no way up, don't worry, the rocks around you will start floating to the surface all of a sudden...broken your metal fin thing that goes on your head? It gets away with some pretty violent sequences for a PG-13 film, making it feel more like a James Gunn film than his previous installments. There are a tad bit too many scenes where the guardians get a little too touchy-feely with their emotions and Drax is trying too hard to be funny with his quips, where as what made him funny in the last film was his character's lack of humor. Rocket Racoon is more of a stand out character in this one to me but Michael Rooker also delivered in a very unexpected way towards the end. Kurt Russell is a great addition, but his powers along with Chris Pratt's new found powers develop into an over the top climax that went a little overboard. Overall, I appreciate the amount of heart Gunn put into this script and the parts that work make up for the parts that did not.

WOW!! In a nutshell it's spectacular fun! I literally smiled and laughed out loud from start to finish.  The initial credit scene is pure joy. The camera work by James Gunn will leave you stunned and the FX are incredible, but it's baby Groot who steals the show with some dance floor moves while the battle rages behind them.  That opening sets the scene for what's to come and it's flawless!!

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is an extremely fun and entertaining movie. The cast is as great as usual. Chris Pratt is great, and Baby Groot is adorable. Other highlights include Michael Rooker as Yondu and Kurt Russell as Ego. Karen Gillan overdoes it as Nebula again. She isn't terrible, but she's the weakest link in the film. The film is a whole lot of fun. I laughed out loud numerous times. The action is exciting if at times overwhelming. The film also has a nice emotional core to it. The effects are amazing. I saw the film in IMAX 3D, and it was stunning. The film doesn't really have a plot, but it still entertains. The plot is does have is still really good. There is a whole lot more I want to write, but I don't want to spoil the movie. Overall, this is an overwhelming success. It matches the first film, and even succeeds it in some ways. I highly recommend this film for anyone who is looking to have fun and enjoy themselves.

Una película pasada de chistosa... En la primera mitad de retrasa un poco el conflicto para darnos una especie de sit-com espacial, lo cual hace que las carcajadas sean imparables. Ya en la segunda mitad cuando se revela el gran villano la trama cobra mucha fuerza y hace que esta secuela esté a la altura de la original. 

Recuerden que hay 5 escenas post créditos, las cuales muestran que el Vol 3 va a ser realmente épico.

Se puede notar que mejoraron el desarrollo de personajes, y de una manera brutal, teniendo la empatia que debíamos tener con ellos en la primera película, siendo Drax y Gamora los personajes los que les sentó mejor este cambio en su personalidad. Y en lo malo, solo puedo ver que durante unas escenas que se dividen los dos grupos durante la película, hay momentos que se pueden poner un tanto pesados para el publico, pero pasaran rápido, ya que la película explota y se luce en su más propio estilo que se hizo característico en su predecesora. Y me gusto el villano de esta pelicula.

Pero si me preguntan que si es mejor o peor que la primera, yo la veo de la misma calidad, pero tocando otros temas para expande y conocer más el universo de los Guardianes de la Galaxia.

Y hay que reconocer que esos créditos son una genialidad para que los espectadores se queden hasta el final de los créditos, aunque no sean escenas que marquen un gran cambio a Marvel.

EPIC! The much anticipated Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2 lived up to expectations. Not easy, given how the Marvel films are constantly upping the ante in the delivery and keep setting new benchmarks. It was highly entertaining, and hilarious. It's a notch up from Vol 1, now packed with more characters that you know will play a part in the bigger Marvel Cinematic Universe. Despite its adrenalin packed visuals, it was surprisingly emotional and touching. I think many will come away from the film touched by the idea and meaning of family. I felt a choke in my throat when Yondu said, "he may be your father, but he was never your daddy."  Loving the way this film is uniquely woven by the 80's music that runs from Quill's cassette in his walkman. Love Groot. Love Hasselhoff. Great casting. Most of all, am very impressed with director, James Gunn who capably pulls this off.

The first one was nearly a perfect movie, this one fall a bit short, but it's still really good. I once said that Guardians Of The Galaxy is my favourite comic book movie of all time. This is not an especially bold statement, considering it's nowhere near my favourite genre, but Guardians was breezily paced, aesthetically brilliant, infinitely likeable and drew more laughs out of me than any movie I'd seen in ages. So I walked into GOTG 2 with a lot of hope. In short, it's fantastic. James Gun has taken his quirky, mismatched quintet of contrasting personalities and pushed them all further than ever before. The actors have lost nothing since the last instalment, clearly very comfortable in their white/green/grey and red/furry/wooden skin. Not one of them is left without a conflict, and all are compelling in one way or another. I don't think the structure is as tight as the first one, and the father-son storyline didn't interest me as much as the story of how the Guardians came together in the first place, and the 3rd act is pretty bloody busy, but for over 2 hours the filmmakers deliver everything that we loved about the original. Witty one liners, relatable heroes, stunning space battles, gorgeous foreign worlds, the constant subversion of heavily tense and dramatic scenes with sprinkles of unexpected comedy, and do I even need to talk about how great the soundtrack is? GOTG2 may have a hard time matching its predecessor, but it never feels weak or like it's slumming. It's got laughs, drama, high emotional stakes, toe-tapping songs, and Kurt Russell. What more could you possibly want?

The drawback is that Kurt Russell isn't given enough to illustrate his motives and the gold people are kind of used as a maguffin needlessly taking away from the other characters, but overall the film is as good if not better than the original, the music is also used better in this film.

Leave it to Disney Marvel to make me dislike Kurt Russell. In "generic Marvel comic book movie: issue 57", the sentinels of the stars have a bunch of 1970's radio staples litter the John Williams-lite soundtrack. There's gratuitous murder of multicolored anthropoids (with quips). They double down on the psychedelic overload, and there are more evocations of the importance of family than the latest "Fast and the Furious" franchise feature. Let's not forget all of the snarky moments from the trailer! Really, the only enjoyable part of the film is the sardonic punchlines. You know everything is going to be fine, relegating everything in the film to, at best, a great episode of "Doctor Who" and, at worst, a normal episode of "American Dad". Aside from the few laugh out loud moments, I am at a loss for positive things to say about the film. It is a middle-of-the-road kids movie. There is hardly a story, and what little plot there is is in service of the headache-inducing CG set pieces. Can you really call them set pieces if the scenes are just strobing colors and crumbling rocks? I'll admit it: I'm done with comic book movies. For anyone who isn't a man-child (or an actual child), the only good watch you will get out of this is a Clockwork Orange-style, eye-lid free acid trip while listening to Monster Magnet's "Ego, the Living Planet" on a non-stop loop. It is better than "Thor" 1 and 2, "Iron Man" 1-3, "The Avengers", and especially "Ant Man", but that's not saying much.

4 Stars: The A-holes of the galaxy are back in a cinema near you and doing what you want them to do... and that's make you leave the cinema with a grin. This time after the events of Vol.1 they're established as trouble shouters for hire. Starting with a job having to protect some batteries (but not Duracell). The movie first act is primary a gag fest. Joke after joke, some great, some not so and of cause the music. Where the first volume was team building, this is all centred around family, even when the family is as dysfunctional as these guys. Drax (Dave Bautista) steals any scenes his in, though Baby Groot comes a close second. Again at the very start Marvel use some great effects to make a certain start look like his 1980s self. The second third is a look at the various team members stories and around Quill (Chris Pratt) true parentage. The final act is the big bad(s) reveal and the team trying to clean up the mess. This is a film to go see with a crowd who can laugh together at the various misadventures of these team of (as the admit) A-holes. Watch out for Stan lee who make a few appearances in this. Once again you'll want to hang around for the 4 err was it 5 scenes (?) (actually I lost count) post credit bits. Basically stick around to the end and yes they are coming back. So go to the cinema with the biggest screen now, come on you know you want to.

"Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2" is better than "Guardians of the Galaxy". There I said it. Yes it really is that good. The best Marvel movie in ages. 
All the ingredients that made the first instalment are present and correct but this time the story carries much more emotional weight which adds a gravitas to proceedings. The characters are a joy to watch, the script is hilarious, the visuals are superb but the one thing that makes "Vol 2" stand out is that it has a heart. 
At its core it's a film about family. You feel for this strange bunch of crazy characters and that is testimony to the brilliant script from writer director James Gunn.
It's a joy from start to finish, I was never bored and it's never felt tired or cliched even though there are elements that we've all seen before. Baby Groot is the standout star and his moments are some of the funniest in the film. 
The magic is still there, the gangs all here and by doing something different and original Marvel remains way ahead of its competitors.

Guardians of the Galaxy is exactly what the Marvel Cinematic Universe needed in 2014. It was something that introduced the more sci-fi elements, yes, but also something that broke the superhero fatigue, at least temporarily. Sure, there have been Marvel moments that feel unique: Thor 2's climactic subway chase taking on a Bug Bunny-esque madcap style, The Winter Soldier's surveillance paranoia. But Guardians of the Galaxy felt more like Star Wars than Iron Man 4, taking a ragtag crew and letting them hop around a universe that had no restraint in reality, or even preconceived mythology given their relative obscurity to figures like Thor. And everything clicked for it, from its well-tuned cast that benefited from just-pre-superstardom surprise turns from Chris Pratt and Dave Bautista, its colorfully constructed universe, its memorable quasi-irreverent soundtrack, and the instantly iconic Groot.

When the marketing cycle for Vol. 2 started, there was immediately reason for concern. Not because these elements were missing, but because the trailers seemed to lean into these elements incredibly hard. Liked Drax being obtuse? We'll focus the first clip released of precisely that. That Baby Groot dance everyone loved at the end of the first? You bet he's going to be everywhere in trailers being all adorable and stuff. Looking for '80s hits? We'll release the soundtrack in a bag of Dorito's to make sure you hear them. Looking for references to Night Rider? Fuck it, we'll have David Hasselhoff on the soundtrack. For something that was a breath of fresh air three years ago, everything looked pretty stale.

It's no surprise that Vol. 2 delivers on these items, for good and for bad. What does come as a surprise is that, rather than build on the previous film to make a tighter experience, Vol. 2 is a much looser film, both stylistically and plot-wise, than maybe any other movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. It very much feels like the Marvel execs put their complete faith in director James Gunn, as the DNA of his previous films Super and especially Slither is all over Vol. 2. Vol. 2 is nearly a best-case scenario in giving a genre auteur a whole bunch of money and telling him to have fun, and as a result Vol. 2 wears influences from Star Wars (obviously) to The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (hilariously inventing and immediately exploiting the rules of its universe) to The Thing (magnificently nearing body horror more than once). Taika Watiti's Thor Ragnarok has a chance of pulling a similar trick soon, and Joss Whedon's The Avengers clearly had his fingerprints all over it, but Vol. 2 is the rare MCU film that feels more like a creator's vision than a brand obligation, even more so than its predecessor. In a way, it feels more like Darkman than Iron Man, which at this point is a very good thing.

As for the old characters, there it is a bit more mixed. Drax is probably the biggest victim of sequel fatigue, as the surprise of discovering that character's quirks was a big part of the pleasure in the first. There are no new dimensions to Drax here, so the gags involving him simply aren't as surprising. Baby Groot, on the other hand, is an absolute treasure. Sure, he's adorable, and the kids in the audience loved him, but he's often used as a vehicle for considerably darker humour than expected. As for the others, Gamora is generally a bit wasted, and Quill is a bit less of a wise-ass thanks to his position in the plot, but Michael Rooker's Yondu is brought back to great effect, and Rocket Raccoon is still a lot of fun. On the new front, Kurt Russell's Ego is a slithery presence, oozing that old-school cool in fitting with the 80s stylings. Considering the general failure of MCU villains to make any impression, Russell is top-tier. Even the secondary villains, a race of genetically engineered bourgeoisie, are a ton of fun and would have been interesting enough to carry their own movie if called upon to. 

Plotwise, Vol. 2 is focused on family, especially the bond between fathers/father-figures and sons, but extending to sibling relationships and, of course, teams. While there's plenty of boilerplate talk about the Guardians being one big family, the film overall nicely focuses on relationships between two people, putting together as many combos as possible and examining their familial stance. Sure, Quill/Gamora comes back up, and Quill/Ego is all over the trailers, but the film finds some depth in the bipartite relationships between Quill, Yondu, and Rocket Raccoon, even giving Yondu a father figure of his own, and further explores the Gamora/Nebula sisterhood to surprising effect. Yes, it does boil down to a dastardly plot eventually, but it avoids magicla MacGuffins like infinity stones or whatever and ties its developments into actual, believable character interactions.

But more than anything else, Vol. 2 is stock full of a few deliriously fun setpieces. The final battle goes on for about ten minutes longer than it should have, but the opening scene beautifully sets up a major battle only to have it occur out of focus in the background, while a fight involving Yondu, Rocket, and a horde of space pirates can only be described as a beautiful composed spree of violence. Throughout these sequences, Vol. 2 is willing to be completely cartoony, which weirdly makes it a standout among superhero movies. It takes risks, and is sure to dismissed as dumb by some, but it entertains in ways that are novel for a film of this budget and scale. It successfully transplants low-budget cult-horror visuals and ideas to the biggest budget scale there is, and is by a huge margin the best future midnight-movie in the MCU. Bring on Volume 3.

I should begin this review by stating that I am far from an MCU fanboy, and find many of the series' instalments adequate, but far from stellar. This is a feeling I largely held until the original 'Guardians of the Galaxy' arrived - a fun, fresh and funny addition to this cinematic universe, with a genuinely likable cast. In short, it was, by far, one of my favourite films in the franchise at the time.

Before sitting down to watch 'Volume 2', I was excited, yet sceptical. Whilst early reviews were positive, they all assured me that it was not as good as the first, and in some places a retreat of its predecessor. Having seen it, I am inclined to agree, but more of the same is far from a complaint.

Firstly, to focus on the plot. It achieves many staples of a good sequel. It expands on the universe (a lot!), develops the characters, and improves upon its predecessor (which is the case here, in places). I was worried, judging from the trailers, that the film may be trying to show more than it had time for, but fortunately, this was not the case. Instead, it introduces us to new races and organisations in the universe, making it seem like a much larger place that appeared in the original. The characters are well- developed here, and the relationships between them are clear and concise, however, the majority of time was allocated to Chris Pratt's Star-Lord, and whilst the rest of the cast did have decent screen time, it is clear that they were not the priority here, despite the all-round stellar performances.

Secondly, the soundtrack returns and is as glorious as ever. The use of music felt more frequent that in the previous film, and could prove a little unnecessary at times, but overall, the song choice was impeccable, and in some cases had a real relevance to the events unfolding on screen. The inclusions of Cat Steven's 'Father and Son', as well as Fleetwood Mac's 'The Chain', were very welcome.

The humour was another standout of the first film, and delivers here in droves. It often hits, but the frequency and unresting presence of jokes can ruin the more sentimental or serious moments in the film - causing a wavering tone that isn't quite sure which way to turn. Despite this, I can say that in my opinion, this was the most emotionally impactful film in the MCU to date, due to investment in the characters and how likable they are.

In conclusion, this film was a satisfying follow-up to the original, and I would struggle to determine which of the two is superior. The characters are as engaging as ever, the set pieces are glorious (despite a heavy reliance on CGI, rendered beautifully). The soundtrack is possibly better than the first (perhaps a little overused, but quality nevertheless), and the humour is largely on-point, but can be very in your face and ruin emotionally significant moments. All in all, this is worth a watch, and I will definitely be coming back to it once it is released on home video.

Guardians of the Galaxy was an inspiring film with an excellent story line filled with excitement, light hearted fun, humour, pace, inspiring CGI and fabulous characters. I loved it! Fast forward to 2017 and the eagerly anticipated sequel.....OMG agonising poor, I had lost the will to live after 30 minutes and wondered if the storyline had been crafted on the back of a postage stamp. All the positive elements of the original were quashed under a raft of motion blur CGI, calculated bad humour, excessive violence and predictable soulless characters. I watched in disbelief, mid film at the self indulgent "let's play catch" energy ball scene between Starlord and Ego! I was ready to walk, but remained seated bearing in mind that I had just shelled out £40 notes for the family. Consensus from our small band of travellers, all of which are avid Guardians fans.....we had just witnessed the ruin inaction of a classic film. I am sure the zombie masses will love it and will beg for more of the same........

Inevitably, this film can only be judged as a continuation of the excellent first part, and it is a very decent continuation, despite the difficulty of generating many surprises when the characters are fundamentally the same.  A tiny bit too long and sentimental, the film relies more on jokes than on plot fore its best moments, but there are a few worthy efforts around the themes of family, fatherhood and sisterhood - yet nothing particularly novel in the universe of Hollywood and Disney.  The romance between Quill and Gamora  does not advance much either. Still, the spirit of the first film is there, quite intact, and the music and the humor save the day again and again (not so the imagery, too often over the top). Special mentions for two characters, Drax, by far the most effective at making us laugh, and super cute baby Groot.

"Overall, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 isn't better than the first one, but it stays true to my expectations. The whole movie is hilarious, the cast has an unbelievable chemistry and Michael Rooker steals the show from Chris Pratt, who also has a great performance. The visuals are stunning, the action set pieces are good and the soundtrack keeps being awesome. However, there are some issues: the pacing is off, the comedy becomes forced, Karen Gillan is the worst part of the film, even if the Nebula-Gamora subplot is interesting, and the main story isn't as captivating as it should be since the supporting characters are terribly misused."

Slightly disappointed by this film if I'm honest. My expectations where high as the first was so unexpected, funny and successful at introducing these characters, so this film was always going to have a tough task to be an improvement. It's by no means a bad film, but when compared to the first it's not quite on the same level. This is probably funnier than the first, but story wise it's lacking a bit and the action is largely a CGI fest - with some of it being a bit cartoonish. All the existing characters were good and baby Groot steals most scenes he's in. The gold characters you see in the trailer didn't really work for me and they're in it a fair bit as the antagonists - so the film suffers a bit when they're on screen. There are also 5 after credits scenes, with one in particular being very funny with Groot. Enjoyable film overall.

Marvel is back with their first 2017 movie! I went into the cinema very excited to see more of the 'Guardians of the Galaxy', however I came out feeling a similar feeling after seeing Avengers 2. Don't get me wrong, the characters were as fantastic as ever, the jokes kept coming and the soundtrack worked very well with the action (unlike Suicide Squad's attempt to use Bohemian Rhapsody). But aside to this, the plot was a bit boring. While the standout moments were with Rocket, Groot and Yondu, they served very little to the overall plot. The other characters suffer as the plot revolves around Quill and his father, who was very well played by a still great Kurt Russell.

I'm not saying this movie was bad, in fact it is one of the much better Marvel movies. It has one of the best developed villains in the whole MCU (well kept secret in the trailers). On the other hand, the pacing was a bit muddled and the balancing between the characters wasn't great. Very enjoyable, but not as outstanding as its predecessor.

What happened?. Well that have introduced characters with the pretense of giving more fluency to the film, but has not been effective, there are some things that have no importance, etc ... The most surprising is the appearance of Stallone, although it appears as a cameo, But at least it is the same movie as the first one, as it is still entertaining, but it seems that it is the ones that have to be seen better on television. I feel like a drone. Every year Marvel comes out with its new set of movies and every year like drones we all go out to see them. And for this reason Marvel makes tons of $$$ without any quality improvement or originality, because as drones, we all just gobble it up. It's like we have been given a command: "This year you will see the following movies and not hold them to any standard, kapeesh!!" 
And so this year, the cycle begins with us giving our money to Guardians of the Galaxy V2. Expect nothing more than what the trailer has to offer. Or see the first one again and it'll be the same as seeing V2, you'll just save money. The story does advance with Kurt Russell starring as Starlord's dad. Kind of a rehash of "No/Luke....I am your father." It's good when they hire good actors. Make-up and special effects are great. But in all, I wouldn't use the words "enjoyable" or "exciting." I'll just say, "Ritual completed, onto the next superhero movie." Hey I'm a victim here nonetheless. I'm not criticizing people for seeing Guardians, as I also did, but I'm getting to get critical of us who every year, dish out our money for these superhero movies, which are in fact not becoming any better in quality, and studio execs thinking that they are creating masterpieces because of the gross $$$, hence thereforth making no extra effort to make a better movie. Guardians of the Galaxy 2 is a strong followup to a surprise hit. I'll begin with the score, it was all absolutely immaculate. The tone of the movie is carried on the back of the brilliant score, much like the previous film. But where the previous film lacked any significant character arcs for our protagonists or a fully formed villian, this does not. Kurt Russel and Chris Pratt work well together on screen and the rest of the cast carry their roles very well. Bradley Cooper as Rocket kills it throughout with some marvellous voice acting and Dave Bautista delivered consistently solid one-liners. The movie is slightly let down by a very strange editing decision, pulling away from a dramatic scene seemingly just because we hadn't seen the other characters in a little while. I didn't buy into baby groot who is very clearly made to be as sweet as treacle for the marketing. All in all i don't think that the third act will hold up as much as previous marvel entries due to the high emotional stakes which once explored can't be re-learned.As a film-goer i walked out of this film buzzing with my mate about the scenes and jokes we enjoyed. And that's important. It's why we all see movies. All in all the jokes landed, the action was packed and the music was divine.

It seems Marvel is getting rather tired. With the story being a cheap version of The Empire Strikes Back, the humour that seems like a parody of the original, and despite all of the explosions it gives us (and way too much motion blur) the movie still goes out with a wimper.

This is almost on-par with its predecessor, with improvements in its visuals, its humour and its terrific villain. There is a great soundtrack to boast that doesn't feel like it is over-dominating the film. The central theme of family is refreshing, however it suffers from being slightly disjointed in its plot, and seems to be more focused on the humour than the film. But there are great emotional moments that are both unexpected and rewarding, and the new characters add to the fun of the film. Overall, another great flick!

Review. 
So here are my thoughts on Guardians of the Galaxy 2. 
WOW!!!! In a nutshell it's spectacular fun. I literally smiled and laughed out loud from start to finish. The opening shot/scene is sublime and it seems the reverse age CGI FX technology has reached a whole new level. I won't say too much but when you see it, you'll know.  The initial credit scene is pure joy. As the credits crank you're treated to a huge fight between the guardians and a giant space monster. The camera work by James Gunn will leave you stunned and the FX are incredible but it's baby Groot who steals the show with some dance floor moves while the battle rages behind him that's so fucking cool your jaw will be on the floor. That opening sets the scene for what's to come and it's flawless!!! 
The plot is awesome. The whole cast are having a ball and like I said earlier the FX this time round are nothing short of phenomenal. There's amazing banter between them all and Rocket is funny as fuck. Kurt Russell is great and Michael Rooker has a bigger role as Yondo and has a great time playing the part too. 
With the first Guardians film, James Gunn captured lightening in a bottle and the film was an amazing experience. I'm here to tell you guys that James Gunn has done it again. Guardians of the Galaxy 2 is a fun, joyful and spectacular ride. You will NOT be disappointed by this movie. It's as good as the first one if not slightly better and it's definitely in my top 2 Marvel movies. With Thor:Ragnarok and Spider-Man: Homecoming arriving later this year the Marvel juggernaut keeps rolling on with no sign of stopping and I can't freaking wait. Guardians 2 - 10/10

After waiting 3 years to see this gem, and knowing that a Third installment is already on the way, this film (in my mind) could not have been better. I saw Volume 1 when I was in a dark place (emotionally and mentally, but blah blah blah, whatever), and it really helped he out in the simplest way - it made me laugh. It might seem like an overly simple purpose for a film to have, but Guardians 1 (and now Vol. 2) go way beyond this. Not only are they both stellar examples of original, creative ways of engaging audiences, but also too they dare to go deeper than other Marvel films ever have. On the surface the films are deceivingly light and humorous, but under that the raw emotions of some very real characters can be seen, and the evolution of their relationships with each other are more than fascinating . A magical combination of brilliant script-writing by James Gunn, amazing casting and a famously well-chosen soundtrack, not to mention a stunningly delicious panoply of colour and bold CGI effects are the ingredients that make up this 21st century masterpiece of a film. This perhaps is a biased opinion, given my emotional connection with this franchise, but nonetheless, this film is to be cherished and admired for its bravery in going to new places for an audience ready and waiting to see another surprising Gunn feature. Special mentions must be given to Sean Gunn and Pom Klementieff for their outstanding performances - their roles were unique and their acting superbly appropriate.
Biased, I know, but an outstanding feature regardless. Highly recommended for all to see.

Other studios can try to emulate the shared universe formula, but none have the sight and sensibility to deal with their source material like Kevin Feige and Marvel Studios do. Many will undoubtedly dislike the lack of surprise from the first movie, and in regards to that I will say this: while the first movie was to introduce these characters and come up with ways to unite them, this one is to explore them and come up with ways to keep them together. All returning characters get insights adding dimension to them, which unfortunately backfires at least once when the movie decides to jump from one drama scene to the other without much variety (action, for example) in between. This happens specifically on the second act.

A person that doesn't remember everything about the first movie and how it ended will get lost easily, but someone who does and enjoyed the characters in that movie will find it a great experience when all characters get these new insights along with great acting (although new characters Mantis, Ayesha and Taserface could've used more deepness, unlike those core ones). It's undoubtly more about family and visual wonder than the first one, with particularly memorable scenes often enhanced by songs from the great Awesome Mix Vol 2.

Let's be honest: you can't repeat a big surprise. And the sequel to she smash hit does have scenes that feel a bit like playing it safe, repeating ideas that worked in part one. Thankfully, overall this is never a mere copy. And it takes some guts to pause all action and concentrate on no less than three slow character building scenes in the middle of the film. It turns out that's working great for the characters and is one of the main reasons why the final act works fantastically. It pushes all the right emotional buttons (hehe) and ultimately makes for a deeply touching ending, redeeming some of the superficially funny parts of the beginning. Great cameos and Easter eggs for Marvel fans complete the picture. Not as outstanding as the first part, but still great. And what a pleasant surprise that the big winner of the film is neither Rocket nor Groot after all.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 throws you right back into the world of the MCUs hottest space crew, and plays like an action sitcom, which unfortunately is a bit much from the very start. Its plot picks up from there, but the story is heavy on exposition and kind of all over the place, which makes it feel like the movie has no structure at all. Still, the movie is smart, funny, the visuals are great, the characters are just as good as you expect them to be, and the overall film is just a fun ride and a hilarious experience.

A very fun action packed film that follows up the original unexpected hit in fantastic style. The film builds on the enjoyable characters of the first, with baby Groot stealing the show throughout. Kurt Russell brings energy and style to the role of Peters father, handling the somewhat hokey exposition dialogue well, as he explains his life and purpose. The idea of a planet as Star Lords father was one to wait for, and it works quite well. The rest of the cast are in fine form and appear comfortable in their roles the second time around. The film does sag a little in the middle and it felt like it borrowed a quite a bit of imagery from other films, especially Star Trek in its character designs, Man of Steel for its father explaining his history sequence and even the film Evolution, for the moments when Ego spreads across the various planets. I thought they should have tried some head and shoulders shampoo on the advancing alien mass

Guardians Of The Galaxy 2 Spoiler Free Full Review.
 It is to my strong belief that most people will prefer the first one over this one... but I don't. I like both almost equally but the GOTG2 just nudges it out slightly. It's kinda the James Gunn movie I wanted from the first one. It want all in on the comedy and wackyness. But! It does compromise the plot but honestly almost all Marvel movies have shitty plots so it was great that it really didn't care to tell the story in a coherent way and focused in on the fun. It's comepletly scrapped the boring mcguffin style plot of the first one and went for something more character driven. The movie works great as a collection of scenes where you just have fun with a bunch enjoyable characters and my good is the comedic timing perfect most of the time. There's two super long dragged out still shot joke (Similar to the "planning the breakout"-scene in the first one) that is pure perfection. It also handles the tone shifts alot better and it's the best looking movie Marvel made, they thrown away the washed out look and gone for full contrasty and deep black images with a high dynamic range. I even wanna rewatch it in 3D. They even nailed how to make all the scenes look and feel cool incomaprison to the first GOTG which ended with them standing in a line holding a stone.
What's bad? Well, the music wasn't as well handled this time. They didn't feel as natural as the first one. There is alot of stuff going on and cutting back and forth between events so the casual fan might be unable to follow what is happening and get into all the characters. There are scenes that are even too corny for GOTG but hey they where in the first one. The use of Slowmotion during dramatic scenes was cheesy in a bad none selfaware way. As mentioned the plot is a mess but whatever anyone who watches a Marvel movie for the story doesn't know what a good story is. The first 1/3 kinda feels like arguing the movie and for fuck sake Hollywood can we stop having characters spell out the main theme of the story right in direct dialogue for the audience. We are not dumb, stop stating the fucking obvious. If they didn't pay enough attention in the movie to get it that's their own problem.
All in all. GOTG2 did things better then GOTG1 but it also does thing worse then GOTG1. Thus they are about equal. Which one you prefer is honestly just up to what kind of experience you are looking for.
In my case I'ts going to be this one.

Really wanted to enjoy this more than I did, unfortunately it was pretty disappointing.

Reducing the characters behaviour to that of children all the time sure sets up a few lazy jokes, but it doesn't exactly leave you much room for real character development or well developed storylines.

I don't want to spoil it too much for those who don't know, but changing Quill's father from his father in the comics also makes very little sense. A significant portions of Guardians of the Galaxy plot-lines are driven by Quill's *on-going* interactions with his enormous jerk of a father.

There are plenty of other significant changes to the characters from the comics e.g. Drax being officially an alien (he's actually human, sort of, in the comics). I don't mind the back-stories being simplified for the movies, but Guardians of the Galaxy was already one of the most accessible comics out there and has only been around since 2008. It's not like many of Marvel's other assets, where characters were created over 50 years ago and in need of an overhaul to remain relevant. Changing the characters may not have been a huge issue if their motivations were replaced, rather than simply omitted, which is the case. Comic book characters aren't exactly renowned for being well rounded, but wow, the ones on screen in Guardians of the Galaxy vol. 2 are unbearably shallow. They no longer have any reasonable back-stories or motivations to behave the way they behave - the only character who seems reasonably on-point is Rocket - being as simple as he is, he's pretty hard to mess up.

Gamora has changed quite a bit from the comics. Without Marvel Cinematic Universe having access to X-men, and hence Kitty Pryde, her interactions with Quill are one of the few changes that actually makes sense. But ah, what's the deal with making all the bad guys into good guys? This isn't a 90s feel-good flick, is it? Way to just throw a whole bunch of story-lines down the drain. Combine that with the removal of J'son and you've really gone and screwed over future writers quite a bit. I'd hate to be involved in Adam Warlock at this point!

Somehow, for an action flick, the action is too mindless and boring, even for a Marvel action flick. Sure the film looks good, and there's a few okay one-liners in there. However, as a whole it's hugely disappointing given how much potential Guardians of the Galaxy had. I would have thought Deadpool opened the door for humour, adult themes, and reasonably in-depth characters to co-exist in super hero films... Apparently not.

How do you follow up  a movie that surprised everyone when the first one came out with how great it was but left so many unanswered questions? Well you answer the questions. 

Vol.2 follows up where the first left off, Peter Quill (Chris Pratt) still has no idea who his real father is until a not so chance meeting with Ego (Kurt Russell) who straight away no spoilers tell hims he is his father. From there we go into Spoiler territory and I won't do that. 

This is a film like other Marvel films is again setting up more character development, characters, locations and anything else that has to be used. It suffers a little BUT it is still very entertaining to watch!

James Gunn said in the beginning said this film will be about Peter learning about and finding his father and that is the film. Drax (Dave Bautista) and Gamora (Zoe Saldana) don't  get as much development in this, more along for the ride, BUT Yandu (Michael Rooker) gets a whole lot more screen time and is made better with his involvement with Rocket (Bradley Cooper) and Baby Groot (Vin Diesel, YES VIN DIESEL DOES BABY GROOT).  They are a great trio on screen which makes every scene, even though at times can drag on, Be very fun! 

BABY GROOT, The best thing that will be remembered about this movie will be this most adorable little baby tree thing running around being very naughty! 

Sly Stallone is in this and....i can't say anymore. 

Awesome Mix Volume 2, THIS IS GREAT AGAIN, even though like the first film they left out my favorite song on the soundtrack, they made up for it with "Southern Nights" and its scene it was playing in. SO GREAT!!! 

Yes, You need to see this for future Marvel Films 3/5 on the important scale. 

It has its flaws, but I couldn't care less. I enjoyed the hell out it! So go and check it out!

Like a number of Marvel "part 2" entries, it suffers from the push-pull between being a smaller, more character-driven sequel and providing the required mega-bucks action and spectacle.

A disappointing step down from the original, and one which has little idea what to do with the characters now that their identity as a team has been established.  Apart from doing too little of what really worked originally (the humour) and too much of the stuff that kind of worked (action sequences set to classic rock), the real flaw here is in ignoring the vaguely credible socio-political world created in the first instalment and stranding the characters on uninhabited far-flung planets.  Theyre franchise characters, without innocent bystanders to put in danger, all tension drains away.  Its unclear whether the setting up of a new team at the end is aiming for a spin-off or creating antagonists for the next instalment, but either way its far less interesting than the teaming of Sylvester Stallone, Michelle Yeoh and Ving Rhames should be.

A truly unimportant film,adding only a thin layer of character development over its duration without adding much to its story. Less of a sequel more of a Guardians 1.5. Shares a similar comedic tone as Age of Ultron where quantity always dominated the quality. The latter part of the film also overuses of tonal shifts during scenes to create some form of drama fail to hit the mark.

Having just seen Thor Ragnarok, I have to come back to this and say I am a fan of the duel converging plots of these two movies. It may seem disjointed and therefore not too enthralling for the general audience, I find it fresh and an exciting spin on the typical Marvel formula of movie making. Considering this is the direction Avengers Infinity War is going, I am eager to see this trend in more superhero films moving forward. As for this film - I very much enjoyed the mix of action and laughs this movie gave me. However, I am tiring of the toilet humor Marvel seems to gravitate towards. That being said, the movie provided me with action, beautiful visual effects, another case of perfect casting by Marvel, and an ending that left me in tears and has me eager to see where all of these characters - new and old - go.

Loved it. In my opinion, I thought this movie was better and more understandable than the first one, probably because there were less characters. This movie not only has heaps of action but tugs at the heartstrings as well. Overall, this movie is now one of my favourites, and is definitely a movie would recommend. :)

Waiting for the film to begin, I sat thinking it's amazing how 3 years ago no one cared about these characters but here I am, sitting in a packed theatre for the sequel. Marvel Studios have got these E list heroes and made them into A list heroes, now even people other than comic book fans know them.

The sequel to the movie that beat TASM2 at the box office is not surprisingly phenomenal. James Gunn expands this colourful universe and continues to develop these likable characters. These characters are what shapes the story in this sequel. Dave Bautista and Michael Rooker as Drax and Yondu are the real standouts within the fantastic bunch of characters.

I recommend you watch GOTG again before going in for this outing. Because if I hadn't I would have greatly regret it. There are numerous connections and plot points this sequel picks up on. Even some of the dialogue are significant call-backs to the first entry. The story in this sequel feels like a needed meaningful continuation unlike other recent blockbuster sequels.

Gunn displays the best opening credit scene ever! The third act of this film is the best act unlike other MCU films. The message of the film is deep and will have you thinking.

There are countless surprises throughout the film, which probably only fans with an extensive knowledge of comic books will understand. This is the first MCU film to have 5 after credits scene, at least 3 of which people without an extensive knowledge of comic books, the general audience for a better term, will not understand or be satisfied by.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2 is the definition of a sequel. This is a spectacular start to MCU's 2017. This is the type of film that will stick to your heart for some time. The sequel is worth seeing again while it plays in theatres to catch all the juicy references and easter eggs. Gunn produces a strong sequel that does not disappoint. 9/10.

P.S. Can people stop bringing their babies to the very first screening of a film. They cry during the film and ruin the experience, same thing happened with Captain America: Civil War last year. There are some people in the theatre that wait years for a film.

There is always the fear that the sequel will not live up to the original, I mean, look at any marvel cinematic universe film with a 2 at the end (Iron man 2, Thor 2, Averngers 2) all disappointing, not terrible movies but big let downs from the originals.

Guardians 1 took us all by surprise and we were sucked in by the world and the characters that James Gunn brought to life. A rag tag bunch of misfits with plenty of charm and swagger to keep even the most sceptical film goer entertained. The risk here was bringing these characters back and basically getting another dose of the same characters and plot points and being left disappointed. Luckily this film stands out for two big reasons.

1. Because we know and love these characters, Gunn leans on them more than ever, even when the action looks as amazing as any big budget action adventure film, it always comes back to these characters and because we know them so well the emotional moments in the film REALLY hit!

2. James Gunn brought himself into the Marvel universe with Guardians 1 but anyone who has seen any of his films knows this was James Gunn light, he can go full weird and crazy and totally freak an audience out. You can see in this film that Marvel are very comfortable with Gunn showing more of his flare, this isn't fully balls out like his film Super but you can see has been given license to let his quirky nature seep deeper and deeper into this world. This is more violent while still being Marvel friendly, ruder without alienating the mainstream filmgoer and honestly darker while still keeping its hip and vibrant colour palette.

If I have gripes about this film they are really minor, the opening of the film feels very cheesy like these characters have been allowed to shoot the shit for the last 3 years without anyone telling them what's funny and what's not. Not to fear, they hit their straps about 10 minutes later and it's smooth sailing after that. The soundtrack is also a bit of a letdown, don't get me wrong, still solid and the high points of this track list are amazing but as a collection of songs its not as catchy or as iconic as Guardians one. There's a great little bit that reassures fans that there is plenty of room to be playful in the soundtrack for Volume 3

To sum it up, the film is great, it stands alone as an amazing film but also as a great follow up to the previous film. For fans its a must, for new comers, come in and enjoy the ride!

You know what?

I wrote out a large chunk of text about this movie. Then I decided that I wasn't saying anything that couldn't be encapsulated in the words:

"It is a real piece of shit, don't bother."

So, there you go.

When Guardians of the Galaxy first burst onto the scene back in 2014 no-one knew who this gang of misfits were and it surprised everyone with kick-ass action, gut busting humour, and tonnes of everlasting fun. It very quickly became my favourite Marvel movie and the franchise i had no expectations for suddenly became one of my most anticipated. James Gunn returns and largely delivers on more of what you love about the first film and he even does a couple things much better, but in the end it didn't quite reach the height the first one did. The action is all there with some very big, fast, and impressive fight sequences, the humour is present with a few great running jokes and the occasional big laugh-out loud moment that hits a few times. The characters you all love are back and well, apart from Groot they thankfully haven't changed. And the story, the story is where this film surpasses its predecessor as it is more interesting, engaging, and incorporates a villain who is much better than Ronan the Accuser. 

The strongest part of this franchise is most definitely the team dynamic within the Guardians that is so rich and full of humour. The distinct personalities of Starlord, Gamora, Drax, Rocket, and Groot and how they all clash and interact back and forth throughout the film is just as fantastic as ever. It lends itself to plenty of humorous moments, some decent character building moments, but overall it allows you to remain invested in this team and all of the characters involved. The other characters such as Nebula, Mantis, and Yondu were also great with Yondu definitely being the biggest highlight of the three of them. Nebula was good although her place in the film was plentiful but not as involved in the film as a whole, rather she was there to serve a side plot that was executed pretty well throughout the film. The story i won't go into because even with seeing all the trailers there is a lot about this film that is still very secret and it is best to experience everything in the moment. I was much more invested in this story than i was in the first Guardians film so in that respect i feel like it surpassed the story of Ronan's flawed universe crushing plan. 

Now where the story was fantastic the film does take a dip in the overall flow during the second act almost in its entirety. When the guardians get to a certain planet in the film the pacing pretty drastically slows down and what follows wasn't particularly bad it just wasn't as engaging and did feel kinda disconnected from the rest of the film, like it almost stopped. There is a lot of character building in this act, a lot of plot detailing, and overall it was moving at a really slow pace and dragging a good amount. Even though during this dip the action is taking a back seat at least the humour is still present and helps to get you through it easier. But despite this average at best second act the first and third acts of this film are damn-right fantastic. The action is big, plentiful, and at times beautifully chaotic, the third act especially is where shit goes down and it is i think the best stuff we have seen from the guardians yet, so look forward to that. 

The humour was a big part of the first film and it is definitely a big part of this one. It's integrated into the action sequences very well, especially the opening sequence (similar to the opening sequence of the first film). It does a good job at using running jokes to a good length and not running them into the ground, and the humour is pretty well spaced out. Where in the first film essentially none of the humour missed, there were a few misses here and there but it's hardly anything worth criticising. There also weren't as many big hilarious moments that catch you off-guard, there were a couple but overall i didn't laugh as much as i guess i'd have hoped. 

Despite the films flaws this is still a great movie with ample humour, enough action to thoroughly entertain you, and most importantly it is still a tonne of fun. The character dynamics explored are fantastic as you'd expect and the new additions to the cast are great characters with great performances backing them, that includes Kurt Russell's introduction as Ego. I would love to praise this movie as highly as i did the first guardians film and give it the highest score but then i'd be lying as even though the first and last acts are incredible, the second act just isn't too great. I shouldn't have to tell you this by now but as this is a Marvel film there are sequences during and after the credits. This time though there are FIVE SCENES, so don't leave after 1, 2, or 3, stay right to the end until you see all 5.

'Guardians of the Galaxy: Vol. 2' is the highly-anticipated sequel to one of Marvel's surprise hits - and it doesn't disappoint. Sure, it's not as novel or zesty as the original, but it's still one of the best sequels in a long time. It still looks - and sounds - great: vibrant colours, plenty of action, both in space and on strange planets and another killer soundtrack that will grow on people as well. Great use of Fleetwood Mac and Cat Stevens, in particular.

Peter/Star Lord (Pratt) is back with his rag-tag friends/family - Gamora (Saldana), the almost-love-interest; Drax (Bautista) who's both endearingly stupid and means well; Rocket (Cooper), the alienated racoon and Groot (Diesel), in ultra-cute baby-tree form. Yondu (Rooker), Peter's adopted father and Nebula (Gillan), Gamora's sister, are dragged back into the fray, as Peter's father finally appears - Ego (Bridges, charming as ever). There's some great cameos - Hasselhoff, Stallone, and, as always, Stan Lee (+ The Watchers) - and some good development of Mantis (Klementieff) and Kraglin (Gunn).

The main plot is all about family - Peter and his new-found father, as well as his odd relationship with Yondu (and Gamora); Gamora's love/hate relationship with Nebula; Rocket being lonely and struggling to accept that he cares for others; and them all looking after Baby Groot (excellent post-credits scene too). Obviously, a great final battle scene and plenty of laughs throughout.

The latest instalment in Marvel's cosmic franchise tries just a little bit harder to be as unconventionally hilarious as the first flick and nearly succeeds. GOTG V2 has more success striking emotional chords this time around, delving deeper in each of the character's back stories. Writer/director James Gunn's fun script fortifies the character interactions within the team (it helps when the entire cast are very comfortable in their roles, even newcomers such as Kurt Russell, Elizabeth Delbicki, and Sylvester Stallone) and has a more complex story than the McGuffin plot in Vol. 1. The visuals and sight gags are as mind-blowing as ever (IMAX 3D is the way to go for the best viewing experience). And the '70s soundtrack is sublime. Long-time Marvel fans will love all the easter eggs. GOTG V2 is fun in multiple levels!
