Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is the squeal to the 2014 film, (of course) and it stars the original cast as well. 
This one is about Chris Pratt's character as he begins a relationship with his father (Kurt Russel) and knows more about him. All while trying to survive against enemies in the process.
Now before I go any farther, I want to say that  the first one was an MCU masterpiece. A true staple in pop-culture. When I watch a sequel, I expect it to be better or the same as the first.
This installment did not do this, but it was still a lot of fun.
I was five minutes into this film and I thought to myself, 'This is going to have a ton of CG isn't it', and just as I suspected, it had a lot of CGI. It was good CGI, but there was a ton of it. It also delved deeper into the characters that we were introduced to in the first. I had one problem with the the Character development though. It took almost the entire movie to figure out who the main antagonist was. For me, that was pretty confusing.
The acting was fairly solid. It could've been better considering that a large percentage of the cast was completely brought together with visual effects. The comedic side was solid as well. Like I said, it wasn't as good as the jokes in the first, but they were good enough to laugh at.
My biggest complaint is that there are times when the story gets dull. It was mostly reasonable, yet there are a few scenes where Peter develops a relationship with his father. Those scenes got old very fast.
Everything in this movie that wasn't perfect was sirtenly good.
Over all, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 wasn't as good as the first, but that doesn't mean it was bad. I had a really good time with it. 4/5 stars

Are we here to save the galaxy again? Yes. Was Vol. 2 better than Vol. 1? No. Is it still a good movie? Overall, yes it is and very enjoyable, too. How many post creds? There are 5 mini post credits. What is your favorite track from Vol. 2? The Chain by Fleetwood Mac which is what I'm listening to as I write up this review. How should I watch it? Definitely IMAX like the sound and picture quality was just amazing for a movie like this. 

The gang is once again back together to save the galaxy once more and doubling up their payment. What has been considered as one of the most anticipated movies of the summer is for the most part a great movie that is able to maintain many aspects that made the first one so great. The group has once again been able to maintain the laughter. This time, It was Drax who leads the "assholes" with so many jokes and personal stupidity. Lets also not forget our favorite Groot, being the cutest of the cute and being a typical baby he is. The more surprising character who steals the show is actually Yondu. He has more character development in this one compared to any other character in Vol. 2 and even more than he had in Vol. 1. Lets just say as a way to avoid spoilers: He is the Real MVP. Also, the visual effects were once again amazing as usual, complimenting many of the great actions scenes, especially at the end. Also, the movie once again was able to maintain the groovy 70s and 80s music and concept with the colorful galaxy theme which is why we loved the first movie in the first place. (Not gonna lie I'm too obsessed with the Chain song by Fleetwood Mac). At the same time, I do appreciate a bit more of the serious tone in this one as the movie is going into a more personal level compared to the first one, especially since Peter's father appears for the first time. Also, once again the guys had a great performance, especially for Pratt who had to show a different side of Quill we hadn't seen before and also props to Rooker as well who had a lot more screening time. But really the music is just amazing. Like there was once scene where the Chain song by Fleetwood Mac is playing and it just fits so well with the scene like I was having some chills. Definitely a lot highlighted scenes and actions. 

However, there are flaws to Vol. 2. First off, there are inconsistencies in characterization. Unlike the first one where every guardian had some purpose to their storyline, Vol. 2 gave more importance to some characters like Yondu, Rocket and Starlord but weakened others like Nebula and Gamora. Yondu as I mentioned had the most character development, which increasingly made the character more likable unlike the first. Gamora in the other hand really served little purpose in this one. I understand that she has a fit with Nebula from the previous and had to somehow address it but I felt that the plot for it was just so quick and weak. I just didn't feel at sympathy for such relationship between Gamora and Nebula whereas as the relationship between Yondu and Peter was a lot more understandable and meaningful. Heck, there was more development between Yondu and Rocket than Gamora and Nebula. Another thing is that the plot was a bit lost in the beginning. It probably took until the 30th minute to really understand what was really going on, especially since there were a few too many subplots that caused the further confusion. This somewhat caused the inconsistency but eventually it brought the pieces together. However, once it picks up, it does have a nice story to it that feels a bit more different and emotional. Lastly, Marvel's villain issue is still ongoing on this one. Not to spoil, again it was a bit lost to what was going on but once you learn more about the villain, the villain seems a bit more dangerous than other villains we have been exposed to but this villain has the least purposeful reason as to why he wanted to do such thing in the first place. However, the villain was actually quite powerful and cruel in comparison to many, even perhaps a level up in how the villain tried to accomplish his goal. Lastly, this movie is definitely a bit more personal in some character developments, so it is suppose to be a bit emotional. However, I felt it didn't reach that level that I had expected. I did have feelings at the end but not enough for me to say that it was a tearjerker. Had the story been a bit more focused and organized, this issue would perhaps been solved. But I do applaud Gunn for taking a different approach to that and trying to change the tone a bit as it is a bit more personal. 

Vol. 2 is certainly not the best Marvel movie and definitely not better than the first. However, it isn't a disastrous film and doesn't disappoint as much like Iron Man 2/3 and Avengers: Age of Ultron. Vol. 2 in the end is still a lot of fun to watch to a point where I really don't care about the noticeable flaws in the movie. Lets also add that Vol.1 was an unexpected hit that no one initially had faith in and surprised people whereas Vol. 2 already had expectations which may also add the growing flaws. So, our expectations may have affected that a bit. Nevertheless, I ended up enjoying Vol. 2 and smiling by the end of the movie, knowing that this movie is all about bringing back a great group of characters back to make us laugh and root for them to beat the bad guys like what you are suppose to get from a superhero movie. Lets also add the stupidity that just ups the laughter level. In a way, I think Vol. 2 is funnier than Vol. 1, just not entirely organized like the first. Also, I just can't help but thinking how great the track is for the movie. It also takes a more personal level take, which wasn't entirely done right but still enough for me to have some sympathy for some characters. I think people should definitely watch it for the fun and laughter and just enjoy it as if you are a kid watching a Disney movie (oh wait? It is owned by Disney but you know what I mean). I may even say that I may watch it a few more times, probably a few months from now, just not in the next week or so. Don't expect it to be the Oscar type or that will just make you disappointed. Enjoy what makes the Guardians of the Galaxy great and follow that mindset in Vol. 2. That way at least you leave the theater happy and knowing that you had a great deal of fun. Just want to emphasize, Baby Groot is the cutest thing ever to a point where I need a baby Groot. But to emphasize, I really liked it for the most part and had a lot of fun out of it.

The original Guardians of the Galaxy was a great concept that in my view never quite reached its fullest potential. It was never quite as funny as it thought it was, nor was it substantive enough for me to be fully invested in its characters and plot, but it was nonetheless still a solid film in its own right. Volume 2 could have just settled for more of the same, but instead I am happy to report that it addresses nearly all of its predecessor's problems, resulting in a vastly improved motion picture and yet another crowned gem in the seemingly infinite sea of creativity that is the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Guardians 2 opts for a more personal narrative that dives deep into all of its characters on an individual level, fleshing them out much more than the previous film while also upping the ante with its zany brand of humor. Culminating with a final act that actually carries emotional weight as it delivers the spectacle, Guardians 2 ends up as a near-masterpiece from James Gunn that oddly isn't getting as much credit as it deserves. Critics clearly didn't see the same film that I did, because this is obviously the bigger, better, and funnier film with greater character depth.

A blast of a sequel, James Gunn has delivered again with this offbeat intergalactic adventure. While not as fresh and unexpected with its humor as the first go round, the film still manages to excite. The emotional underlining helps things tremendously, with Kurt Russell giving easily his best performance in years.

The film is not without a slew of drawbacks though. The golden antagonists known as "The Sovereign" are there for little more than to be generic bad guys. The climax of the film, while thrilling, goes on and on for way too long. Lastly, one of the big reasons why the first film was such a hit was the fantastic soundtrack. This time though, the hit songs if yesteryear feel very forced in and far less organic to the story.

All that considered, this still amounts to a very fun film and an adventure worth taking.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2  answers some big questions posed in the first guardians, such as who is Star Lords father, and why did Yondu never Deliver Peter Quil(Star Lord) to him? Where the first installment was a little light on the action side this one dials it up to 10 featuring some excellent  sequences, particularly one with Rocket Racoon and another with Yondu.  Dave Batista delivers once again as the comic relief,  and  there is some really great emotional payoffs as the story continues to expand on the family theme.  All in all GOTG Vol 2 is a fun space opera and great way to kick off the summer movie season.

While much of the movie capitalized on retreading the same jokes that worked before, GOTGv2 also doubled down on the familial dynamic of the heroes. The Guardians represent a pivot that Marvel movies have made toward a cosmic and comedic style compared to the more grounded comic-book fare. The additions of Kurt Russell (Ego the living planet) and his servant Mantis were compelling and memorable characters that expanded the mythos of the group and added elements of emotional depth, especially for Peter Quill and Drax. Michael Rooker returns for a more substantial role and also provides an unexpected emotional core that establishes his character as one of the unsung standouts of the greater Marvel Universe. The villain (the movies glaring weakness) falls apart during the climax of his arc by ignoring the thoughtful set-up built through the first two-thirds of the movie and becoming a monstrous over-large CGI video game boss. It's important to note; the Guardians are only part of a much larger MCU plan, and despite the bungling of this movie's antagonist, the story did a great job of setting up an even more important villain, Thanos. Through one character's accounts of his brutal torture, they added to the mysteriousness that I'm hoping gets paid off in 2018's Infinity War. It goes without saying, Baby Groot is adorable, and I'm sure sold lots of toys. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 served as a great episode in what is basically a big screen Marvel Cinematic Universe television show.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is back and flashy as ever when it comes to its visual style of action, soundtrack, a fun cast, and the laughable humor. Usually sequels can be a let down after its predecessor set the standards high. And the build up momentum for the sequels is easily forgotten. Writer/Director James Gunn manages to continue what worked on the first movie and expand further with the characters he brought together. Yes, it is a ragtag of misfits that try to be a team and argue to each other with their own personal issues. In the end, they see each other not as friends but family. 

The plot follows Peter (Chris Pratt), Gamora (Zoe Saldana), Drax (Dave Bautista), Rocket (voiced by Bradley Cooper), and Baby Groot (voiced by Vin Diesel) are tasked at fighting away a giant monster and protecting valuable batteries. Ayesha (Elizabeth Debicki) the leader of the sovereign race, who needed the guardians help for the task. After a dispute, leaving the guardians on the run away from Ayesha and her army of drones chasing them away. The guardians crash on a planet, where they come across Ego (Kurt Russell) who is Peter's father. Ego takes Peter, Gamora, and Drax to his planet. Meanwhile, Rocket, Groot, and Nebula (Karen Gillan) stay behind their wrecked ship, only to come across the Ravagers led by Yondu (Michael Rooker). Trying to claim the bounty on the guardians that is set by Ayesha. 

Guardians of the Galaxy 2 has everything you can expect. It has plenty of action and the visual effects were colorful, and impressive. When Peter and his team visit Ego's planet. The visual effects were astonishing. The set pieces were great too. It does have its fun share of humor. It is fun to see a dysfunctional team trying to get along; you have Peter and Rocket with their arrogant cocky self. Nebula and Gamora personal conflict that keeps them fighting each other. The one thing that always drives Peter and his team is how they see each other as family. Also, there is baby groot which is always a scene stealer. Groot is small and cute, even from the opening moment of him dancing and needing music playing as the guardians are fighting against a giant monster. 

The villains are usually what worry me, as several Marvel movies later. They all have that same motive and have that cliché routine. I was worried for a second in this film about who and what the villain was. Without giving away spoilers or details. This film villain is by far better compared to the first movie. Definitely, the villain does not show until later. It definitely leads the direction into a big climax with the guardians trying to save the galaxy yet again. 

The guardians are tested personally as Peter, Gamora, and Drax are separated from Groot and Rocket being with Yondu. Gunn never lets a single moment become dull. There are easter eggs, celebrity cameos, etc. Also, there are five mid/post credit scenes that are worth checking out unlike the first movie end scene of Howard the Duck that was a waste. 

Overall, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a visually exciting sequel that surpasses the original. It has a fun cast and characters, the soundtrack is awesome, the visual effects and action is exciting, the villain is an interesting one, and James Gunn's fun direction makes it a flashy fun movie.

After the incredibly original, fun, and fresh Guardians of the Galaxy, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 tries to be a successful follow up and mostly succeeds, though it might feel a little forced. The film opens with a space battle, shortly after the events of the first film and for the next hour there is no apparent plot. There are plenty of jokes, laughs, and action sequences in the first two acts, but they are meaningless and almost tedious. It is not until the last act that a story becomes apparent, and the film goes from okay to good. Kurt Russell does great as Ego, Chris Pratt is still good as Star-Lord but not as good as the first film. Improvements in characterization include Gamora, Nebula, Rocket, and Yondu, who all develop an emotional backstory that ties the film together. But certain characters like Baby Groot, and Ayesha have no development or worthiness at all. Drax is still funny, and newcomer Mantis is a welcome addition to the Guardians. The finale is spectacular, in contrast to the rest of the film, and the payoff is very emotional as Peter finds who his true "daddy" is. Vol. 2 plays more like an episode of a T.V. story than a sequel to an epic superhero story. It is very focused, and is one of the smallest-scaled Marvel films ever made. In the end, it was fun to see the Guardians again, but Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 does not live up to the first film, and stands as middle-of-the-road Marvel entertainment.

In my opinion, I think this movie is much better than the first one. I highly recommend this movie to old and new Marvel fans of all ages.

Volume 2 is far too wrapped around its soundtrack, baby Groot's cuteness and its director's corporate loyalty like a python on a trash panda but it's funny, awe-inspiring and touching enough to fit in with this tidal wave of great Marvel movies. I can't imagine Infinity Wars solving the character development issue but if these actors continue to do wonderful things the issues won't matter much and I'll continue to be giddy on the edge of my seat like a tween. There's a part where they're being chased by a bunch of ships and are still cracking jokes, with Rocket telling Quill he's going to put a turd in his pillow case, and that it'll be one of Drax's. Drax then starts bellowing like a goon and says, "I have famously huge turds." I almost walked out of the movie at that.

Baby Groot is so annoying. It just shows how stupid society has actually gotten that people love Baby Groot. He's essentially Jar Jar but instead of people rightly being angered by such a horrible character getting focused like in the 90s when Episode 1 first came out, now everyone loves Baby Groot. With my Marvel loving friend telling me I "obviously lacked a soul and heart" since I didn't like Baby Groot. The start of the movie has the giant monster from the trailer, and instead of showing the whole fight, it focuses on Baby Groot as he dances to music while the fight is blurry in the background.

The story is bland as usual with MCU movies. It's just Peter's Dad needs Peter to help him activate these seedlings so he can take over other planets. All with bountiful jokes.

Drax was the only part I enjoyed of the first Guardians. His deadpan humor made up for the forced humor of the others. He took everything literally in the first film and that's what made him funny. Like the "everything goes over his head" line which he replied, "nothing goes over my head, I'm too quick, I would catch it." But in this movie he's "AHAHAHAHAHAHA EVERYTHING I SAY IS A JOKE!! AHAHAHAHAHAHAAHAHAHA WHY ARE YOU NOT LAUGHING? THIS IS WHAT MCU FANS LOVE!! AHAHAHAHAAHHA MEMES!!!!!" And he didn't do much in the way of "Destroying".

There's a part of the movie where Quill covers himself in rocks and turns into Pacman, which I immediately thought "oh, this movie is the comic version of Pixels!!!" Not a good thing.

I think the one scene I really enjoyed was the Ravager funeral for Yondu at the end of the film. That was it. The rest of the movie was just joke, joke, joke, reference to old songs, jokes, serious scenes that played out pretty nicely and then ruined by jokes, and more jokes.

Five post-credit scenes. None of which mattered.

Everyone's singing this movie's praise. Which doesn't surprise me. Everyone loves the MCU and always give these movies a pass on being terrible. They love the humor and don't care how basic the plot is. I honestly believe if Marvel Studios put out a two hour movie of a Marvel character sitting at a table and just sipping a cup of tea it'd get a 100% on Rotten Tomatoes and the Marvel fanboys would call it cinema at it's finest.

The movie is so bad it's cringe.

It's just so bad. So, so bad. Everyone laughed at the horrible jokes, but what had me laughing was the outrageously high score on this site.

Another thing I really like is that there are no infinity stones, no Thanos (except when mentioned in reference to the first film), no MCU continuation stuff wedged in - just a solid, interesting standalone story, expanding the scope of this subseries alone. I don't think I've ever been in so much pain.  I had to live through finals week all while waiting to see Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 and the anticipation hurt like a bitch.  Having now seen the movie, I can safely say that the wait was well worth it.  Guardians 2 was freaking awesome! I loved it and I wanna see it again.  After looking at some reviews, I feel that Vol. 2 is getting unfairly criticized for not being as "fresh" as the first movie. But I think that many people are failing to realize that it is literally not possible for a film sequel to be as "fresh" as the original, whatever that means.  And furthermore, Vol. 2 is just as inventive as Guardians 1.  When you really think about the sequel, not that much actually happens in it, yet the film is still extremely entertaining.  And it takes some serious guts and skill for a movie to be able to pull that off.  Guardians 2 also takes the time to add more dimension to its characters, including some characters who aren't necessarily audience favorites like Yondu and Nebula.  Rocket also gets some added and welcome emotional depth.  As expected, Vol. 2 was fabulously funny and the soundtrack was kicking.  I might be riding on a high, as I just saw the movie, but I honestly liked it more than the first one.  I was so happy to see the Guardians return to the galaxy and to theaters and I can't wait to see them again.

What made the original work so well was the perfect blend of humor and not taking itself seriously.  This go around in the sequel provides similar moments of humor but there is a tonal shift. I'm just goanna come out here and say it, Guardians of the Galaxy is one of my favourite movies of all time. Each and every one of the cast is fantastic, it's visually stunning; the action is nothing short of fantastic, the story is surprisingly emotional and it is by far one of the funniest movies ever made, I'm not being hyperbolic I actually believe that. So as you can see I have a huge soft spot for Guardians of the Galaxy to me it's one of those movies that's great in almost every possible way. But enough about that movie because as amazing as Guardians of the Galaxy truly is I'm not here to talk about that movie oh no. I'm here to talk about the highly anticipated follow up to that movie Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2. 
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is one of my most anticipated movies of this year and one of my most anticipated movies of all time and that is partly due to how much I love the first movie and also because I'm a huge Marvel fan in general. Marvel to me have made some of the best superhero movies in general. Some great examples would Iron man, the Avengers, Captain America the Winter Soldier, Guardians of the Galaxy, Captain America Civil War and of course Doctor Strange. Lately Marvel's movies never fail to entertain me and the MCU as a whole is one of my favourite movie and TV franchises of all time.
But now Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 has finally been released in cinemas and as you can imagine and also because of the title of this review I've seen the movie already and now I'm here to share my thoughts on the movie with you guys and after seeing it I can most can definitely say that Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 one of my most anticipated movies of all time... is one of the greatest super hero movies I have ever seen.
The level of greatness that this movie is currently at is on the level of Watchmen, the Incredibles, X- men Days of Future Past, Deadpool, Captain America Civil War! This sequel not only manages to be an entertaining follow up that more than lives up to its predecessor but it also manages to do something very different in the superhero movie genre and still manages to be an awesome movie at the same time. I'm just going to say it here and now, hands down this movie is the most fun I have had in the cinema all year, once again I'm not being hyperbolic at all I absolutely truly believe that.
For starters the cast here are absolutely fantastic. I loved Chris Pratt as Star Lord in the first movie and I loved him even more in this movie. Chris Pratt is a really funny and likeable actor and he puts that to great use here and I really like that. I really like what they do with Star Lord as a character in this movie, seeing this world through the perspective of someone who never got the chance to grow up with a real farther, who really wishes he was able to do that is really enthralling and it's through that character element that the relationship between Star Lord and his farther Ego the living plant truly blossoms (and before you guys complain about me spoiling potentially an important plot point of the film, let me just tell you that that technically it isn't a spoiler when it's in the freaking trailers thank you very much).
For me watching Star Lord Form a relationship with his long lost farther was actually really emotional and there are some moments in particular that had my eyes fill up with tears. The relation between these 2 characters is realised remarkably well here and that is definitely the movies strongest element in fact that's another pro. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is just as emotional and tear jerking as the first one. The more dramatic scenes in this movie are handled really well and make for some excellent drama and I'll admit there are a couple of scenes near the end of the movie that actually had me crying and watching Peter and Ego bond throughout the course of the movie was actually a really emotional and heart-warming. It actually reminded me of all the things I used to do with my Dad before he passed away. I related to Peter Quill in that sense because believe me I would give anything to see my Dad again and I haven't had the chance to grow up with my Dad having my back and it was really cool for me to find a character in a movie like Guardians of the Galaxy that I could relate to in that sense.
As for Ego the living planet. This is character I've been wanting to see in a Marvel movie since day one, so as you can imagine I was super hyped that this character would be appearing in this movie and thankfully Kurt Russel who plays Ego is fantastic in this movie, he gave a great performance in The Fate of the Furious and he gives a great performance in this movie so that's 2 times in a row that Kurt Russel has blown me away this year. He makes for a very intriguing character and at times a pretty creepy character but he also comes off as very off the wall and really charming. Overall I would say that Ego is one the MCU's most intriguing and unique characters and overall a great addition to the MCU.
I loved what they did with the Guardians as a team in this movie. The introduction to Ego actually sets up a conflict between the Guardians in this movie and I loved how that was handled and I enjoyed seeing that conflict grow as the film progressed because you have someone who's finally found the farther he was never able to grow up with and really wants to connect with him and do everything a farther and son would do and then you have the rest of the team who are not certain on whether or not to trust this person. This all makes for dramatic tension between the team that I feel doesn't go unwelcomed and I think it really helps to strengthen the idea that Guardians see each other as family and it was cool to see what would happen if someone who jeopardises that bond came into the lives of these people.
Outside of Star lord and Ego though the other characters in this movie are also fantastic. I liked what they did with Zoe Saldana as Gamora and Karen Gillan as Nebula. We get a closer look into their backstories in this one and I think I had a better understanding of their sister hood in this film than I did in the last. The relationship between these 2 characters was great in the first film however I think it's improved upon in this film and the actresses playing these characters give great performances and bounce off each other really well and as a matter of fact that brings me to what I feel is the best story element in this film and just the best part of the movie in general, family.
The theme of family is the driving force of this movie. We have the heart-warming farther son relationship that is formed between Peter and Ego, the troubled yet touching sisterhood that is shared between Gamora and Nebula and even this team of characters just feels like one big inseparable family of misfits, even the chemistry between our heroes just screams family. This theme is used to its full potential in this movie and works remarkably well building more emotional depth to the characters and I think it's an interesting theme to have as the main focus of a super hero movie and thankfully it works really here in Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2.
Dave Batista as Drax to me is perfect casting choices at its finest. He manages to make Drax one of the film's most interesting characters while at the same time coming off as absolutely hilarious in the best way possible, the socially awkward aspect of this character has always been one the best parts these movies, from the way he inappropriately laughs in people's faces to the way he takes metaphors way too seriously always makes for good laughs. Bradley Cooper as Rocket Racoon was absolutely hilarious, I really like how they switched things up a little with Rocket and Groot's relationship, Rocket is now having to protect Groot who is now the size of your average twig and is having to act as a sort of protector/ farther figure and that was really cool to see and as for Baby Groot, I'll admit I was worried that were going to force the idea of Baby Groot on us a little too much but thankfully they didn't and not only was he absolutely adorable but he was also  hilarious and it never felt like he was just there so the audience can think "Oh my god he's so ADORIBLE!!!" I must say though that I did end up liking Mantis quite a bit in this movie, she was a fun and likeable presence in the movie, I was worried that she would annoy me when I first saw her in the trailers, however in the end I liked her quite a bit in this movie and Pom Klementieff who is the actress that played her in this movie gave a really good performance as the character on the whole..
I have to say a pretty big surprise for me in this movie was actually Michael Rooker as Yondu. For me he was probably one of the most interesting of all the characters in this movie. We get to learn more about what he believes to be the true meaning of being a ravenger and we even get an insight as to what it was like raising 	Peter and training him to become a ravenger and just what it might have been like to raise him. Strangely but in the best way possible he has some of the film's most emotional scenes for example there's a scene near the end of the movie between him and Peter and that had me crying. But similar to most of the characters in this movie he has fair share of gags and humour that almost never fail to land perfectly.
    Now the first Guardians of the Galaxy was very effective its comedy and the whole way through that I was laughing my ass off. In terms of how effective the humour is in this film, I'm going to be completely honest, I haven't laughed that hard since Deadpool. The comedy in Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is amazing. Quite literally every joke or gag in the film had me going from chuckling to outright laughing hysterically. If there's one thing marvel always seem to nail in their movies it's the comedy and Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is no exception.
A group of people that I think really deserve praise here are the visual effects team. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is the most visually stunning marvel movie to date, yes even on the level of Doctor Strange. All the space battles look amazing; Ego the living planet looks incredible. I would also be whiling to say that this is definitely the most colourful Marvel movie as well as being one of the most colourful movies I've ever seen in general and in a really good way. Every single affect in this movie to me is virtually flawless and there are so many effects that will either blow you away, have you staring at the screen in awe and in some cases both. In other words definite well done to the visual effects team they have truly out done themselves this time and as you can imagine the action in this film is also amazing.
There are a lot of truly awesome set pieces in this movie, they are all shot, rendered and choreographed really well and the action sequences are genuinely entertaining. If I were asked what my favourite action sequence in this movie was I would honestly find it breath takingly hard to decide because every action sequence that followed was always as entertaining as the previous sequence before that.
And now the soundtrack, oh my days, the sound track for this movie. The sound track for vol. 2 has been stuck in my head ever since I walked out of that theatre. This movie has by far my favourite soundtrack out of anything marvel with a personal favourite being 'The Chain' by Fleetwood Mac, from now on that song will never fail to get me pumped up.  
You would think it would be round about here at this point in this already very long review that I would begin to explain some of the problems I had with the movie, but here's the problem. When I walked outta that theatre I came to the realisation in my mind that there was literally nothing I disliked about Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 in fact this might actually be my favourite marvel movie. James Gunn you've done it again just like with the first movie you have brought us a visual spectacle that is a hysterically funny, heart-warming and emotional movie about family that still manages to be a one hell of a kickass superhero movie. I mean I don't even have to say it; of course you should go and see this movie, you will have a blast watching it. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a definite must see!

Volume 2 doesn't quite manage to live up to the surprise and success of the first Guardians of the Galaxy, but Kurt Russell makes for an excellent addition to the cast, and baby Groot is one of the most adorable things on screen in a long time.
Visually stunning and hilarious! This is a great sequel.

While Guardians Vol 2 (aka the Drax and baby-Groot comedy hour) is a fine film, it lacks the spunk and persona that made the original stand out. While this is still the best collection of characters in the MCU, this movie lacks in giving them depth and room to grow. They almost tread on some characterization with Rocket, but the film spreads out over too many storylines to adequately do anything with it and his character feels flat as well. The film also just feels more confined and less adventurous. There are less locations, less action sequences, and less jabbing jokes between our leads. And, in Marvel tradition, the villain is cliche and uninteresting. Everything the first movie did well, this one does not quite as well. It felt like a movie that needed to be done so they can start filming Avengers 3. It's funny, entertaining, has a wonderful soundtrack, and is vibrate in its colors and scenery. But ultimately the first Guardians was far better at all of the above, along with providing an interesting plot and character arcs.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a great example of a strong sequel. While not as fresh or as captivating as the original installment, it adds upon the lore of the Guardians, as well as the Marvel Cinematic Universe. While this film is extremely funny and looks great, it can at times feel like just a filler movie for the MCU, which it ultimately is and ends up being. Regardless of that, this movie does seem to fix a bit of Marvel's villain problem, and without spoilers, has the first villain in a Marvel movie that I have thoroughly enjoyed. It also adds onto the villainous nature of Thanos, and even though he is not shown in the movie, the story arch between Nebula and Gamora gives his character a stronger background that gets you excited to see him in Avengers: Infinity War. Overall, the movie is exciting and funny with a great cast, and is a must see for all Marvel/GotG fans. 4/5
